{"uri": "8218270143", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "08:07:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T08:07:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T08:07:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/sports/football-news/euro-2024-netherlands-vs-england-semi-final-preview-tactics-head-to-head-time-venue-13791421.html", "title": "Euro 2024: Netherlands vs England semi-final preview, tactics, head-to-head, start time, venue", "body": "England take on Netherlands in the semi-final of Euro 2024. The winner takes on Spain in the final on Sunday. AP\n\nEngland manager Gareth Southgate has led his country to a third semi-final in four major tournaments. Ahead of the last-four showdown against the Netherlands at Euro 2024, there has been mounting criticism of the Three Lions' boring football.\n\nShould England end a 58-year wait to win a major trophy on Sunday, supporters may not take umbrage with the team's style, or lack thereof, but the inability of such an array of attacking stars to excite has been stunning.\n\nEngland produced just five shots on target in 240 minutes of action against Switzerland and Slovakia in the prior two rounds, needing penalties and extra-time respectively.\n\nFormer England striker Alan Shearer called the team \"rotten\", while French Euro 2000 winner Emmanuel Petit labelled England \"boring\".\n\nTold his team was \"not easy on the eye\" by a reporter, Southgate produced an assortment of reasons.\n\n\"I'm sorry for that, but our intention is always to play well with the ball - in football you have an opponent that's trying to stop you,\" he said after the win over Switzerland.\n\n\"These are not normal football matches, these are national events with huge pressure, with really young men in the middle of it.\n\n\"Our team has been under enormous pressure from the start. They are doing so well.\"\n\nSouthgate pointed to the opponents using defensive formations and blamed the grass in Germany for hampering his players.\n\nAfter reaching the 2018 World Cup semi-finals and being beaten in the Euro 2020 final on penalties by Italy, England began this tournament as one of the favourites.\n\nSouthgate noted even Spain, who by contrast have dazzled this summer in Germany, modified their style to be more direct as they beat Germany in the quarter-finals.\n\nGoals flow for Dutch\n\nEngland now face a Dutch team whose five games have produced nearly double the number of goals as England's, despite playing 60 minutes less.\n\nIn Cody Gakpo and Wout Weghorst, Ronald Koeman's side have variety to create havoc, leading to hope of a more entertaining, higher-calibre clash.\n\nNetherlands' planned pre-match press conference was cancelled on Tuesday after the Dutch had their travel plans disrupted.\n\nThe team were due to travel to Dortmund from their base in Wolfsburg by train but were unable to do so due to a blockage on the line.\n\nInstead, the Dutch were forced to fly but were unable to fulfil their media duties.\n\n\"Due to disruption of the Netherlands' planned team travel to Dortmund, their arrival has been significantly delayed and therefore no press conference will take place,\" said a statement from the Dutch football association.\n\nSouthgate said he did not think the disruption would have any impact on the outcome of the semi-final.\n\n\"We don't play until 9pm (1900GMT) tomorrow. I'm sure they will still get dinner when they arrive,\" said Southgate at his own pre-match press conference.\n\n\"They've got plenty of time. I don't see it having any impact on the game.\"\n\nEngland's Harry Kane has endured an underwhelming tournament, far from the goal machine he proved in his first season at Bayern Munich.\n\nKane clearly is nowhere close to his physical peak and now must tussle with Liverpool defender Virgil van Dijk.\n\nThe Dutchman has not been at his best either but like his team, has improved in the knockouts.\n\nWith Southgate reluctant to take off his stars, keeping Kane marshalled could go a long way to stopping the somewhat limited threat England have thus far been capable of offering.\n\nDutch left vs England right\n\nGakpo is the joint-top scorer at the Euros with three goals and has been the Netherlands' key attacking threat.\n\nMost of their dangerous moves rely on his involvement at some point, but in England right-back Kyle Walker he faces a tough defender to get the better of.\n\nThe Manchester City man can match Gakpo for pace and Southgate will instruct Bukayo Saka to be diligent in his tracking back to help minimise the threat from the left flank.\n\nAt the other end, Saka faces off with a familiar foe in City's Nathan Ake, who has fared well against him at club level, but still names the England winger as one of his toughest opponents.\n\nSouthgate vs Koeman\n\nThe managers' substitutions may well play a vital role in the outcome of the game, as was evidenced in their quarter-final wins.\n\nSouthgate brought on Luke Shaw, Cole Palmer and others and England rapidly levelled against Switzerland with just 10 minutes to go.\n\nThree of Southgate's substitutes - Ivan Toney, Trent Alexander-Arnold and Palmer - also converted their penalties in England's 5-3 shoot-out win.\n\nKoeman, meanwhile, threw on Wout Weghorst with his team 1-0 down at half-time against Turkey and secured a 2-1 win.\n\nThe six-foot-six Burnley target man put the proverbial cat among the pigeons and is raring to do so again against England, where his club career hit a bump in the road.\n\nEuropean Championship record\n\nNetherlands have won the Euros only once - back in 1988 when Koeman was part of the Dutch playing XI.\n\nEngland's last major trophy came in 1966 in the form of the FIFA World Cup. They've not won a European Championship in their history. In 2021 they reached the final but were beaten by Italy on penalties.\n\nNetherlands vs England will kickoff at 9pm local time (1900 GMT) on 10 July (Wednesday). In India it will start at 12:30am IST on 11 July (Thursday).\n\nNetherlands vs England venue\n\nNetherlands vs England will be played at the BVB Stadion in Dortmund, Germany.\n\nHow to watch Netherlands vs England?\n\nNetherlands vs England in Euro 2024 will be broadcast live on Sony Sports Network and live streamed on SonyLiv app.", "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8217465815", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:28:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:28:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:27:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.news-gazette.com/euro-2024-england-plays-the-netherlands-aiming-for-back-to-back-european-finals/article_a3c6c8c7-95f5-51cd-ad73-7fce2b5f24d3.html", "title": "Euro 2024: England plays the Netherlands aiming for back-to-back European finals", "body": "DORTMUND, Germany (AP) -- England can reach back-to-back European Championship finals when it meets the Netherlands in Dortmund in the second semifinal. The winner plays Spain or France in Sunday's final. Kickoff is at 9 p.m. local time (1900 GMT). Here's what to know about the match.\n\nMatch facts\n\n-- Both teams conceded the opening goal in their quarterfinals before coming back to win, with England beating Switzerland in a penalty shootout after a 1-1 draw and the Netherlands winning 2-1 against Turkey.\n\n-- After a win on penalties in his 100th game in charge of England, coach Gareth Southgate defending his often-cautious tactics as the kind of \"streetwise\" style successful teams use. The backlash from England fans, including some who threw plastic cups at him after a group-stage game, is \"quite difficult\" to deal with, he added.\n\n-- The Netherlands will be by far the highest-ranked team England has faced after group games with Serbia, Denmark and Slovenia, followed by knockout games with Slovakia and Switzerland.\n\n-- The referee for the game is Felix Zwayer, who once had ties to a match-fixing scandal in Germany. England midfielder Jude Bellingham was fined 40,000 euros ($43,400) in 2021 while playing for Borussia Dortmund for criticizing Zwayer.\n\n-- The Dutch endured some travel disruption on the way to Dortmund on Tuesday when their scheduled train journey from Wolfsburg was canceled because of what the team said was a \"blockage\" on the line. The squad had to fly instead, meaning the Netherlands' news conference with Ronald Koeman and defender Nathan Ak\u00e9 was called off.\n\nTeam news\n\n-- England has relied on the right-footed Kieran Trippier at left wing back, but his tendency to cut inside has meant England has made little use of the left wing all tournament. Left-footed Luke Shaw came off the bench against Switzerland for his first minutes since February after injury. Shaw says he's fit to start against the Netherlands if Southgate picks him, and the coach said Tuesday he had a tough decision to make.\n\n-- Southgate has to choose whether to stick with Ezri Konsa in the center of defense after he replaced the then-suspended Marc Gu\u00e9hi against Switzerland. Gu\u00e9hi is eligible again.\n\n-- There's scrutiny of Harry Kane's fitness after the England captain went off with cramp in extra time against Switzerland. Ivan Toney came off the bench and scored one of England's five successful penalties in the shootout.\n\n-- Netherlands coach Ronald Koeman could keep his lineup unchanged for the third game in a row, with Memphis Depay starting alongside Cody Gakpo and Steven Bergwijn up front.\n\nBy the numbers\n\n-- England has played a full hour more than the Netherlands in the last 10 days, after beating Slovakia in extra time and then Switzerland on penalties. The Dutch wrapped up their wins over Romania and Turkey without needing extra time.\n\n-- The Netherlands scored the opening goal in only one of its five games so far at Euro 2024, against Romania in the last 16. England last scored the opening goal against Denmark in the group stage.\n\n-- The Netherlands hasn't reached a European Championship final since it won the tournament in 1988 and was last a semifinalist in 2004.\n\n-- England's first shot on target against Switzerland was Bukayo Saka's goal to level the score in the 80th minute. One round earlier, Bellingham's spectacular overhead kick was England's first shot on target. That came in the fifth minute of second-half added time.\n\n-- Gakpo is the top-scoring player left at Euro 2024 with three goals. What was initially thought to be a fourth against Turkey was instead ruled to be an own-goal. Kane and Bellingham are England's top scorers with two.\n\nWhat they're saying\n\n\"I don't really understand the criticism. What he's done for the country, for us as players as well, he really took us to the next level ... I've got a lot to thank him for because he showed a lot of faith and trust in picking me when he didn't have to.\" -- England defender Luke Shaw on manager Gareth Southgate.\n\n\"You're now into that moment of the tournament where it's what's possible, what's achievable rather than what might go wrong. That is different for a player, an athlete.\" -- Southgate on the mentality shift in the England squad.\n\n\"Hopefully it's us that will have the ball more than England. So it's more England that's running. I expect a high intensity game.\" -- Netherlands defender Micky van de Ven.\n\nEllingworth reported from Duesseldorf, Germany.\n\nAP Euro 2024: https://apnews.com/hub/euro-2024", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8217667718", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "21:48:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T21:48:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T21:48:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.ocregister.com/2024/07/09/euro-2024-semifinal-what-you-need-to-know-for-england-vs-netherlands/", "title": "Euro 2024 semifinal: What you need to know for England vs. Netherlands", "body": "DORTMUND, Germany -- England can reach back-to-back European Championship finals when it meets the Netherlands in Dortmund in the second semifinal. The winner plays Spain in Sunday's final. Kickoff is at noon PT. Here's what to know about the match.\n\n-- Both teams conceded the opening goal in their quarterfinals before coming back to win, with England beating Switzerland in a penalty shootout after a 1-1 draw and the Netherlands winning 2-1 against Turkey.\n\n-- After a win on penalties in his 100th game in charge of England, coach Gareth Southgate defending his often-cautious tactics as the kind of \"streetwise\" style successful teams use. The backlash from England fans, including some who threw plastic cups at him after a group-stage game, is \"quite difficult\" to deal with, he added.\n\n-- The Netherlands will be by far the highest-ranked team England has faced after group games with Serbia, Denmark and Slovenia, followed by knockout games with Slovakia and Switzerland.\n\n-- The referee for the game is Felix Zwayer, who once had ties to a match-fixing scandal in Germany. England midfielder Jude Bellingham was fined 40,000 euros ($43,400) in 2021 while playing for Borussia Dortmund for criticizing Zwayer.\n\n-- The Dutch endured some travel disruption on the way to Dortmund on Tuesday when their scheduled train journey from Wolfsburg was canceled because of what the team said was a \"blockage\" on the line. The squad had to fly instead, meaning the Netherlands' news conference with Ronald Koeman and defender Nathan Ak\u00e9 was called off.\n\n-- England has relied on the right-footed Kieran Trippier at left wing back, but his tendency to cut inside has meant England has made little use of the left wing all tournament. Left-footed Luke Shaw came off the bench against Switzerland for his first minutes since February after injury. Shaw says he's fit to start against the Netherlands if Southgate picks him, and the coach said Tuesday he had a tough decision to make.\n\n-- Southgate has to choose whether to stick with Ezri Konsa in the center of defense after he replaced the then-suspended Marc Gu\u00e9hi against Switzerland. Gu\u00e9hi is eligible again.\n\n-- There's scrutiny of Harry Kane's fitness after the England captain went off with cramp in extra time against Switzerland. Ivan Toney came off the bench and scored one of England's five successful penalties in the shootout.\n\n-- Netherlands coach Ronald Koeman could keep his lineup unchanged for the third game in a row, with Memphis Depay starting alongside Cody Gakpo and Steven Bergwijn up front.\n\n-- England has played a full hour more than the Netherlands in the last 10 days, after beating Slovakia in extra time and then Switzerland on penalties. The Dutch wrapped up their wins over Romania and Turkey without needing extra time.\n\n-- The Netherlands scored the opening goal in only one of its five games so far at Euro 2024, against Romania in the last 16. England last scored the opening goal against Denmark in the group stage.\n\n-- The Netherlands hasn't reached a European Championship final since it won the tournament in 1988 and was last a semifinalist in 2004.\n\n-- England's first shot on target against Switzerland was Bukayo Saka's goal to level the score in the 80th minute. One round earlier, Bellingham's spectacular overhead kick was England's first shot on target. That came in the fifth minute of second-half added time.\n\n-- Gakpo and Spain's Dani Olmo are the top-scoring players left at Euro 2024 with three goals. What was initially thought to be a fourth for Gakpo against Turkey was instead ruled to be an own-goal. Kane and Bellingham are England's top scorers with two.\n\n\"I don't really understand the criticism. What he's done for the country, for us as players as well, he really took us to the next level ... I've got a lot to thank him for because he showed a lot of faith and trust in picking me when he didn't have to.\" -- England defender Luke Shaw on manager Gareth Southgate.\n\n\"You're now into that moment of the tournament where it's what's possible, what's achievable rather than what might go wrong. That is different for a player, an athlete.\" -- Southgate on the mentality shift in the England squad.\n\n\"Hopefully it's us that will have the ball more than England. So it's more England that's running. The winner plays Spain or France in final.\n\nBoth teams conceded the opening goal in their quarterfinals before coming back to win, with England beating Switzerland in a penalty shootout after a 1-1 draw and the Netherlands winning 2-1 against Turkey.\n\nAfter a win on penalties in his 100th game in charge of England, manager Gareth Southgate defended his often-cautious tactics as the kind of \"streetwise\" style successful teams use.\n\nThe backlash from England fans, including some who threw plastic cups at him after a group-stage game, is \"quite difficult\" to deal with, he added.\n\nThe Netherlands will be by far the highest-ranked team England has faced after group games with Serbia, Denmark and Slovenia, followed by knockout games with Slovakia and Switzerland.\n\nThe referee for the game is Felix Zwayer, who once had ties to a match-fixing scandal in Germany.\n\nEngland midfielder Jude Bellingham was fined 40,000 euros (USD 43,400) in 2021 while playing for Borussia Dortmund for criticizing Zwayer.\n\nEngland has relied on the right-footed Kieran Trippier at left wing-back, but his tendency to cut inside has meant England has made little use of the left-wing all tournament.\n\nLeft-footed Luke Shaw came off the bench against Switzerland for his first minutes since February after injury. Shaw says he's fit to start against the Netherlands if Southgate picks him.\n\nSouthgate has to choose whether to stick with Ezri Konsa in the centre of defence after he replaced the then-suspended Marc Gu\u00e9hi against Switzerland. Gu\u00e9hi is eligible again.\n\nThere's scrutiny of Harry Kane's fitness after the England captain went off with a cramp in extra time against Switzerland.\n\nIvan Toney came off the bench and scored one of England's five successful penalties in the shootout.\n\nNetherlands coach Ronald Koeman could keep his lineup unchanged for the third game in a row, with Memphis Depay starting alongside Cody Gakpo and Steven Bergwijn up front.\n\nBy the numbers\n\nEngland has played a full hour more than the Netherlands in the last 10 days, after beating Slovakia in extra time and then Switzerland on penalties.\n\nThe Dutch wrapped up their wins over Romania and Turkey without needing extra time.\n\nThe Netherlands scored the opening goal in only one of its five games so far at Euro 2024, against Romania in the pre-quarterfinals. England last scored the opening goal against Denmark in the group stage.\n\nThe Netherlands hasn't reached a European Championship final since it won the tournament in 1988 and was last a semi-finalist in 2004.\n\nEngland's first shot on target against Switzerland was Bukayo Saka's goal to level the score in the 80th minute.\n\nA round earlier, Bellingham's spectacular overhead kick was England's first shot on target. That came in the fifth minute of second-half added time.\n\nDutch forward Gakpo is the top-scoring player left at Euro 2024 with three goals.\n\nWhat was initially thought to be a fourth against Turkey was instead ruled to be an own goal.\n\nKane and Bellingham are England's top scorers in the ongoing Euro 2024 with two.\n\n\"I don't really understand the criticism. What he's done for the country, for us as players as well, he really took us to the next level ... I've got a lot to thank him for because he showed a lot of faith and trust in picking me when he didn't have to,\" said England defender Luke Shaw on manager Gareth Southgate.\n\n\"Hopefully, it's us that will have the ball more than England. So it's more England that's running. I expect a high-intensity game,\" said Netherlands defender Micky van de Ven. Kickoff at 12:30 am IST. {"uri": "8216736017", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "10:25:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T10:25:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T10:25:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/306430", "title": "England plays Netherlands aiming for back-to-back European finals", "body": "England can reach back-to-back European Championship finals when it meets the Netherlands in Dortmund in the second semifinal. The winner plays Spain or France in Sunday's final. Kickoff is at 9 p.m. local time (1900 GMT). Here's what to know about the match.\n\nMatch facts\n\n-- Both teams conceded the opening goal in their quarterfinals before coming back to win, with England beating Switzerland in a penalty shootout after a 1-1 draw and the Netherlands winning 2-1 against Turkey.\n\n-- After a win on penalties in his 100th game in charge of England, manager Gareth Southgate defending his often-cautious tactics as the kind of \"streetwise\" style successful teams use. The backlash from England fans, including some who threw plastic cups at him after a group-stage game, is \"quite difficult\" to deal with, he added.\n\n-- The Netherlands will be by far the highest-ranked team England has faced after group games with Serbia, Denmark and Slovenia, followed by knockout games with Slovakia and Switzerland.\n\n-- The referee for the game is Felix Zwayer, who once had ties to a match-fixing scandal in Germany. England midfielder Jude Bellingham was fined 40,000 euros ($43,400) in 2021 while playing for Borussia Dortmund for criticizing Zwayer.\n\nTeam news\n\n-- England has relied on the right-footed Kieran Trippier at left wing back, but his tendency to cut inside has meant England has made little use of the left wing all tournament. Left-footed Luke Shaw came off the bench against Switzerland for his first minutes since February after injury. Shaw says he's fit to start against the Netherlands if Southgate picks him.\n\n-- Southgate has to choose whether to stick with Ezri Konsa in the center of defense after he replaced the then-suspended Marc Gu\u00e9hi against Switzerland. Gu\u00e9hi is eligible again.\n\n-- There's scrutiny of Harry Kane's fitness after the England captain went off with cramp in extra time against Switzerland. Ivan Toney came off the bench and scored one of England's five successful penalties in the shootout.\n\n-- Netherlands coach Ronald Koeman could keep his lineup unchanged for the third game in a row, with Memphis Depay starting alongside Cody Gakpo and Steven Bergwijn up front.\n\nBy the numbers\n\n-- England has played a full hour more than the Netherlands in the last 10 days, after beating Slovakia in extra time and then Switzerland on penalties. The Dutch wrapped up their wins over Romania and Turkey without needing extra time.\n\n-- The Netherlands scored the opening goal in only one of its five games so far at Euro 2024, against Romania in the last 16. England last scored the opening goal against Denmark in the group stage.\n\n-- The Netherlands hasn't reached a European Championship final since it won the tournament in 1988 and was last a semifinalist in 2004.\n\n-- England's first shot on target against Switzerland was Bukayo Saka's goal to level the score in the 80th minute. One round earlier, Bellingham's spectacular overhead kick was England's first shot on target. That came in the fifth minute of second-half added time.\n\n-- Dutch forward Gakpo is the top-scoring player left at Euro 2024 with three goals. What was initially thought to be a fourth against Turkey was instead ruled to be an own-goal. Kane and Bellingham are England's top scorers with two.\n\nWhat they're saying\n\n\"I don't really understand the criticism. What he's done for the country, for us as players as well, he really took us to the next level ... I've got a lot to thank him for because he showed a lot of faith and trust in picking me when he didn't have to.\" -- England defender Luke Shaw on manager Gareth Southgate.\n\n\"Hopefully it's us that will have the ball more than England. So it's more England that's running. I expect a high intensity game.\" -- Netherlands defender Micky van de Ven.", "source": {"uri": "naharnet.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Naharnet"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-416032798", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "09:52:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T09:52:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T09:20:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/euro-2024-england-plays-the-netherlands-aiming-for-back-to-back-european-finals/article_bc8752e5-89b9-5679-976e-63d70d3b8fba.html", "title": "Euro 2024: England plays the Netherlands aiming for back-to-back European finals", "body": "DORTMUND, Germany (AP) -- England can reach back-to-back European Championship finals when it meets the Netherlands in Dortmund in the second semifinal. The winner plays Spain or France in Sunday's final. Kickoff is at 9 p.m. local time (1900 GMT). Here's what to know about the match.\n\nMatch facts\n\n-- Both teams conceded the opening goal in their quarterfinals before coming back to win, with England beating Switzerland in a penalty shootout after a 1-1 draw and the Netherlands winning 2-1 against Turkey.\n\n-- After a win on penalties in his 100th game in charge of England, manager Gareth Southgate defending his often-cautious tactics as the kind of \"streetwise\" style successful teams use. The backlash from England fans, including some who threw plastic cups at him after a group-stage game, is \"quite difficult\" to deal with, he added.\n\n-- The Netherlands will be by far the highest-ranked team England has faced after group games with Serbia, Denmark and Slovenia, followed by knockout games with Slovakia and Switzerland.\n\n-- The referee for the game is Felix Zwayer, who once had ties to a match-fixing scandal in Germany. England midfielder Jude Bellingham was fined 40,000 euros ($43,400) in 2021 while playing for Borussia Dortmund for criticizing Zwayer.\n\nTeam news\n\n-- England has relied on the right-footed Kieran Trippier at left wing back, but his tendency to cut inside has meant England has made little use of the left wing all tournament. Left-footed Luke Shaw came off the bench against Switzerland for his first minutes since February after injury. Shaw says he's fit to start against the Netherlands if Southgate picks him.\n\n-- Southgate has to choose whether to stick with Ezri Konsa in the center of defense after he replaced the then-suspended Marc Gu\u00e9hi against Switzerland. Gu\u00e9hi is eligible again.\n\n-- There's scrutiny of Harry Kane's fitness after the England captain went off with cramp in extra time against Switzerland. Ivan Toney came off the bench and scored one of England's five successful penalties in the shootout.\n\n-- Netherlands coach Ronald Koeman could keep his lineup unchanged for the third game in a row, with Memphis Depay starting alongside Cody Gakpo and Steven Bergwijn up front.\n\nBy the numbers\n\n-- England has played a full hour more than the Netherlands in the last 10 days, after beating Slovakia in extra time and then Switzerland on penalties. The Dutch wrapped up their wins over Romania and Turkey without needing extra time.\n\n-- The Netherlands scored the opening goal in only one of its five games so far at Euro 2024, against Romania in the last 16. England last scored the opening goal against Denmark in the group stage.\n\n-- The Netherlands hasn't reached a European Championship final since it won the tournament in 1988 and was last a semifinalist in 2004.\n\n-- England's first shot on target against Switzerland was Bukayo Saka's goal to level the score in the 80th minute. One round earlier, Bellingham's spectacular overhead kick was England's first shot on target. That came in the fifth minute of second-half added time.\n\n-- Dutch forward Gakpo is the top-scoring player left at Euro 2024 with three goals. What was initially thought to be a fourth against Turkey was instead ruled to be an own-goal. Kane and Bellingham are England's top scorers with two.\n\nWhat they're saying\n\n\"I don't really understand the criticism. What he's done for the country, for us as players as well, he really took us to the next level ... I've got a lot to thank him for because he showed a lot of faith and trust in picking me when he didn't have to.\" -- England defender Luke Shaw on manager Gareth Southgate.\n\n\"Hopefully it's us that will have the ball more than England. So it's more England that's running. I expect a high intensity game.\" -- Netherlands defender Micky van de Ven.\n\nEllingworth reported from Duesseldorf, Germany.\n\nAP Euro 2024: https://apnews.com/hub/euro-2024", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8216774747", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "10:50:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T10:50:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T10:50:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.mid-day.com/sports/football/article/euro-2024-england-faces-netherlands-in-bid-for-consecutive-european-finals-23362065", "title": "Euro 2024: England faces Netherlands in bid for consecutive European finals", "body": "England can reach back-to-back European Championship finals when it meets the Netherlands in Dortmund in the second semis\n\nEngland can reach back-to-back European Championship finals when it meets the Netherlands in Dortmund in the second Euro 2024 semi-final. The winner plays Spain or France in Sunday's final.\n\nKick-off is at 9 pm local time 1900 GMT, 12.30 am (Thursday). Here's what to know about the match.\n\nBoth teams conceded the opening goal in their quarterfinals before coming back to win, with England beating Switzerland in a penalty shootout after a 1-1 draw and the Netherlands winning 2-1 against Turkey.\n\nAfter a win on penalties in his 100th game in charge of England, manager Gareth Southgate defended his often-cautious tactics as the kind of 'streetwise' style successful teams use. The backlash from England fans, including some who threw plastic cups at him after a group-stage game, is 'quite difficult' to deal with, he added.\n\nThe Netherlands will be by far the highest-ranked team England has faced after group games with Serbia, Denmark and Slovenia, followed by knockout games with Slovakia and Switzerland.\n\nThe referee for the game is Felix Zwayer, who once had ties to a match-fixing scandal in Germany. England midfielder Jude Bellingham was fined 40,000 euros (USD 43,400) in 2021 while playing for Borussia Dortmund for criticizing Zwayer.\n\nTeam news\n\nEngland has relied on the right-footed Kieran Trippier at left wing-back, but his tendency to cut inside has meant England has made little use of the left-wing all tournament. Left-footed Luke Shaw came off the bench against Switzerland for his first minutes since February after injury. Shaw says he's fit to start against the Netherlands if Southgate picks him.\n\nSouthgate has to choose whether to stick with Ezri Konsa in the centre of defence after he replaced the then-suspended Marc Gu\u00e9hi against Switzerland. Gu\u00e9hi is eligible again.\n\nThere's scrutiny of Harry Kane's fitness after the England captain went off with a cramp in extra time against Switzerland. Ivan Toney came off the bench and scored one of England's five successful penalties in the shootout.\n\nNetherlands coach Ronald Koeman could keep his lineup unchanged for the third game in a row, with Memphis Depay starting alongside Cody Gakpo and Steven Bergwijn up front.\n\nBy the numbers\n\nEngland has played a full hour more than the Netherlands in the last 10 days, after beating Slovakia in extra time and then Switzerland on penalties. The Dutch wrapped up their wins over Romania and Turkey without needing extra time.\n\nThe Netherlands scored the opening goal in only one of its five games so far at Euro 2024, against Romania in the pre-quarterfinals. England last scored the opening goal against Denmark in the group stage.\n\nAlso Read: Euro 2024: Battle for glory! Four European powerhouses vie for final berth\n\nThe Netherlands hasn't reached a European Championship final since it won the tournament in 1988 and was last a semi-finalist in 2004.\n\nEngland's first shot on target against Switzerland was Bukayo Saka's goal to level the score in the 80th minute. A round earlier, Bellingham's spectacular overhead kick was England's first shot on target. That came in the fifth minute of second-half added time.\n\nDutch forward Gakpo is the top-scoring player left at Euro 2024 with three goals. What was initially thought to be a fourth against Turkey was instead ruled to be an own goal. Kane and Bellingham are England's top scorers with two.\n\nWhat they're saying\n\n\"I don't really understand the criticism. What he's done for the country, for us as players as well, he really took us to the next level ... I've got a lot to thank him for because he showed a lot of faith and trust in picking me when he didn't have to.\" - England defender Luke Shaw on manager Gareth Southgate.", "source": {"uri": The backlash from England fans, including some who threw plastic cups at him after a group-stage game, is \"quite difficult\" to deal with, he added.\n\n- The Netherlands will be by far the highest-ranked team England has faced after group games with Serbia, Denmark and Slovenia, followed by knockout games with Slovakia and Switzerland.\n\n- The referee for the game is Felix Zwayer, who once had ties to a match-fixing scandal in Germany. England midfielder Jude Bellingham was fined 40,000 euros ($43,400) in 2021 while playing for Borussia Dortmund for criticizing Zwayer.\n\n- England has relied on the right-footed Kieran Trippier at left wing back, but his tendency to cut inside has meant England has made little use of the left wing all tournament. Left-footed Luke Shaw came off the bench against Switzerland for his first minutes since February after injury. England last scored the opening goal against Denmark in the group stage.\n\n- The Netherlands hasn't reached a European Championship final since it won the tournament in 1988 and was last a semifinalist in 2004.\n\n- England's first shot on target against Switzerland was Bukayo Saka's goal to level the score in the 80th minute. One round earlier, Bellingham's spectacular overhead kick was England's first shot on target. That came in the fifth minute of second-half added time.\n\n- Dutch forward Gakpo is the top-scoring player left at Euro 2024 with three goals. So it\u00b4s more England that\u00b4s running. I expect a high intensity game.\" - Netherlands defender Micky van de Ven.\n\nEllingworth reported from Duesseldorf, Germany.\n\nAP Euro 2024: https://apnews.com/hub/euro-2024\n\nEngland's manager Gareth Southgate embraces England's Harry Kane after Kane is substituted off during a quarterfinal match between England and Switzerland at the Euro 2024 soccer tournament in Duesseldorf, Germany, Saturday, July 6, 2024. {"uri": "2024-07-416550065", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "17:38:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T17:38:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T09:34:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://arab.news/nx4at", "title": "Euro 2024: England plays the Netherlands aiming for back-to-back", "body": "DORTMUND: England can reach back-to-back European Championship finals when it meets the Netherlands in Dortmund in the second semifinal. The winner plays Spain or France in Sunday's final. Kickoff is at 9 p.m. local time (1900 GMT). Here's what to know about the match.\n\nMatch facts\n\n-- Both teams conceded the opening goal in their quarterfinals before coming back to win, with England beating Switzerland in a penalty shootout after a 1-1 draw and the Netherlands winning 2-1 against Turkiye.\n\n-- After a win on penalties in his 100th game in charge of England, manager Gareth Southgate defending his often-cautious tactics as the kind of \"streetwise\" style successful teams use. The backlash from England fans, including some who threw plastic cups at him after a group-stage game, is \"quite difficult\" to deal with, he added.\n\n-- The Netherlands will be by far the highest-ranked team England has faced after group games with Serbia, Denmark and Slovenia, followed by knockout games with Slovakia and Switzerland.\n\n-- The referee for the game is Felix Zwayer, who once had ties to a match-fixing scandal in Germany. England midfielder Jude Bellingham was fined 40,000 euros ($43,400) in 2021 while playing for Borussia Dortmund for criticizing Zwayer.\n\nTeam news\n\n-- England has relied on the right-footed Kieran Trippier at left wing back, but his tendency to cut inside has meant England has made little use of the left wing all tournament. Left-footed Luke Shaw came off the bench against Switzerland for his first minutes since February after injury. Shaw says he's fit to start against the Netherlands if Southgate picks him.\n\n-- Southgate has to choose whether to stick with Ezri Konsa in the center of defense after he replaced the then-suspended Marc Gu\u00e9hi against Switzerland. Gu\u00e9hi is eligible again.\n\n-- There's scrutiny of Harry Kane's fitness after the England captain went off with cramp in extra time against Switzerland. Ivan Toney came off the bench and scored one of England's five successful penalties in the shootout.\n\n-- Netherlands coach Ronald Koeman could keep his lineup unchanged for the third game in a row, with Memphis Depay starting alongside Cody Gakpo and Steven Bergwijn up front.\n\nBy the numbers\n\n-- England has played a full hour more than the Netherlands in the last 10 days, after beating Slovakia in extra time and then Switzerland on penalties. The Dutch wrapped up their wins over Romania and Turkiye without needing extra time.\n\n-- The Netherlands scored the opening goal in only one of its five games so far at Euro 2024, against Romania in the last 16. England last scored the opening goal against Denmark in the group stage.\n\n-- The Netherlands hasn't reached a European Championship final since it won the tournament in 1988 and was last a semifinalist in 2004.\n\n-- England's first shot on target against Switzerland was Bukayo Saka's goal to level the score in the 80th minute. One round earlier, Bellingham's spectacular overhead kick was England's first shot on target. That came in the fifth minute of second-half added time.\n\n-- Dutch forward Gakpo is the top-scoring player left at Euro 2024 with three goals. What was initially thought to be a fourth against Turkiye was instead ruled to be an own-goal. Kane and Bellingham are England's top scorers with two.\n\nWhat they're saying\n\n\"I don't really understand the criticism. What he's done for the country, for us as players as well, he really took us to the next level ... I've got a lot to thank him for because he showed a lot of faith and trust in picking me when he didn't have to.\" -- England defender Luke Shaw on manager Gareth Southgate.\n\n\"Hopefully it's us that will have the ball more than England. So it's more England that's running. I expect a high intensity game.\" -- Netherlands defender Micky van de Ven.", "source": {"uri": "arab.news", "dataType": "news", "title": "Arab News"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8217649239", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "21:28:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T21:28:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T21:26:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.gulf-times.com/article/686370/sports/england-now-dreaming-of-history-not-fearing-failure", "title": "'England now dreaming of history, not fearing failure'", "body": "England manager Gareth Southgate, players Phil Foden, Cole Palmer and Eberechi Eze during a training session in Blankenhain, Germany, on Tuesday. (Reuters) England manager Gareth Southgate believes his side have been freed up by edging closer to a first ever major final on foreign soil at Euro 2024 after struggling to deal with the weight of expectation earlier in the tournament.\n\nThe Three Lions arrived in Germany as one of the favourites thanks to a richly-talented squad and an upturn in their fortunes under Southgate. England are into a third semi-final in four tournaments, where they will face the Netherlands in Dortmund today.\n\nBut they have never reached a final outside of England or won the European Championship before.\n\nSouthgate's men have been heavily criticised for their performances at Euro 2024, where they have won only one of their five games in 90 minutes.\n\nBut he said his players showed signs of what they are capable of in a quarter-final win over Switzerland on penalties after needing a late Bukayo Saka equaliser to send the game to extra time.\n\n\"One of our strengths over the last eight years has been less fear, less inhibition but at the beginning the expectation weighed heavily,\" said Southgate at his pre-match press conference on Tuesday.\n\n\"We couldn't quite get ourselves in the right place and in the end what was impressive was the players ground results out.\n\n\"Now we are into that moment in the tournament where it is what is possible? What is achievable? Rather than, what could go wrong?\n\n\"That is different for a player. This is now the chance to make history, first time to make a final not held in England. We are trying to break new ground and that is difficult, but the players have responded brilliantly.\"\n\nEngland's only previous European Championship final was three years ago when they missed out agonisingly on penalties to Italy at Wembley.\n\nHarry Kane has been captain for almost the entirety of the Southgate era in charge and believes his side can lean on that experience against a Dutch side in their first Euros semi-final since 2004.\n\n\"We've got a lot of players who have experienced big games at international and club level,\" said Bayern Munich striker Kane.\n\n\"You use that experience over the course of your career to prepare the best way possible to control nerves and excitement tomorrow night will be not different.\n\n\"We had a goal, a target of what we think it is achievable and step-by-step we've been getting closer to that target.\n\n\"We've got ourselves in a great spot and we've got a big game to reach back-to-back finals in the European Championships which would be an amazing achievement.\"\n\nSouthgate has all of his 26-man squad available with Luke Shaw pushing for his first start of the tournament. The Manchester United left-back made his first appearance for club or country since February as a substitute against the Swiss.\n\nMarc Guehi looks set to return from suspension in place of Ezri Konsa, but Southgate looks set to stick with the 3-4-2-1 formation he used in the quarter-final.\n\nNetherlands hit by travel chaos ahead of semi\n\nThe Netherlands' planned pre-match press conference ahead of today's Euro 2024 semi-final against England was cancelled on Tuesday after the Dutch had their travel plans disrupted.\n\nRonald Koeman's men were due to travel to Dortmund from their base in Wolfsburg by train but were unable to do so due to a blockage on the line. Instead, the Dutch were forced to fly but were unable to fulfil their media duties due to their late arrival.\n\n\"Due to disruption of the Netherlands' planned team travel to Dortmund, their arrival has been significantly delayed and therefore no press conference will take place,\" said a statement from the Dutch football association.\n\nEngland boss Gareth Southgate said he did not think the disruption would have any impact on the outcome of the semi-final.\n\n\"We don't play until 9pm (1900GMT) tomorrow. I'm sure they will still get dinner when they arrive,\" said Southgate at his own pre-match press conference.\n\n\"They've got plenty of time. I don't see it having any impact on the game.\"\n\nFrom Koeman's free-kick to Euro 96: Five Netherlands v England clashes\n\nThe Netherlands and England meet in the last four of Euro 2024 today with both teams eyeing a place in this weekend's final in Berlin. There was a time when the two nations met regularly on the international stage, but the match in Dortmund will be just the second competitive game between the sides this century. AFP Sport looks back at their most notable past encounters:\n\nVan Basten hat-trick: The 1988 European Championship remains the only major international tournament that the Netherlands have won, and will always be remembered for Marco van Basten's stunning goal in the final against the Soviet Union. It also remains a low point for England, the only time in which they have gone to a major tournament and lost every game. Both sides lost their opening match before they clashed in Duesseldorf in the group phase, and the Dutch came out on top thanks to a Van Basten hat-trick. England had chances, with Gary Lineker and Glenn Hoddle both hitting the post. Van Basten's opener for the Netherlands was cancelled out by a Bryan Robson equaliser just after half-time, but two goals in five second-half minutes allowed Van Basten to complete his hat-trick and sealed a 3-1 Dutch win.\n\nDraw at Italia 90: The nations were again drawn in the same group at the 1990 World Cup in Italy, and many of the players involved in 1988 again featured in this meeting in Cagliari, among them current Dutch boss Ronald Koeman. The sides had each drawn their opening match, with England being held by Ireland and the Netherlands by Egypt. This time England kept Van Basten quiet in a 0-0 draw, and it was England who would top the group on the way to reaching the semi-finals. The Dutch, meanwhile, were beaten by West Germany in the last 16.\n\nEngland miss out on USA 94: England have failed to qualify for just one World Cup since the 1970s, and it was the Netherlands who denied them a place at USA 94. Graham Taylor's England had a poor campaign, taking just one point from two games against Norway, who topped the group. They squandered a two-goal lead at home to the Dutch at Wembley, but when they went to Rotterdam for the return fixture - their penultimate game in the group - England still had qualification in their own hands as they were above the Dutch. With Paul Gascoigne suspended, England fell behind to a free-kick just after the hour mark by Koeman - who the visitors felt should have been sent off earlier on - before Dennis Bergkamp sealed a 2-0 Dutch win. England beat San Marino in their final game but a Dutch win in Poland ensured they qualified instead. It was a disastrous campaign for Taylor, captured in a warts-and-all TV documentary. Taylor later resigned, while the Dutch reached the World Cup quarter-finals.\n\nShearer, Sheringham double act: The nations met again in the group stage at Euro 96. Both teams had taken four points from their first two matches before clashing at Wembley, where Alan Shearer opened the scoring with a penalty and added another goal early in the second half, in between a brace by Teddy Sheringham. Patrick Kluivert's late goal for the Dutch made the final score 4-1 as England - who had current boss Gareth Southgate in defence - won the group and the Netherlands squeezed through in second place ahead of Scotland. The Dutch lost on penalties to France in the last eight, while England were beaten in a shoot-out in the semi-finals by Germany, with Southgate missing the crucial kick.\n\nDutch win Nations League semi: The only competitive meeting of the teams since Euro 96 came in the semi-finals of the inaugural UEFA Nations League in 2019. Southgate was already England's manager and Koeman was in his first spell as Dutch coach as the teams clashed in Guimaraes, Portugal. Marcus Rashford put England ahead from a penalty but Matthijs de Ligt levelled, taking the game to extra time.\n\nKyle Walker's own goal gave the Dutch the lead and Quincy Promes sealed a 3-1 victory for the Netherlands, who would lose the final to hosts Portugal.", "source": {"uri": "gulf-times.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Gulf-Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8216702593", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "10:06:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T10:06:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T10:05:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-euro-2024-england-plays-the-netherlands-aiming-for-back-to-back-european-finals-6097282.html", "title": "Sports News | Euro 2024: England Plays the Netherlands Aiming for Back-to-back European Finals | LatestLY", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on Sports at LatestLY. England can reach back-to-back European Championship finals when it meets the Netherlands in Dortmund in the second semi-final. The winner plays Spain or France in Sunday's final.\n\nDortmund (Germany), Jul 9 (AP) England can reach back-to-back European Championship finals when it meets the Netherlands in Dortmund in the second semi-final. The winner plays Spain or France in Sunday's final.\n\nKick-off is at 9 pm local time (1900 GMT, 12.30 am [Thursday]). Here's what to know about the match.\n\nAlso Read | Is Urvashi Rautela Dating Anyone? Actress Has THIS To Declare Amidst Her Linkup Rumours With Cricketer Rishabh Pant and Footballer Karim Benzema (LatestLY Exclusive).\n\nAlso Read | Will Kylian Mbappe Play Tonight in Spain vs France UEFA Euro 2024 Semifinal Match? Here's the Possibility of French Star Featuring in Starting XI.\n\nMatch facts\n\n-- Both teams conceded the opening goal in their quarterfinals before coming back to win, with England beating Switzerland in a penalty shootout after a 1-1 draw and the Netherlands winning 2-1 against Turkey.\n\n-- After a win on penalties in his 100th game in charge of England, manager Gareth Southgate defended his often-cautious tactics as the kind of \"streetwise\" style successful teams use. The backlash from England fans, including some who threw plastic cups at him after a group-stage game, is \"quite difficult\" to deal with, he added.\n\n-- The Netherlands will be by far the highest-ranked team England has faced after group games with Serbia, Denmark and Slovenia, followed by knockout games with Slovakia and Switzerland.\n\n-- The referee for the game is Felix Zwayer, who once had ties to a match-fixing scandal in Germany. England midfielder Jude Bellingham was fined 40,000 euros (USD 43,400) in 2021 while playing for Borussia Dortmund for criticizing Zwayer.\n\nTeam news\n\n-- England has relied on the right-footed Kieran Trippier at left wing-back, but his tendency to cut inside has meant England has made little use of the left-wing all tournament. Left-footed Luke Shaw came off the bench against Switzerland for his first minutes since February after injury. Shaw says he's fit to start against the Netherlands if Southgate picks him.\n\n-- Southgate has to choose whether to stick with Ezri Konsa in the centre of defence after he replaced the then-suspended Marc Gu\u00e9hi against Switzerland. Gu\u00e9hi is eligible again.\n\n-- There's scrutiny of Harry Kane's fitness after the England captain went off with a cramp in extra time against Switzerland. Ivan Toney came off the bench and scored one of England's five successful penalties in the shootout.\n\n-- Netherlands coach Ronald Koeman could keep his lineup unchanged for the third game in a row, with Memphis Depay starting alongside Cody Gakpo and Steven Bergwijn up front.\n\nBy the numbers\n\n-- England has played a full hour more than the Netherlands in the last 10 days, after beating Slovakia in extra time and then Switzerland on penalties. The Dutch wrapped up their wins over Romania and Turkey without needing extra time.\n\n-- The Netherlands scored the opening goal in only one of its five games so far at Euro 2024, against Romania in the pre-quarterfinals. England last scored the opening goal against Denmark in the group stage.\n\n-- The Netherlands hasn't reached a European Championship final since it won the tournament in 1988 and was last a semi-finalist in 2004.\n\n-- England's first shot on target against Switzerland was Bukayo Saka's goal to level the score in the 80th minute. A round earlier, Bellingham's spectacular overhead kick was England's first shot on target. That came in the fifth minute of second-half added time.\n\n-- Dutch forward Gakpo is the top-scoring player left at Euro 2024 with three goals. What was initially thought to be a fourth against Turkey was instead ruled to be an own goal. Kane and Bellingham are England's top scorers with two.\n\nWhat they're saying\n\n\"I don't really understand the criticism. What he's done for the country, for us as players as well, he really took us to the next level ... I've got a lot to thank him for because he showed a lot of faith and trust in picking me when he didn't have to.\" -- England defender Luke Shaw on manager Gareth Southgate.\n\n\"Hopefully, it's us that will have the ball more than England. So it's more England that's running. I expect a high-intensity game.\" -- Netherlands defender Micky van de Ven. {"uri": "8216684040", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "09:54:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T09:54:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T09:54:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://technosports.co.in/euro-2024-semi-netherlands-vs-england-preview/", "title": "Euro 2024 Semi-Final: Netherlands vs England - Preview", "body": "Leny Yoro only wants Real Madrid transfer with contract running out in 2025\n\nFor the second time in five years, these two European powerhouses face off in a semi-final. The Netherlands emerged victorious 3-1 after extra time in their Nations League clash in 2019. Given their history, it wouldn't be surprising if this highly-anticipated encounter went the distance again; five of their last eight meetings have ended in a draw after 90 minutes.\n\nThe Netherlands secured their first EURO semi-final appearance since 2004 by defeating T\u00fcrkiye. England, meanwhile, have reached this stage for the second consecutive tournament.\n\nHere's a preview and prediction for the Euro 2024 semi-final between the Netherlands and England, set to take place on Thursday in Dortmund.\n\nRead More: Portugal's New Penalty Hero: Decoding Diogo Costa's Record-Breaking Saves\n\nEngland have stumbled through Euro 2024, but they've still managed to reach another semi-final.\n\nFor the third time at a major tournament under Gareth Southgate, the Three Lions have made it to the last four. Since the start of the 2018 World Cup, the only competition in which they failed to reach this stage was the 2022 World Cup in Qatar.\n\nNow, standing in their way of a consecutive Euros final are the Netherlands.\n\nRonald Koeman's side was unconvincing in the group stage but have found their form in the knockout rounds. Unlike their opponents in Dortmund on Wednesday, the Netherlands have hit their stride in the knockouts.\n\nEngland needed extra time and a stunning goal from Jude Bellingham to overcome Slovakia, then relied on perfect penalty kicks and a crucial save from Jordan Pickford to defeat Switzerland. In contrast, the Netherlands defeated Romania 3-0 and Turkey 2-1 within 90 minutes.\n\nEngland have gone to extra time in both of their knockout matches so far. Only Portugal at Euro 2016, and Spain and Italy at Euro 2020, have ever gone to extra time three times in a single edition of the finals.\n\nWhile Southgate has faced criticism for England's performances in Germany, his major tournament record is impressive.\n\nFrom 1996 to 2018, England went 22 years without reaching a semi-final. Since then, they've made it to the final four three times, including their World Cup run in Russia six years ago.\n\nAfter 65 years without reaching a men's final, England is now on the verge of back-to-back appearances in a major tournament's biggest event. Only five teams have reached consecutive Euro finals: USSR (1960/1964), Germany (1972/1976, 1976/1980, 1992/1996), and Spain (2008/2012).\n\nThis marks England's fourth appearance in the semi-finals of the European Championship. They were eliminated in the first two in 1968 (vs Yugoslavia) and 1996 (vs Germany). At Euro 2020, they reached the final after defeating Denmark 2-1 but lost on penalties to Italy at Wembley.\n\nBukayo Saka redeemed his 2021 penalty miss with a composed effort in the shootout against Switzerland and forced extra time with a superb strike. He is likely to start on the right again despite recent discussions about moving him to the left, especially with Luke Shaw returning from the bench in the quarter-finals.\n\nFor the Netherlands, this will be their sixth Euros semi-final. They have lost their last four, with their only victory in 1988 when they went on to win the tournament. Marco van Basten scored one of the most famous goals in Euros history in that final in Munich.\n\nThis is the Netherlands' first Euros semi-final since 2004 when they lost 2-1 to host nation Portugal. Back then, there were only 16 teams in the competition, making the path to the semi-finals shorter than it is now.\n\nThis marks the fourth encounter between England and the Netherlands at a major tournament. The Oranje triumphed 3-1 at Euro 88, thanks to a Van Basten hat-trick, followed by a goalless draw at the 1990 World Cup, and a 4-1 England victory at Euro 96.\n\nAmong all the nations England have faced 20+ times in their history, only against Brazil (15%) do they have a lower win rate than against the Netherlands (27% - W6 D9 L7).\n\nIn fact, England have won just one of their last nine meetings with the Netherlands in all competitions (D4 L4), with their sole victory being a 1-0 friendly match in Amsterdam in March 2018.\n\nThe Netherlands have one spot in their attack up for grabs as they prepare to face England in the Euro 2024 semi-finals.\n\nWout Weghorst is making a strong case to lead the line after another impressive performance off the bench in the Dutch victory over Turkey.\n\nSteven Bergwijn has struggled in his recent starts on the right flank, making way for Jeremie Frimpong and Donyell Malen, who has had a mixed Euros highlighted by two late goals against Romania in the last-16.\n\nRonald Koeman has used Weghorst, who is still under contract with Burnley, as a super-sub in Germany. However, there are increasing calls for him to start, especially with a place in the final at stake.\n\nStarting Weghorst would allow Memphis Depay to play in a free role behind the striker and move Xavi Simons to the right wing, while Cody Gakpo looks to continue his strong form on the left.\n\nJoey Veerman began the tournament in the Netherlands' starting XI but has since been replaced by AC Milan's Tijjani Reijnders and PSV Eindhoven's Jerdy Schouten.\n\nThe Dutch have a settled defense with Virgil van Dijk and Stefan de Vrij preferred over Matthijs de Ligt and Micky van de Ven. The Tottenham defender has been used as a substitute left-back for Nathan Ake in all four of his appearances at the Euros.\n\nDenzel Dumfries will provide pace and power from the right-back position, and Brighton's Bart Verbruggen is set to continue in goal.\n\nGareth Southgate faces a crucial decision on whether Luke Shaw is ready to start England's semi-final against the Netherlands as their Euro 2024 campaign nears its climax.\n\nSouthgate's team has reached their third semi-final in the last four tournaments and is just one win away from becoming the first England men's team to reach a major final overseas.\n\nShaw made his long-awaited return from a hamstring injury as a substitute during the dramatic quarter-final victory over Switzerland. He played nearly 45 minutes without issues after the match extended to penalties.\n\nThe Manchester United star is the only specialist left-back in Southgate's squad. The Three Lions boss must decide whether Shaw is ready for his first start in five months against the Dutch in Dortmund or if Kieran Trippier will continue as his deputy.\n\nShaw has expressed his readiness to start, but the final decision is yet to be made.\n\nAdditionally, Crystal Palace center-back Marc Guehi is available again after suspension and is likely to replace Ezri Konsa, though Konsa performed well against the Swiss and also has chances to start.\n\nSouthgate's other significant decision is whether to use a back three or back four. England switched to a wing-back system against Switzerland, producing arguably their best performance of the tournament. However, since the Dutch play with a back four, Southgate might consider matching Ronald Koeman's side.\n\nEngland clearly possess more talent and experience in these games. Southgate highlighted this after the win over Switzerland, and it should play a significant role here.\n\nWhile England's defense has been stellar, they struggle to finish off opponents and appear vulnerable to counter-attacks when they take risks.\n\nHowever, the Dutch have their own issues. Their defense can be slow and ponderous, they've lacked midfield control, and they lack a killer touch in attack. Nonetheless, they can be dangerous with crosses, quick interchanges, and long-range shots.\n\nThis is expected to be a tight game that could go the distance, but England's knowhow and quality might pull them through.\n\nPrediction: England to win on penalties.\n\nUEFA Euro 2024 matches will be broadcast live on Sony Sports channels: Sony Sports Ten 2, Sony Sports Ten 2 HD, Sony Sports Ten 3, Sony Sports Ten 3 HD, Sony Sports Ten 4, Sony Sports Ten 4 HD, Sony Sports Ten 5, and Sony Sports Ten 5 HD in India. Live streaming of Euro 2024 can be accessed through the SonyLIV app and website.\n\nYou can watch the match in 11 July from 12:30 am onwards on Sony Sports channels: Sony Sports Ten 2, Sony Sports Ten What he's done for the country, for us as players as well, he really took us to the next level ... I've got a lot to thank him for because he showed a lot of faith and trust in picking me when he didn't have to,\" said England defender Luke Shaw on Southgate's performance.\n\nThe Netherlands will be, by far, the highest-ranked team England have faced after group games with Serbia, Denmark and Slovenia, followed by knockout games with Slovakia and Switzerland.\n\n\"You're now into that moment of the tournament where it's what's possible, what's achievable, rather than what might go wrong. That is different for a player, an athlete,\" said Southgate, speaking about the mentality the team would need to get by the Dutch.\n\nEngland have played one hour more than their Dutch counterparts, and defender Micky van de Ven is hoping the latter can take advantage of that.\n\n\"Hopefully, it's us that will have the ball more than England. So it's more England that's running. I expect a high-intensity game,\" he said.\n\nThe referee for the game is Felix Zwayer, who once had ties to a match-fixing scandal in Germany. England midfielder Jude Bellingham was fined 40,000 euros ($43,400) in 2021, while playing for Borussia Dortmund, for criticising Zwayer.\n\nThe Dutch endured some travel disruption on the way to Dortmund yesterday when their scheduled train journey from Wolfsburg was cancelled because of what the team said was a \"blockage\" on the line. The squad had to fly instead, meaning the Netherlands' news conference with Ronald Koeman and defender Nathan Ak\u00e9 was called off.\n\nEngland has relied on the right-footed Kieran Trippier at left wing back, but his tendency to cut inside has meant England have made little use of the left wing all tournament. Left-footed Luke Shaw came off the bench against Switzerland for his first minutes since February after injury. Shaw says he's fit to start against the Netherlands if Southgate picks him, and the coach said yesterday he had a tough decision to make.\n\nSouthgate also has to choose whether to stick with Ezri Konsa in the centre of defence after he replaced the then-suspended Marc Gu\u00e9hi against Switzerland. Gu\u00e9hi is eligible again.\n\nThere's scrutiny of Harry Kane's fitness after the England captain went off with cramp in extra time against Switzerland. Ivan Toney came off the bench and scored one of England's five successful penalties in the shootout.\n\nNetherlands coach Ronald Koeman, on the other hand, could keep his line-up unchanged for the {"uri": "8217459801", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:21:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:21:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:21:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://thepeninsulaqatar.com/article/09/07/2024/england-plays-the-netherlands-aiming-for-back-to-back-european-finals", "title": "England plays the Netherlands aiming for back-to-back European finals", "body": "Dortmund, Germany: England can reach back-to-back European Championship finals when it meets the Netherlands in Dortmund in the second semifinal.\n\nThe winner plays Spain or France in Sunday's final. Kickoff is at 9 p.m. local time (1900 GMT). Here's what to know about the match.\n\nMatch facts\n\nBoth teams conceded the opening goal in their quarterfinals before coming back to win, with England beating Switzerland in a penalty shootout after a 1-1 draw and the Netherlands winning 2-1 against Turkey.\n\n- After a win on penalties in his 100th game in charge of England, coach Gareth Southgate defending his often-cautious tactics as the kind of \"streetwise\" style successful teams use. The backlash from England fans, including some who threw plastic cups at him after a group-stage game, is \"quite difficult\" to deal with, he added.\n\n- The Netherlands will be by far the highest-ranked team England has faced after group games with Serbia, Denmark and Slovenia, followed by knockout games with Slovakia and Switzerland.\n\n- The referee for the game is Felix Zwayer, who once had ties to a match-fixing scandal in Germany. England midfielder Jude Bellingham was fined 40,000 euros ($43,400) in 2021 while playing for Borussia Dortmund for criticizing Zwayer.\n\n- The Dutch endured some travel disruption on the way to Dortmund on Tuesday when their scheduled train journey from Wolfsburg was canceled because of what the team said was a \"blockage\" on the line. The squad had to fly instead, meaning the Netherlands' news conference with Ronald Koeman and defender Nathan Ak\u00e9 was called off.\n\nEngland has relied on the right-footed Kieran Trippier at left wing back, but his tendency to cut inside has meant England has made little use of the left wing all tournament. Left-footed Luke Shaw came off the bench against Switzerland for his first minutes since February after injury. Shaw says he's fit to start against the Netherlands if Southgate picks him, and the coach said Tuesday he had a tough decision to make.\n\n- Southgate has to choose whether to stick with Ezri Konsa in the center of defense after he replaced the then-suspended Marc Gu\u00e9hi against Switzerland. Gu\u00e9hi is eligible again.\n\n- There's scrutiny of Harry Kane's fitness after the England captain went off with cramp in extra time against Switzerland. Ivan Toney came off the bench and scored one of England's five successful penalties in the shootout.\n\n- Netherlands coach Ronald Koeman could keep his lineup unchanged for the third game in a row, with Memphis Depay starting alongside Cody Gakpo and Steven Bergwijn up front.\n\nBy the numbers\n\nEngland has played a full hour more than the Netherlands in the last 10 days, after beating Slovakia in extra time and then Switzerland on penalties. The Dutch wrapped up their wins over Romania and Turkey without needing extra time.\n\n- The Netherlands scored the opening goal in only one of its five games so far at Euro 2024, against Romania in the last 16. England last scored the opening goal against Denmark in the group stage.\n\n- The Netherlands hasn't reached a European Championship final since it won the tournament in 1988 and was last a semifinalist in 2004.\n\n- England's first shot on target against Switzerland was Bukayo Saka's goal to level the score in the 80th minute. One round earlier, Bellingham's spectacular overhead kick was England's first shot on target. That came in the fifth minute of second-half added time.\n\n- Gakpo is the top-scoring player left at Euro 2024 with three goals. What was initially thought to be a fourth against Turkey was instead ruled to be an own-goal. {"uri": "2024-07-417317500", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:00:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:00:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:00:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://jakartaglobe.id/news/england-eyes-consecutive-euro-finals-in-semifinal-clash-with-netherlands", "title": "England Eyes Consecutive Euro Finals in Semifinal Clash with Netherlands", "body": "Dortmund. England aims for back-to-back European Championship finals when it meets the Netherlands in Dortmund in the second semifinal of Euro 2024. The winner will play Spain in Sunday's final. Kickoff is at 9 p.m. local time or 2 a.m. on Friday Jakarta time.\n\nBoth teams conceded the opening goal in their quarterfinals before coming back to win. England defeated Switzerland in a penalty shootout after a 1-1 draw, while the Netherlands won 2-1 against Turkey.\n\nAfter a win on penalties in his 100th game in charge of England, coach Gareth Southgate defended his often-cautious tactics as the kind of \"streetwise\" style successful teams use. The backlash from England fans, including some who threw plastic cups at him after a group-stage game, is \"quite difficult\" to deal with, he added.\n\n\"I don't really understand the criticism. What he's done for the country, for us as players as well, he really took us to the next level ... I've got a lot to thank him for because he showed a lot of faith and trust in picking me when he didn't have to,\" England defender Luke Shaw said about manager Gareth Southgate\n\nThe Netherlands will be by far the highest-ranked team England has faced after group games with Serbia, Denmark, and Slovenia, followed by knockout games with Slovakia and Switzerland.\n\nThe referee for the game is Felix Zwayer, who once had ties to a match-fixing scandal in Germany. England midfielder Jude Bellingham was fined 40,000 euros ($43,400) in 2021 while playing for Borussia Dortmund for criticizing Zwayer.\n\nEngland has relied on the right-footed Kieran Trippier at left wing-back, but his tendency to cut inside has meant England has made little use of the left wing all tournament. Left-footed Luke Shaw came off the bench against Switzerland for his first minutes since February after injury. Shaw says he's fit to start against the Netherlands if Southgate picks him, and the coach said Tuesday he had a tough decision to make.\n\nSouthgate has to choose whether to stick with Ezri Konsa in the center of defense after he replaced the then-suspended Marc Gu\u00e9hi against Switzerland. Gu\u00e9hi is eligible again. There's scrutiny of Harry Kane's fitness after the England captain went off with a cramp in extra time against Switzerland. Ivan Toney came off the bench and scored one of England's five successful penalties in the shootout.\n\nNetherlands coach Ronald Koeman could keep his lineup unchanged for the third game in a row, with Memphis Depay starting alongside Cody Gakpo and Steven Bergwijn up front.\n\n\"Hopefully it's us that will have the ball more than England. So it's more England that's running. I expect a high-intensity game,\" Netherlands defender Micky van de Ven said.\n\nThe Netherlands hasn't reached a European Championship final since it won the tournament in 1988 and was last a semifinalist in 2004.\n\nGakpo and Spain's Dani Olmo are the top-scoring players left at Euro 2024 with three goals. What was initially thought to be a fourth for Gakpo against Turkey was instead ruled to be an own-goal. Kane and Bellingham are England's top scorers with two. The winner plays Spain or France in Sunday's final. Kickoff is at 9 p.m. local time (1900 GMT).\n\nTeam news\n\nEngland has relied on the right-footed Kieran Trippier at left wing back, but his tendency to cut inside has meant England has made little use of the left wing all tournament. Left-footed Luke Shaw came off the bench against Switzerland for his first minutes since February after injury. Shaw says he's fit to start against the Netherlands if Southgate picks him.\n\nSouthgate has to choose whether to stick with Ezri Konsa in the center of defense after he replaced the then-suspended Marc Guehi against Switzerland. Guehi is eligible again.\n\nThere's scrutiny of Harry Kane's fitness after the England captain went off with cramp in extra time against Switzerland. Ivan Toney came off the bench and scored one of England's five successful penalties in the shootout.\n\nNetherlands coach Ronald Koeman could keep his lineup unchanged for the third game in a row, with Memphis Depay starting alongside Cody Gakpo and Steven Bergwijn up front.\n\nBy the numbers\n\nEngland has played a full hour more than the Netherlands in the last 10 days, after beating Slovakia in extra time and then Switzerland on penalties. The Dutch wrapped up their wins over Romania and Turkey without needing extra time.\n\nThe Netherlands scored the opening goal in only one of its five games so far at Euro 2024, against Romania in the last 16. England last scored the opening goal against Denmark in the group stage.\n\nThe Netherlands hasn't reached a European Championship final since it won the tournament in 1988 and was last a semifinalist in 2004.\n\nEngland's first shot on target against Switzerland was Bukayo Saka's goal to level the score in the 80th minute. One round earlier, Bellingham's spectacular overhead kick was England's first shot on target. That came in the fifth minute of second-half added time.\n\nDutch forward Gakpo is the top-scoring player left at Euro 2024 with three goals. What was initially thought to be a fourth against Turkey was instead ruled to be an own-goal. Kane and Bellingham are England's top scorers with two.\n\nWhat they're saying\n\n\"I don't really understand the criticism. {"uri": "8216640917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "09:28:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T09:28:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T09:27:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/euro-2024-england-plays-netherlands-092133299.html", "title": "Euro 2024: England plays the Netherlands aiming for back-to-back European finals", "body": "-- After a win on penalties in his 100th game in charge of England, manager Gareth Southgate defending his often-cautious tactics as the kind of \"streetwise\" style successful teams use. The backlash from England fans, including some who threw plastic cups at him after a group-stage game, is \"quite difficult\" to deal with, he added.\n\n-- The Netherlands will be by far the highest-ranked team England has faced after group games with Serbia, Denmark and Slovenia, followed by knockout games with Slovakia and Switzerland.\n\n-- England has relied on the right-footed Kieran Trippier at left wing back, but his tendency to cut inside has meant England has made little use of the left wing all tournament. Left-footed Luke Shaw came off the bench against Switzerland for his first minutes since February after injury. Shaw says he's fit to start against the Netherlands if Southgate picks him.\n\n-- Southgate has to choose whether to stick with Ezri Konsa in the center of defense after he replaced the then-suspended Marc Gu\u00e9hi against Switzerland. Gu\u00e9hi is eligible again.\n\n-- There's scrutiny of Harry Kane's fitness after the England captain went off with cramp in extra time against Switzerland. Ivan Toney came off the bench and scored one of England's five successful penalties in the shootout.\n\n-- Netherlands coach Ronald Koeman could keep his lineup unchanged for the third game in a row, with Memphis Depay starting alongside Cody Gakpo and Steven Bergwijn up front.\n\nBy the numbers\n\n-- England has played a full hour more than the Netherlands in the last 10 days, after beating Slovakia in extra time and then Switzerland on penalties. The Dutch wrapped up their wins over Romania and Turkey without needing extra time.\n\n-- The Netherlands scored the opening goal in only one of its five games so far at Euro 2024, against Romania in the last 16. England last scored the opening goal against Denmark in the group stage.\n\n-- The Netherlands hasn't reached a European Championship final since it won the tournament in 1988 and was last a semifinalist in 2004.\n\n-- England's first shot on target against Switzerland was Bukayo Saka's goal to level the score in the 80th minute. One round earlier, Bellingham's spectacular overhead kick was England's first shot on target. That came in the fifth minute of second-half added time.\n\n-- Dutch forward Gakpo is the top-scoring player left at Euro 2024 with three goals. What was initially thought to be a fourth against Turkey was instead ruled to be an own-goal. Kane and Bellingham are England's top scorers with two.\n\nWhat they're saying\n\n\"I don't really understand the criticism. What he's done for the country, for us as players as well, he really took us to the next level ... I've got a lot to thank him for because he showed a lot of faith and trust in picking me when he didn't have to.\" -- England defender Luke Shaw on manager Gareth Southgate.\n\n\"Hopefully it's us that will have the ball more than England. So it's more England that's running. I expect a high intensity game.\" -- Netherlands defender Micky van de Ven.\n\n___\n\nEllingworth reported from Duesseldorf, Germany.\n\nSteve Douglas And James Ellingworth, The Associated Press",
