{"uri": "8217670876", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "21:52:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T21:52:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T21:51:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2024/07/09/gareth-southgate-euro-2024-semi-final-england-v-netherlands/", "title": "Gareth Southgate: We want to give the nation a night to remember", "body": "Southgate's side have the chance to become the first England team to reach the final of a major tournament on foreign soil\n\nGareth Southgate has urged his England players to give the country a footballing evening to remember by seizing their moment at the European Championship and making history.\n\nSouthgate's side will become the first England team to reach the final of a major tournament abroad with victory against the Netherlands at Westfalenstadion in Dortmund.\n\nPlayers have seen footage of fans celebrating by throwing drinks at screenings of their knockout wins in Germany, and while Southgate had plastic beer cups thrown at him by supporters in the group stages, he now has the chance to lead England to their most glorious summer since 1966.\n\n\"I can remember what that is like from previous tournaments, so it's one of the privileges of representing England that you have the chance to give people memories that stay with them for a long time,\" said Southgate, who is expected to make a change to his starting line-up, with Marc Guehi returning from suspension for Ezri Konsa.\n\n\"Those enjoyable nights when everyone comes together and enjoys themselves. So, without a doubt, we want this game to be another one of those.\"\n\nSouthgate has led his team to the semi-final stage of three of his four major tournaments and says he has drawn on his experiences in last-four clashes in his preparations to face Ronald Koeman's side.\n\nThe clash at Borussia Dortmund's stadium is a rematch of the Euro '96 fixture at Wembley in which Southgate played and England captured the imagination of the country with a 4-1 win that gave them momentum in the tournament.\n\nAs a manager, Southgate has led his team to the final of the last Euros but England's only other final was at the 1966 World Cup, which was also on home soil. Reaching a final abroad is the next step for Southgate's squad after setting records and changing the mindset of players during his eight years in charge.\n\nHe insists his young squad have none of the scars from previous tournament failure and has seen a change during the tournament after playing with 'fear' in the first two matches of the group stage.\n\n\"We've risen well to those challenges over the years and used them as motivation to break new ground,\" Southgate said. \"We've never been to a final outside of our own shores, so these are opportunities to make a difference.\n\n\"That's how we have to look at it. It's about their moment now, nothing that's gone on in the past, none of that is their fault or concern. It really is this group of players who really have come together well over the last three or four weeks.\"\n\nEngland had not reached a semi-final of a major tournament since 1996 before Southgate's arrival but after reaching the last-four stage at the 2018 World Cup, Southgate has been mindful not to \"overprepare\" his team ahead of potentially two era-defining matches in four days.\n\n\"We have a better understanding of that than when we were in Russia,\" he said. \"We didn't fully appreciate how much of a demand that was.\n\n\"It's been factored into all our operations for the last few years. For not just managing the day-to-day but the weeks we've been away. Managing staff energy, managing players' energy.\n\n\"I suppose in Russia winning a knockout game was the first target and it felt that from that moment on was the change of mindset,\" said Southgate. \"We've gone further in more recent tournaments and nobody is thinking a quarter-final is anywhere near enough.\n\n\"Now we're in the real business end of the tournament which of course given that's only the third time in however many years, that's not to be underestimated but for us as a group, the great thing is we're not sitting here happy with a semi-final, we want to go further and our aim is to come here and win it and we are now two games away from doing that.\"", "source": {"uri": "telegraph.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Telegraph"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8217243254", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "15:37:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T15:37:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T15:37:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/netherlands-vs-england-familiar-foes-152900487.html", "title": "Netherlands vs England: Familiar foes trade tackles in blockbuster Euro 2024 semi-final", "body": "Signal Iduna Park forms the backdrop for a heavyweight 2024 UEFA European Championship semi-final clash between the Netherlands and England.\n\nBorussia Dortmund's iconic stadium serves as a springboard for the final, where the winner of this tie will meet the better of the other semi-final duel between Spain and France.\n\nIt's been a while since the Netherlands ran this deep into the tournament, with their last Euros semi-final foray dating back to 2004, when Portugal sealed their fate.\n\nOn the other hand, England are far more familiar with the territory, with this being their third last-four tie in four major tournaments under Gareth Southgate.\n\nRonald Koeman's charges blew hot and cold in the group stages (W1, D1, L1), landing a last-16 berth as one of the best third-place teams, but they've found their feet in the knockouts.\n\nFollowing a comprehensive 3-0 thumping of Romania in the Round of 16, the Oranje overturned a 1-0 half-time deficit against Turkey in the quarter-finals to set up this tie.\n\nVirgil van Dijk's header and Mert Muldur's own goal beyond the hour mark inspired the Netherlands to a 2-1 victory, giving them a chance to settle the account with England.\n\nThe last time the two teams faced each other at the Euro finals, the Three Lions thrashed the Dutch 4-1 in 1996, with Alan Shearer and Teddy Sheringham bagging braces.\n\nHowever, England's misfiring tournament effectively rules out the potential for another emphatic scoreline.\n\nSouthgate's men haven't scored more than once in regulation in any of their five games at Euro 2024, intensifying the pressure on the ex-Middlesbrough manager.\n\nThe 53-year-old avoided sacking by the skin of his teeth in both previous knockout fixtures.\n\nAfter Jude Bellingham's stunning injury-time overhead kick set the tone for England's 2-1 extra-time against Slovakia, the Three Lions gaffer had Bukayo Saka's brilliance to thank for staying in the tournament.\n\nThe Arsenal ace struck home a speculative shot from an awkward angle to help the pre-tournament favourites take their dramatic quarter-final clash against Switzerland to penalties.\n\nDespite the abovementioned embarrassment in the 1996 edition, the Netherlands' track record against England looks promising.\n\nThe Dutch hammered England 3-1 in the group phase the only previous time they conquered the most prestigious continental tournament in 1988.\n\nEven after that loss nearly three decades ago, the three-time World Cup runners-up have gone from strength to strength against their esteemed rivals.\n\nBarring a 1-0 friendly defeat in 2018, they've gone unbeaten in eight of their nine matches against England in the 21st century (W4, D4), most recently beating them 3-1 in extra time of their UEFA Nations League semi-final showdown in June 2019.\n\nOn the downside, the European Championship semi-finals have frequently been the Netherlands' scourge, as they've failed to go past this hurdle three times on the trot since lifting the title.\n\nDespite their long-standing struggles at this stage, Koeman will hope history could repeat itself, with the Netherlands' only previous Euros success arriving on German soil.\n\nSince dispatching Serbia 1-0 in their curtain-raising Group C outing, England haven't won a Euro 2024 game in regulation, casting further doubt on Southgate's managerial credentials.\n\nHowever, all his tactical flaws and faint-hearted approach would probably fall to oblivion if he becomes the first Three Lions boss to bring the famous phrase 'it's coming home' to life.\n\nThere's no doubt Southgate would appreciate another 'ugly' win. And his men seem well-positioned to answer the call, having gone into overdrive since a 2-1 loss to France in the 2022 World Cup quarter-finals.\n\nIt remains England's last upset in competitive action, with the beaten Euro 2020 finalists avoiding defeat in 13 consecutive contests (W9, D4), conceding one goal or fewer on each occasion.\n\nWhile Southgate can't complain about his team's defensive effort, there's ample room for improvement in the build-up play and, particularly, in front of goal.\n\nAll eyes turn to Ballon d'Or hopeful Bellingham. He scored the winning header against Serbia and extended England's title hopes with the 'goal of the tournament' contender against Slovakia.\n\nEngland's abysmal win rate of only 27% against the Netherlands paints a bleak picture for the Three Lions faithful amidst the team's dire form in Germany.\n\nLuck smiled on Southgate several times at Euro 2024, but another tame performance against the Dutch would probably result in England's exit from the tournament.\n\nKoeman's troops are in better shape, but if Southgate's star-studded line-up can find the chemistry in these crucial moments, there would be no hope for the Oranje.\n\nEngland's sheer attacking potential leads us to believe they'd snatch away a place in the final.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-07-415661123", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "02:30:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T02:30:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T01:39:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240709-from-koeman-s-free-kick-to-euro-96-five-netherlands-v-england-clashes", "title": "From Koeman's free-kick to Euro 96: Five Netherlands v England clashes", "body": "Dortmund (Germany) (AFP) - The Netherlands and England meet in the last four of Euro 2024 on Wednesday with both teams eyeing a place in this weekend's final in Berlin.\n\nThere was a time when the two nations met regularly on the international stage, but the match in Dortmund will be just the second competitive game between the sides this century.\n\nAFP Sport looks back at their most notable past encounters:\n\n- Van Basten hat-trick -\n\nThe 1988 European Championship remains the only major international tournament that the Netherlands have won, and will always be remembered for Marco van Basten's stunning goal in the final against the Soviet Union.\n\nIt also remains a low point for England, the only time in which they have gone to a major tournament and lost every game.\n\nBoth sides lost their opening match before they clashed in Duesseldorf in the group phase, and the Dutch came out on top thanks to a Van Basten hat-trick.\n\nEngland had chances, with Gary Lineker and Glenn Hoddle both hitting the post. Van Basten's opener for the Netherlands was cancelled out by a Bryan Robson equaliser just after half-time, but two goals in five second-half minutes allowed Van Basten to complete his hat-trick and sealed a 3-1 Dutch win.\n\nDraw at Italia 90\n\nThe nations were again drawn in the same group at the 1990 World Cup in Italy, and many of the players involved in 1988 again featured in this meeting in Cagliari, among them current Dutch boss Ronald Koeman.\n\nThe sides had each drawn their opening match, with England being held by Ireland and the Netherlands by Egypt. This time England kept Van Basten quiet in a 0-0 draw, and it was England who would top the group on the way to reaching the semi-finals. The Dutch, meanwhile, were beaten by West Germany in the last 16.\n\nEngland miss out on USA 94\n\nEngland have failed to qualify for just one World Cup since the 1970s, and it was the Netherlands who denied them a place at USA 94.\n\nGraham Taylor's England had a poor campaign, taking just one point from two games against Norway, who topped the group. They squandered a two-goal lead at home to the Dutch at Wembley, but when they went to Rotterdam for the return fixture -- their penultimate game in the group -- England still had qualification in their own hands as they were above the Dutch.\n\nWith Paul Gascoigne suspended, England fell behind to a free-kick just after the hour mark by Koeman -- who the visitors felt should have been sent off earlier on -- before Dennis Bergkamp sealed a 2-0 Dutch win.\n\nEngland beat San Marino in their final game but a Dutch win in Poland ensured they qualified instead. It was a disastrous campaign for Taylor, captured in a warts-and-all TV documentary. Taylor later resigned, while the Dutch reached the World Cup quarter-finals.\n\nShearer, Sheringham double act\n\nThe nations met again in the group stage at Euro 96. Both teams had taken four points from their first two matches before clashing at Wembley, where Alan Shearer opened the scoring with a penalty and added another goal early in the second half, in between a brace by Teddy Sheringham.\n\nPatrick Kluivert's late goal for the Dutch made the final score 4-1 as England -- who had current boss Gareth Southgate in defence -- won the group and the Netherlands squeezed through in second place ahead of Scotland.\n\nThe Dutch lost on penalties to France in the last eight, while England were beaten in a shoot-out in the semi-finals by Germany, with Southgate missing the crucial kick.\n\nDutch win Nations League semi\n\nThe only competitive meeting of the teams since Euro 96 came in the semi-finals of the inaugural UEFA Nations League in 2019.\n\nSouthgate was already England's manager and Koeman was in his first spell as Dutch coach as the teams clashed in Guimaraes, Portugal.\n\nMarcus Rashford put England ahead from a penalty but Matthijs de Ligt levelled, taking the game to extra time.\n\nKyle Walker's own goal gave the Dutch the lead and Quincy Promes sealed a 3-1 victory for the Netherlands, who would lose the final to hosts Portugal.", "source": {"uri": "france24.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "France 24"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marco_van_Basten", "type": "person", {"uri": "8215745083", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "18:30:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T18:30:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T18:29:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/england-suttons-semi-final-predictions-174639397.html", "title": "Will England make it? Sutton's semi-final predictions", "body": "The finishing line is in sight, but which of the four teams left in Euro 2024 will make it to the final in Berlin on 14 July?\n\nLike England's penalty takers against Switzerland, BBC Sport football expert Chris Sutton did not put a foot wrong with his predictions for the quarter-finals, getting all four results correct.\n\nThe majority of you were spot on each time too - although, out of more than 160,000 votes, only 57% of you thought England would beat the Swiss, the lowest proportion of the teams you correctly backed.\n\nStill, that means like Sutton you have a success rate of 54% overall, after getting a total of 26 predictions right from the 48 games played in Germany so far.\n\nCan you get the better of him in the semi-finals? You can make your predictions below for France - Sutton's pre-tournament pick to win the European Championship - versus Spain and England against the Netherlands.\n\nMunich, 20:00 BST\n\nI'm in a bit of a pickle here, because before a ball was kicked I went for France to win Euro 2024.\n\nPlus, I am at Allianz Arena for Radio 5 Live, so I cannot close my curtains and pretend Didier Deschamps' side are not playing.\n\nDidier is an old friend of mine because we joined Chelsea at the same time in 1999 and stayed in the same hotel. We used to play cards together, as a pair, and he was always quite cautious then... but nothing compared to how he has got his team playing now.\n\nWhen I think of the France football team, I think of flair and flamboyance, starting with Michel Platini's side that won the 1984 European Championship. Their sides that have won major honours in the years since then have been the same.\n\nThis version of Les Bleus, though, has been utter dross to watch.\n\nDefensively, they have been excellent. As a centre-half pairing, William Saliba and Dayot Upamecano have been absolutely outstanding and Mike Maignan has been superb in goal too.\n\nAttack-wise though, I was just shocked by their level of performance against Portugal. Ousmane Dembele came on and made a difference, but Kylian Mbappe has not got going at all.\n\nIn contrast, Spain have been the team of the tournament. Their quarter-final win over Germany took a little while to get going, but it was brilliant once it did.\n\nSpain are doing it a very different way to France, and England too, and they have been very impressive in everything they have done - other than maybe not being ruthless enough at times.\n\nTheir manager Luis de la Fuente will have to make changes for this game, because Robin le Normand and Dani Carvajal are both suspended, while Pedri will miss the rest of the tournament with a knee injury.\n\nIf I was being logical about this, I would still say Spain will win - Lamine Yamal is so exciting, Nico Williams has arguably been the player of the tournament, and Rodri and Fabian Ruiz run things in the middle of the pitch - but I just have a feeling that France will get through.\n\nOf course Mbappe could play like the superstar he is, or Dembele could cause Marc Cucurella problems if he starts... but it is more likely that France will just smother Spain and, even if they do not play well, get the job done.\n\nWout Weghorst's physicality made the difference for the Dutch against Turkey after he came on at half-time when they were 1-0 down.\n\nEngland manager Gareth Southgate has been accused of not being decisive enough with his substitutions, but Ronald Koeman got it right for the Netherlands there.\n\nRather than trying to be intricate and playing through Turkey, they got the ball wide, crossed it in and Weghorst was a massive threat.\n\nI do not necessarily think he will start against England, but they will have him as an option on the bench if they need him.\n\nIt is not just Weghorst that England have to watch out for though, because Cody Gakpo will be dangerous too.\n\nGakpo probably has not delivered the form we expected from him for Liverpool, but he has had his moments. For the Netherlands, though, he has been their best player at this tournament.\n\nThere is the possibility that, like England against Switzerland, the Netherlands will move to playing with three at the back for this game. Koeman often does that when he faces stronger teams.\n\nIf the teams do match up with the same formation, I think England have a better midfield than the Dutch duo of Jerdy Schouten and Tijjani Reijnders.\n\nThe problem is that, in an attacking capacity, England just have not turned up yet.\n\nThey have relied on some big moments so far, but the equalisers Jude Bellingham and Bukayo Saka scored against Slovakia and Switzerland were both with their team's first shot on target of the game.\n\nSo, how do you call this? I don't think anything is going to drastically change in the way England play - they are not going to suddenly find some amazing patterns of play that break the Netherlands down.\n\nInstead, if England are going to reach their second successive Euros final, they are going to have to rely on individual brilliance again.\n\nI have not just been blindly backing them to get through each knockout round in Germany but they are definitely on the more gentle side of the draw.\n\nThis is their toughest game yet, and it is going to be very close, but I do think England will edge it... somehow.", {"uri": "8216690818", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "09:58:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T09:58:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T09:58:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.dailysabah.com/sports/football/england-eye-back-to-back-euro-finals-with-netherlands-semis-clash", "title": "England eye back-to-back Euro finals with Netherlands semis clash", "body": "Following a tense first two knockout rounds, England's Three Lions now aim to reach their second consecutive final as they face the Netherlands in Wednesday's second Euro 2024 semifinal.\n\nIt all comes down to the wire in Dortmund; the winners will face either France or Spain in Sunday's final.\n\nEngland has reached its third major tournament semifinal in four attempts, albeit narrowly.\n\nHowever, Gareth Southgate's squad, now regulars in the latter stages of Euros and World Cups, is hungry for silverware this summer.\n\nTheir journey to a fourth Euros semifinal was sealed with a dramatic win over Switzerland in the quarterfinals.\n\nDespite trailing to a late goal by Breel Embolo in Dusseldorf, Bukayo Saka's equalizer forced extra time.\n\nEngland eventually triumphed in a nerve-wracking penalty shootout, converting all five kicks, while Jordan Pickford's save from Manuel Akanji proved crucial.\n\nDespite barely scraping through the group stage and needing Jude Bellingham's stunning strike to spark a comeback against Slovakia, England's path has been far from smooth.\n\nYet, in knockout football, results speak loudest.\n\nSouthgate's 101st game in charge sees England aiming to join an elite group by reaching consecutive Euro finals.\n\nStanding in their way are familiar foes, the Netherlands, in a showdown that promises high drama in Berlin this Sunday.\n\nThis encounter marks the fourth major tournament meeting between England and the Netherlands. The Dutch famously won 3-1 en route to Euro '88 glory thanks to Marco van Basten's hat trick.\n\nA forgettable goalless draw followed at the 1990 World Cup before England's memorable 4-1 victory in 1996.\n\nDespite their attacking prowess, England faces a challenge against the Netherlands, having won just one of their last nine encounters across all competitions.\n\nIn their most recent encounter, a semifinal, the Netherlands beat England 3-1 after extra time in the UEFA Nations League.\n\nBoth Gareth Southgate and Ronald Koeman were at the helm during that memorable clash.\n\nLast weekend, Koeman guided his team to their first Euro semifinal since 2004 by overcoming a resilient T\u00fcrkiye at Berlin's Olympiastadion.\n\nSimilar to England, the Dutch had to mount a comeback to secure their spot in the final four.\n\nTrailing by a goal and seemingly on the brink of elimination, Stefan de Vrij equalized for the Dutch in the 70th minute before Cody Gakpo's pressure led to an own goal from Mert M\u00fcld\u00fcr shortly after.\n\nThe Netherlands, seeking their second European title since their triumph 36 summers ago in Germany, have navigated through what's considered the \"weaker\" half of the draw, having finished third in Group D.\n\nAfter defeating Poland, drawing with France, and experiencing a dramatic loss to Austria, the Oranje faced a relatively favorable last-16 match against Romania, which they comfortably won 3-0.\n\nLed by captain Virgil van Dijk, the Dutch squad aims to secure just their second European Championship semifinal victory.\n\nHowever, their recent record of four losses in the last five semifinals adds weight to the historical challenge they face.\n\nLuke Shaw's return to Gareth Southgate's squad as the sole specialist left-back has been eagerly anticipated. The Manchester United defender, who missed England's first four matches due to a hamstring injury, made a brief appearance against Switzerland and has now declared himself fit to start.\n\nMarc Guehi, who impressed earlier in the tournament, faces competition from Ezri Konsa for a defensive spot upon his return from suspension. The tactical setup for the match in Dortmund remains uncertain, whether it will be a three-man or four-man defense or a combination of both.\n\nDespite being substituted during extra time last weekend due to a cramp, Harry Kane, England's leading goal scorer, is ready to enhance his impressive record in the European Championship knockout stages. Kane has scored five times in the elimination rounds, matching Antoine Griezmann's record.\n\nMeanwhile, the Netherlands face a crucial decision in their attacking lineup after Wout Weghorst's impactful half-time introduction changed the course of their quarterfinal against T\u00fcrkiye.\n\nKoeman, who recently extended his tenure until 2026, is considering whether to start Weghorst alongside Memphis Depay.\n\nHowever, a decisive role off the bench seems more likely.\n\nDepay and Cody Gakpo have been directly involved in 63.5% of the Netherlands' goal attempts this summer, contributing to six of their nine goals.\n\nKoeman is expected to maintain continuity with his starting eleven on Wednesday, with Bart Verbruggen in goal, Virgil van Dijk leading from central defense, and Xavi Simons linking midfield to attack.", "source": {"uri": "dailysabah.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Sabah"}, "authors": [{"uri": "daily_sabah@dailysabah.com", "name": "Daily Sabah", France and a loss to Austria.\n\nMeanwhile, England had some well-documented struggles of their own in Group C, beating Serbia and drawing both Denmark and Slovenia.\n\nThe Three Lions have continued to survive despite struggling offensively in knockout play, as they needed a last-second equalizer -- and extra time -- against Slovakia in the round of 16 and a perfect showing in PKs against least two in all but one of their games to date.\n\nBut England will be much tougher to score on than the likes of Poland, Austria, Romania and Turkey (the Netherlands faced one tough defensive side, France, in group play, and drew that match 0-0).\n\nThe Dutch have controlled possession for the most part in this tournament, but were outpossessed 62-38 by the French. Despite conceding possession, the Netherlands finished that match with eight shots (four on target).\n\nHow Netherlands-France went could be instructive given that France are much more similar to England than any of the other Dutch opponents to date.\n\nEngland Proving Value of Substance Over Style\n\nDating back to the 2018 World Cup, England have made winning ugly (or you could call it low-scoring) a habit. Manager Gareth Southgate's team reached the semifinal of the 2018 WC and the final of Euro 2020 (played in 2021), with a quarterfinal loss to runner-up France in the 2022 World Cup.\n\nAnd, it should be noted, France have been successful with a similar formula at the last two World Cups, winning in 2018 and reaching the final in 2022.\n\nWhether you find it aesthetically pleasing or not, England's ability to limit chances for their opponents keeps their matches close, and this team is getting better and better at finding a way in extra time or PKs when it has to.\n\nIt also helps that when they've fallen behind, young stars Jude Bellingham (against Slovakia) and Bukayo Saka (against Switzerland) have proven that they can produce something spectacular out of nothing to keep their team alive.\n\nNetherlands vs. England Prediction, Best Bets\n\nIt's tough to see this match getting resolved in 90 minutes. The Dutch have gone to extra time in just one of their five matches in this competition, but England have been level with their opponent after 90 minutes in each of their last four.\n\nThis game has the same feel as Portugal-France in the quarterfinals, which had low-scoring draw written all over it. side that has thrived under pressure to win another nail-biter.\n\nPrediction: England 1, Netherlands 1 (England advance on penalty kicks)\n\nBest bets: Draw (+180 at BetMGM, FanDuel, DraftKings and What is achievable? Rather than, what could go wrong?\n\n\"That is different for a player. {"uri": "8217557077", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "19:55:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T19:55:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T19:54:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/southgate-demands-england-step-netherlands-194604092.html", "title": "Southgate demands England 'step up' in Netherlands semi-final at Euro 2024", "body": "Gareth Southgate has conceded that England will need a \"step up\" in performance against the Netherlands if his team is to secure its place in a first major tournament final away from Wembley.\n\nSpeaking ahead of the European championship semi-final tie with the Dutch in Dortmund in west Germany, the England manager said that his team could not expect to win on Wednesday night on current form.\n\nA series of poor performances in the group stage, and a near-death experience against Slovakia in the round of 16 followed by a win on penalties against Switzerland, has provoked heavy criticism of Southgate's tactics, with even Dutch players describing England's approach as \"defensive\".\n\nRelated: Netherlands v England: tactical conundrums that will settle semi-final\n\nSouthgate, who was joined by England captain Harry Kane at a pre-match press conference, said he recognised the frustrations of the fans and pundits but insisted his team was \"prepared for anything\".\n\nHe said: \"We need another step from what we showed in the last game, it's a step up in quality of opponents and we are ready for that.\"\n\nEngland are looking to achieve back-to-back European finals after losing to Italy at Wembley at Euro 2020. The men's national team, which won the World Cup at home in 1966, have never appeared in a major tournament final outside England.\n\nAsked how the players were coping with the pressure of the moment, Kane, who has scored only once in open play at the tournament, said each player was dealing with the situation in his own way. The Bayern Munich striker said: \"I don't think we speak about it in the dressing room. The ones who have had more experience know what it's like to play for England in major tournaments. As we've been getting better the expectation gets higher and that's been no different.\n\n\"Some will use it in different ways, some will use it as motivation, some will just block it out and focus on what they need to do. Everyone's different. From a team point of view we know what we need to achieve. We have a really important game, a really tough game we need to be ready for. We've prepared for that.\"\n\nWith up to 75,000 Dutch supporters expected in Dortmund on Wednesday night, England fans are likely to be outnumbered by four to one although the number of fans in the stadium are expected to be similar. In the stands of the Westfalenstadion, the Dutch presence will be most obvious in the famous south terrace which is known as the \"Yellow Wall\" during Borussia Dortmund games but will become orange on Wednesday night.\n\nSouthgate said: \"I think our players are used to it. The atmosphere in the stadiums has been great this tournament and it's added a different feel and intensity to the games. I'm sure our fans will make themselves heard and it will be a colourful occasion. These occasions is why we're involved in football and we're looking forward to stepping up.\"\n\nThe Netherlands will be by far the highest-ranked team - seventh in the world - England have faced after group games with Serbia, Denmark and Slovenia, followed by knockout matches against Slovakia and Switzerland.\n\nThe referee for the game, Felix Zwayer, served a six-month ban for his role in a match-fixing scandal in 2006. He has always denied wrongdoing. The England midfielder Jude Bellingham hit out at Zwayer while playing for Borussia Dortmund in 2021 after a defeat against Bayern Munich describing him as \"a referee that has match-fixed before\". Bellingham was fined \u20ac40,000 (\u00a333,800) for his unproven allegation.\n\nAsked about the choice of referee, Southgate would not be drawn into criticising Uefa. He said: \"I think everybody knows how I deal with refs, with complete respect for every referee. I know the two guys at Uefa who have been running the refs programme and I think they appreciate the respect we have shown as a team to officials over eight years.\n\n\"I think there's a right way to conduct yourself towards officials and I think that's very important for the game. So no, I'm not concerned about who the ref is. He will be at a very high standard because that's the way Uefa make those decisions and the way they monitor games during the tournament. So, for me, it's not even a consideration.\"\n\nAfter weeks of dismal weather in the west of Germany, the sun was out in Dortmund as fans of England and the Netherlands filled the bars around in the centre of Dortmund. Martin Sauer, head of the organising team for the Euro games in the city, said he was concerned that the sheer number of Dutch fans could overcrowd the fan zones but not by the threat of violence between supporters.\n\nHe said: \"We are expecting 75,000 Dutch fans. We think there are 16,000 English fans with tickets for the stadium and a small number of English fans without tickets, but not as big as the Dutch number. I think the ticket holder numbers are really equal between those two but non-ticket holders will be the majority from the Netherlands.\n\n\"We know that everything is really [tight]. That's good for a really special atmosphere but it's also complicated for public transport and for the public viewing and for everybody to find a space where you can where they can watch the game.\"\n\nSauer said there would be a heavy police presence but there were no major security concerns. He said: \"Always in every fan group there will be somebody who makes trouble but we are not concerned especially for English fans. We have English fans from club level here regularly in the championship games, and usually it's no problem.\n\n\"They're very welcome. And we think that the English fans will like the city and will like our bars. The public transport isn't as big as maybe Berlin or Hamburg or bigger cities in Germany. If you like to use your own feet, it's really easy to go through the city. If you need to public transport, you maybe have to wait some minutes.\"\n\nHarvey Brown, 19, a student at Cardiff Metropolitan university, said: \"I think it will be well organised here. They are used to Borussia Dortmund Champions League games. They are talking about 75,000 Dutch fans but we hear they will be walking to the stadium from 3.30pm so there hopefully won't be any problems, especially given how well England fans have behaved so far.\"\n\nThe new culture secretary, Lisa Nandy, will be at the game as part of a \"fact-finding mission\" ahead of the staging of Euro 2028 in UK and Ireland.", "source": {"uri": grasp shot at 'history' in Euros semi-final against the Dutch", "body": "The Netherlands have a first Euros final since 1988 in their sights in Dortmund\n\nEngland manager Gareth Southgate said the Three Lions are sensing their shot at history in Wednesday's Euro 2024 semi-final against a Netherlands side hitting their stride in Dortmund.\n\nSouthgate's men are aiming to reach the final of a major tournament on foreign soil for the first time and take a step closer to ending a 58-year wait to win a major tournament.\n\nThe winners will face Spain in Berlin on Sunday after they came from behind to beat France 2-1 on Tuesday.\n\nEngland missed out in heartbreaking fashion in the final of Euro 2020, losing on penalties at Wembley to Italy.\n\nCaptain Harry Kane said reaching back-to-back finals would be an \"amazing achievement\" as he aims to win a first major trophy of his career.\n\nBut Kane has been singled out for criticism back home for his sluggish displays in Germany, where he now plays his club football for Bayern Munich.\n\nThe 30-year-old has scored two of England's five goals at the tournament but has looked physically restricted after missing the end of the club season with a back injury.\n\nKane's lacklustre performances have been symptomatic of England's struggles as a team.\n\nTwice they have stared down a humiliating early exit only to fight back against Slovakia and Switzerland thanks to individual moments of magic from Jude Bellingham and Bukayo Saka.\n\nEngland arrived in Germany as one of the favourites thanks to a richly-talented squad and an upturn in their fortunes under Southgate.\n\nAnd he believes his players struggled to cope with that expectation early in the tournament.\n\n\"One of our strengths over the last eight years has been less fear, less inhibition but at the beginning the expectation weighed heavily,\" said Southgate at his pre-match press conference on Tuesday.\n\n\"Now we are into that moment in the tournament where it is what is possible? What is achievable? Rather than, what could go wrong?\n\n\"That is different for a player. This is now the chance to make history, first time to make a final not held in England.\"\n\nMore from this section Scarsdale, Rye top list of wealthiest suburbs in U.S. Report finds deficiencies with Westchester's Bee-Line Bus service Watch Sacramento Kings welcome six-time All-Star DeMar DeRozan\n\nThe selection of referee Felix Zwayer has raised eyebrows after Bellingham was fined during his time at Borussia Dortmund for bringing up a historic charge of match fixing against the German.\n\nZwayer was handed a six-month ban in 2006 after he was investigated for taking a bribe from another official.\n\nBellingham was fined 40,000 euros ($43,000) for his outburst after Bayern Munich beat Dortmund in December 2021.\n\n- Dutch face travel chaos -\n\nThe Netherlands also had their troubles in the group stages as a 3-2 defeat to Austria saw them sneak through as one of the best third-placed sides.\n\nRonald Koeman's men have since found their groove in a 3-0 win over Romania in the last 16 before battling back to beat Turkey 2-1 in the last eight.\n\nThe Dutch boast one of the form attacking players in the tournament in Cody Gakpo, who is looking to move out in front in the race for the Golden Boot by adding to his three goals so far.\n\nThey have had to wait 36 years since their own sole major tournament triumph -- which came the last time the Euros were held in Germany.\n\nBut their preparations for the game were disrupted by issues with the German train system, which has caused chaos for fans throughout the tournament.\n\nThe Netherlands had planned to go from their base in Wolfsburg by rail to Dortmund.\n\nHowever, a blockage on the line meant a last-minute change of plans as they instead had to fly and missed their pre-match media duties as a result.\n\n\"We don't play until 9 pm (1900GMT) tomorrow. I'm sure they will still get dinner when they arrive,\" added Southgate.\n\n\"They've got plenty of time. Van Basten's opener for the Netherlands was cancelled out by a Bryan Robson equaliser just after half-time, but two goals in five second-half minutes allowed van Basten to complete his hat-trick and sealed a 3-1 Dutch win.\n\nThe nations were again drawn in the same group at the 1990 World Cup in Italy, and many of the players involved in 1988 again featured in this meeting in Cagliari, among them current Dutch boss Ronald Koeman.\n\nThe sides had each drawn their opening match, with England being held by Ireland and the Netherlands by Egypt. This time England kept van Basten quiet in a 0-0 draw, and it was England who would top the group on the way to reaching the semi-finals. The Dutch, meanwhile, were beaten by West Germany in the last 16.\n\nEngland have failed to qualify for just one World Cup since the 1970s, and it was the Netherlands who denied them a place at USA 94.\n\nGraham Taylor's England had a poor campaign, taking just one point from two games against Norway, who topped the group. They squandered a two-goal lead at home to the Dutch at Wembley, but when they went to Rotterdam for the return fixture - their penultimate game in the group - England still had qualification in their own hands as they were above the Dutch.\n\nWith Paul Gascoigne suspended, England fell behind to a free-kick just after the hour mark by Koeman - who the visitors felt should have been sent off earlier on - before Dennis Bergkamp sealed a 2-0 Dutch win.\n\nEngland beat San Marino in their final game but a Dutch win in Poland ensured they qualified instead. It was a disastrous campaign for Taylor, captured in a warts-and-all TV documentary. Taylor later resigned, while the Dutch reached the World Cup quarter-finals.\n\nThe nations met again in the group stage at Euro '96. Both teams had taken four points from their first two matches before clashing at Wembley, where Alan Shearer opened the scoring with a penalty and added another goal early in the second half, in between a brace by Teddy Sheringham.\n\nPatrick Kluivert's late goal for the Dutch made the final score 4-1 as England - who had current boss Gareth Southgate in defence - won the group and the Netherlands squeezed through in second place ahead of Scotland.\n\nThe Dutch lost on penalties to France in the last eight, while England were beaten in a shoot-out in the semi-finals by Germany, with {"uri": "8217234105", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "15:31:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T15:31:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T15:30:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/07/09/michael-owen-makes-england-v-netherlands-euro-2024-prediction-names-ideal-gareth-southgate-replacement-21194308/", "title": "Owen predicts England v Netherlands and names ideal Southgate replacement", "body": "A 'quietly confident' Michael Owen has backed England to edge past the Netherlands and secure a spot in the Euro 2024 final.\n\nLast time out, England produced an improved display versus Switzerland to advance to the semi-finals but Gareth Southgate's men once again did it the hard way, coming from behind and progressing via a penalty shootout.\n\nHowever, England impressed for long periods in Dusseldorf, with Southgate opting to switch to a back three, and there is a growing sense of optimism among fans, pundits and former players.\n\nUp next for England - chasing a first major trophy in 58 years - is an all-important clash with Ronald Koeman's Netherlands side, who booked their place in the final four thanks to a 2-1 victory over Turkey previously.\n\nThe winning team on Wednesday night will face the victor of this evening's heavyweight semi-final between an out-of-sorts France and Spain, arguably the standout team in this summer's tournament.\n\nPreviewing the Three Lions' contest with the Netherlands for CSGOLuck, ex-England striker Owen said: 'We've played five games now, and we have been poor for four of them and alright for one.\n\n'It's hard to see how we can play that many games, then all of a sudden have a total shift in performance. But the Netherlands again are another step up, although I wouldn't consider them one of the three or four elite nations in the world.\n\n'But they are in that group behind, so normally I would fancy us to go through against them but based on current form I'd say it's a 50/50.\n\n'It's very hard to back against England because you can't help but look at the teams on paper and think we have better individual players, so it's hard to go against us.\n\n'I'd say it could even be a 1-1 draw again with us going through on penalties, or us winning 2-1. I'd go for the latter. I am quietly confident we can go through.'\n\nSouthgate, who is out of contract with England later this year, has admitted that he will likely step aside should he fail to lead his side to glory this summer.\n\nOwen believes Southgate will look to leave regardless of the outcome in Germany and feels ex-Brighton and Chelsea head coach Graham Potter could be the best fit to replace him in the hot seat.\n\n'I could imagine with Southgate that there will be a natural parting no matter what the result. If we win it, Southgate's had a fair crack at it, he's enjoyed it but he might even be ready for a change himself,' the former Liverpool, Manchester United and Real Madrid forward added.\n\n'The general feeling among fans in England has been that this is his last tournament.\n\n'A lot of people are frustrated with the cautious approach. I just think it may be an occasion whereby it's best for everyone, he might want a break or have a crack at club management.\n\n'I would say if we win or not, Southgate will be looking at life after England.\n\n'There is not an outstanding candidate to take over if Southgate goes. I personally am of the opinion that we should stick to an English manager, that's what international football is about. In fact I would almost go as far as to say there should be a rule change. You are playing for your country, the players are going to be from that country.\n\n'In club football you can have any player or coach from any country but I think when you're playing for your country it should be Scottish managers, Scottish players and Scottish physios. That's the point. Same with France. That's the point of international football.\n\n'It's not a rule but I would have that principle and would like England to have an English manager. I think possibly the one manager free and available is Graham Potter, who may take it. Apart from him, I think Steve Cooper is a good manager, Frank Lampard and Gerrard would have been tipped in the past but they probably need to do well in their current jobs to be back in the fold maybe.\n\n'Eddie Howe I really see as a top manager but he's employed at the moment. As things stand, if Southgate were to leave tomorrow I'd probably say Potter.'\n\nMORE : Ian Wright speaks out on Arsenal fans turning on him for Bukayo Saka demand\n\nMORE : Arsenal eager to sign The big decision for Ronald Koeman will be whether to stick with Steven Bergwijn starting on the right or to bring in either Donyell Malen or Wout Weghorst, the latter meaning a reshuffle of the attack, Xavi Simons likely moving to the flank.\n\nMarc Guehi is back from suspension and with Luke Shaw having returned to fitness to appear off the bench in the quarter-final, England should also have a full 26-man squad for Gareth Southgate to choose from. Starting Shaw or not - and if in place of Kieran Trippier or someone else - will be the manager's big decision, while Guehi may not come back into the side if Ezri Konsa keeps his place.\n\nPredicted lineups\n\nNED - Verbruggen, Dumfries, De Vrij, Van Dijk, Ake, Schouten, Reijnders, Bergwijn, Simons, Gakpo, Depay\n\nENG - Pickford, Walker, Stones, Guehi, Saka, Rice, Mainoo, Shaw, Foden, Bellingham, Kane\n\nWhen is Netherlands vs England?\n\nNetherlands face England in the second semi-final at Euro 2024, with the game kicking off at 8pm BST on Wednesday 10 July in Dortmund.\n\nWhere can I watch it?\n\nThe match will be broadcast live on ITV 1 and STV, while UK viewers can stream the game via the ITV X and STV Player platforms and apps. {"uri": "8214785237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "07:25:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T07:25:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T07:25:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/sport-opinion/eamon-dunphy-column-england-can-33190100", "title": "Eamon Dunphy column: England can make most of poor Euros", "body": "England have a great chance of winning the Euros for three reasons. Switzerland. Slovakia. Slovenia.\n\nThose are their last three opponents. If you had to pick three teams at a major tournament to give you a ticket to the semi-finals, you wouldn't believe your luck if you landed all of those.\n\nActually, I'm wrong, there's a fourth reason. The Netherlands. Now the Dutch have a great history but it's just that. History. This is a plodding team who depend on Cody Gakpo and Memphis Depay up front. That says it all.\n\nREAD MORE: Serie A giants move for Irish teen who is also generating interest from Chelsea and PSV\n\nREAD MORE: Brendan Rodgers says Ireland youngster has the 'personality' to play for Celtic\n\nEngland couldn't have picked handier semi-final opponents.\n\nThe draw is the overriding reason why England can become champions, though I still make France favourites.\n\nIt's not that England have a good team, never mind a great one.\n\nIt's not due to the ability of Gareth Southgate as manager.\n\nHe looks more and more like what he was - a man who got Middlesbrough relegated.\n\nBut I think England will be in the final because they still have outstanding individuals.\n\nLook at their last two games. England were atrocious against both Switzerland and Slovakia.\n\nThey survived, though, because of two moments of brilliance from two class acts in Jude Bellingham and Bukayo Saka.\n\nHow many passages of good team play did England show in those games? Very few.\n\nThey are not a team at all. A manager always should aim to make the whole greater than the sum of the parts.\n\nSouthgate has done the opposite. England, with the players they have, should be much better, but he just picks individuals, not a team.\n\nAnd his conservatism is a major issue too.\n\nIt's never good to be a reactive manager, but that is what Southgate is - witness how he turned to his bench instantly after Switzerland went in front on Saturday.\n\nHe makes changes when they are forced on to him.\n\nIt was clear against Switzerland that a change was needed at left-back. Southgate turned to Luke Shaw, who hadn't played a game since February.\n\nWhen he came on to the pitch, it was clear he was in no way fit.\n\nSouthgate had the option of using Joe Gomez, who played 17 games at left-back for Liverpool last season, and did well there.\n\nBut Shaw is one of the manager's men. Even though he wasn't match fit or, in any way, fit, he turned to Shaw.\n\nHe got away with it because he is blessed with luck at this tournament.\n\nHe's had this luck at other tournaments too. It's incredible the run of good fortune he's had.\n\nIf he is to lead England to glory, though, he can't rely on luck forever.\n\nBig and brave calls have to be made. Harry Kane is badly out of form. He has posed hardly any threat across five games now.\n\nHe was only taken off well into extra time when he picked up a knock.\n\nIs Southgate going to allow a Cristiano Ronaldo situation to develop?\n\nNo player should be undroppable. It doesn't matter if you wear the captain's armband.\n\nSouthgate has plenty of other options up front. He can't afford to always wait until changes are forced upon him.\n\nIs there anyone who is willing to tell Southgate that he can't keep going the way he's going?\n\nIt seems that Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink is his main sounding board.\n\nIn September 2022, Hasselbaink resigned as Burton Albion manager after just seven games of the season.\n\nThey were bottom of League One with just one point from seven games.\n\nHe also managed Royal Antwerp in the Belgian Second Division, QPR in the Championship and Northampton Town in League One.\n\nHasselbaink had a fine playing career but his managerial one has been mediocre.\n\nBut somehow he landed the job of Southgate's assistant with England. In game after game, he is in Southgate's ear.\n\nIf that has, in part, contributed to the turgid stuff we've had to endure from England, it's bewildering.\n\nThe buck does stop with Southgate, however. He'll feel his approach has been vindicated by England's progress. It hasn't, he's just been lucky.\n\nIf such a limited team make the final, what does it tell us about Euro 2024?\n\nIt tells us that international football - in Europe, anyway - is not in a great place.\n\nPremier League clubs started preseason training last week but international football is still going on, all over the world.\n\nPlayers are tired - both physically and mentally. The best players have been defenders, even 41-year-old Pepe was able to leave his mark.\n\nThat tells me that it's a far from vintage tournament.\n\nI have enjoyed Spain but I think their younger players are starting to feel the heat and wilt under the pressure.\n\nFrance, because of the players and experience they have, are the best bet to win outright, but this is a tournament that raises serious questions about Mbappe.\n\nWe saw him as the heir to Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo as the world's greatest player.\n\nBut I'm not sure if he'll ever be the player he promised to be.\n\nHe chose to cruise in the French league for far too long and has been dreadful at the Euros. A broken nose is no excuse.\n\nWe'll know his real worth when he goes to Real Madrid. I wouldn't be convinced he'll shine there.\n\nI can see us ending up with an England v France final, and that would likely be a hard watch.\n\nEngland are dreaming again, but Southgate has come up with a team that play with fear - fear of mistakes, fear of the press, fear of their fans, fear of criticism.\n\nI'm not convinced fear can drive a team to glory, but it will get them to the European {"uri": "8217448292", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:12:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:12:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:12:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/29056684/england-netherlands-euro-2024-tactics-analysis-team/", "title": "Three reasons why England will beat the Netherlands in tense semi-final", "body": "Our analysis shows why England should progress after their much improved showing against Switzerland\n\nTHE quarter final tie against Switzerland was arguably the first real test for England at this European Championships.\n\nThe Swiss had impressed to this point in the tournament and they had came through a tough round of 16 match against Italy and looked good in doing so.\n\nThey even managed to take the lead in the quarter final match, perhaps against the run of play, and England were put on the back foot.\n\nThis England side, however, have already shown determination and a willingness to keep working to the final whistle.\n\nIn the round of 16 against Slovakia it took an acrobatic last minute effort from Jude Bellingham to equalise before they went on to win in extra time.\n\nAgainst Switzerland the composure during the penalty shoot out also spoke of an English side who were well coached and well prepared for this scenario coming into the tournament.\n\nNow, in the semi-final England play a Netherlands side who have faced similar criticism to England during the tournament.\n\nThe Dutch have been solid defensively but they have faced issues when it comes to ball progression and chance creation in the final third, despite the strong performances so far from Cody Gakpo of Liverpool.\n\nNow, as the Netherlands and England meet this week in the semi final there is a clear sense that whichever side is brave enough to take the initiative and to play on the front foot will have a clear advantage going when it comes to reaching the final.\n\nAgainst Switzerland we saw some small changes from England and their coach Gareth Southgate that seemed effective in terms of offering greater control to the English in the match.\n\nBEST FREE BET SIGN UP OFFERS FOR UK BOOKMAKERS\n\nThe most notable was perhaps the switch of Phil Foden from a position where he started on the left-side to a more central position as the '10' between the midfield and the attack.\n\nWe will look at three of the main tactical questions going into this semi final match between the two teams.\n\nFootball is difficult and the truth is that the positions players occupy during a game can be very different from the tactical graphic that the TV channels show us before the game.\n\nIn England's first four matches at the tournament, for example, we saw Foden listed as the left-winger in Southgate's 4-2-3-1 system.\n\nDuring the matches, however, Foden continued to position himself narrow in the channels or even in the central areas.\n\nAgainst Switzerland we finally saw Foden used primarily as the '10' as his starting position, as England changed to something closer to a 3-4-3 shape.\n\nThis meant that the Manchester City man was finally free to move around the central areas as he dropped in and out of pockets of space.\n\nHis movement and positioning in these central areas was very effective for England as it meant the midfield and central defenders had an effective target to play into as they progressed the ball and broke the lines of the Swiss defensive structure.\n\nAgainst Switzerland we saw England create width on the left-side through the movement of Bellingham, who was still relatively narrow but willing to move outside to stretch the pitch.\n\nAnd also Kieran Trippier who moved high as the left-sided wingback.\n\nWhile there was a suggestion amongst some that England had shifted to a back three system in this game, the truth was that Kyle Walker, at right-back, had consistently played in a deeper and more narrow position throughout the tournament.\n\nAgainst the Netherlands and their strong defensive structure the importance of having a player like Foden who can quickly dip in and out of pockets of space to receive the ball and play is clear.\n\nIf England want to be successful in this match then creating threat in spaces in front of the Dutch defensive line will be one of the keys.\n\nPlayers like Foden will without a doubt be the key for England and Southgate as they look to unlock the Dutch defence.\n\nThroughout the entire tournament one of the biggest question marks surrounding England and their team selection has been who would be the player to partner Declan Rice in the centre of the midfield.\n\nAgainst Switzerland there can be little doubt that Kobbie Mainoo of Man United has cemented that position for the rest of the tournament.\n\nMainoo showed a poise and level of composure that is incredibly unusual in a midfield player so young and he was consistently available and in space to receive the ball and help teammates.\n\nMainoo received cleanly and showed the ability to progress the ball and break lines over and over again.\n\nThis is something that will clearly be key for Southgate in his game plan to beat the Dutch.\n\nThe presence of Mainoo in the midfield also unlocks the potential of Rice to a greater degree than we saw with either Trent Alexander-Arnold or Conor Gallagher in the midfield for England.\n\nHaving Mainoo, who is comfortable in the position whether attacking or defending, playing in there allows Rice at times to step out in possession and be more aggressive in his own right.\n\nThe presence of Mainoo alongside Rice at the base of the midfield for England will allow the likes of Saka, Foden and Bellingham more space and freedom to play further forward.\n\nWhile England are likely to be entering this match as slight favourites over the Netherlands they will still have to be careful of some of the attacking threat from their Dutch opponents.\n\nDefensively the Netherlands have been incredibly solid so far in this tournament and they are being effectively led by the Liverpool captain Virgil van Dijk.\n\nIn attack, while Memphis Depay has perhaps not been at his best as the central striker, this has been made less important by the performances of the likes of Xavi Simons, from the midfield, and Gakpo from the wing.\n\nSimons will play in this match as the most attacking of the Dutch midfielders and he will show a clear tendency to look to drop into little pockets of space between or around the midfield due of Rice and Mainoo for England.\n\nGakpo has been impressive from the left-side of the attack for the Dutch and he has registered three goals and one assist so far in the tournament.\n\nHe will look to position himself wide and to hold the width on the left for the Dutch and from this position he can receive the ball and either create for others or drive dangerously towards goal.\n\nThe likes of Gakpo and Simons are dangerous opponents for England and they have the capacity to cause threat whether the Netherlands are possession dominant in this game or attacking more in transition.\n\nWhile neither England or the Netherlands have necessarily impressed so far in this tournament, this semi-final still promises to be an interesting and close match.", "source": {"uri": "8218965644", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "15:19:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T15:19:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T15:18:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/why-some-england-fans-hate-netherlands-manager-ronald-koeman/", "title": "The historic reason why some England fans still hate Netherlands manager Ronald Koeman", "body": "Highlights Ronald Koeman is the current Netherlands manager, and he was also a terrific defender-cum-midfielder for his country during his playing career. Koeman infamously fouled England's David Platt in a crucial World Cup qualifier in 1993 but was spared what looked like an obvious red card. The Dutchman went on to score just minutes later and England missed out on qualification for the World Cup in 1994.\n\nThere's a saying that time heals all wounds, and many of the England fans who will be watching the Euro 2024 semi-final between the Three Lions and the Netherlands on Wednesday night won't even have been born when the incident this article is about took place. But football fans are also a special breed, and few England fans over a certain age will ever fully forgive Ronald Koeman for his role in denying the Three Lions a spot at the 1994 World Cup.\n\nIn 1993, England played the Netherlands in a crucial World Cup qualifier knowing that a win, or even a draw, would have been crucial to their chances of making it through to the tournament in the United States. England were coming off the back of a disappointing European Championship campaign in 1992, when they were knocked out in the group stage, and were handed a World Cup qualifying group comprising six teams, with the top two guaranteed a place at the World Cup.\n\nEngland vs the Netherlands H2H record\n\nPlayed\n\n22\n\nEngland wins\n\n6\n\nNetherlands wins\n\n7\n\nDraws\n\n9\n\nEngland's Crunch Showdown vs the Netherlands Three Lions needed to avoid defeat\n\nGraham Taylor was the man in charge when England crashed out of Euro '92 and the Three Lions' poor form in their USA '94 qualifying campaign did little to improve the public's confidence in him as the national team's manager.\n\nEngland actually began their qualifying campaign quite well, collecting 10 points from their opening four matches, but they then went on a three-game win-less run to put themselves in trouble. After eight matches each, England and the Netherlands had the same number of points, having each won four matches, drawn three and lost one.\n\nGIVEMESPORT Key Statistic: England have only failed to qualify for the World Cup three times in the competition's history - in 1974, 1978 and 1994.\n\nNorway, meanwhile, were in pole position to top the group, having won six and drawn two of their first eight qualifying matches, leaving England in a straight shoot-out with the Netherlands for the final qualifying spot.\n\nEngland travelled to Rotterdam to face the Dutch in the penultimate qualifier for both teams, and the Three Lions knew that a draw would make them the favourites to progress to the tournament proper. Although a draw would've seen them stay in third place in qualifying, behind the Netherlands on goal difference, the goal difference swing was only three, and England were due to face whipping boys San Marino in their final qualifier, while the Netherlands had to travel to Poland.\n\nRelated Alan Shearer Names his England Starting 11 to Face the Netherlands\n\nAlan Shearer has had his say on who should start England's Euro 2024 semi-final tie against the Netherlands.\n\nEngland were the better team for much of the game in the Netherlands, creating chance after chance but not managing to convert their dominance into goals. Then, 10 minutes after half-time, England midfielder David Platt was bearing down on the Dutch goal following a through ball by Andy Sinton. Koeman, who had been beaten to Sinton's pass by Platt, blatantly dragged the then Sampdoria player to the ground. It was a denial of an obvious goal-scoring opportunity, and was clearly a foul deserving of a red card.\n\nKoeman Drags Platt Down Dutchman was handed lucky reprieve\n\nThe match referee, Germany's Karl-Josef Assenmacher, however, only brandished a yellow card, and to make matters worse, the foul occurred just outside the penalty area, meaning England didn't even have the chance to at least take the lead from the penalty spot.\n\nEngland boss Taylor was wearing a microphone during the match for a Channel 4 and was audibly, and understandably, furious. \"Referee! Referee! He should be sent off. Is he going to send him off? He's got to send him off! That... what are they being instructed? Eh? You know the rulings. Eh? Linesman! Linesman! What sort of thing is happening here? Absolutely disgraceful. The referee's got me the sack. (To the fourth official) Thank him ever so much for that, won't you.\"\n\nMinutes later, Koeman put his country in front with a delightful free-kick, and the game ended 2-0 to the Netherlands after Dennis Bergkamp had doubled their lead later in the second half.\n\nThat left England needing to beat San Marino, Poland to beat the Netherlands, and for there to be a significant goal difference swing in order for them to finish in second place in the group. England did thrash San Marino, but the Netherlands beat Poland, taking matters out of the Three Lions' hands.\n\nAlthough England did plenty of things wrong during that qualifying campaign, Koeman's role in their failure to make it to the '94 World Cup is what it is most remembered for.", "source": {"uri": "givemesport.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "GiveMeSport"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-07-416927260", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:28:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:28:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T03:07:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/england-ready-to-grasp-shot-at-history-in-euros-semi-final-against-the-dutch/article_da6b00aa-6ec9-5f2a-90f5-e53983fe52c2.html", "title": "England ready to grasp shot at 'history' in Euros semi-final against the Dutch", "body": "The Netherlands have a first Euros final since 1988 in their sights in Dortmund\n\nEngland manager Gareth Southgate said the Three Lions are sensing their shot at history in Wednesday's Euro 2024 semi-final against a Netherlands side hitting their stride in Dortmund.\n\nSouthgate's men are aiming to reach the final of a major tournament on foreign soil for the first time and take a step closer to ending a 58-year wait to win a major tournament.\n\nThe winners will face Spain in Berlin on Sunday after they came from behind to beat France 2-1 on Tuesday.\n\nEngland missed out in heartbreaking fashion in the final of Euro 2020, losing on penalties at Wembley to Italy.\n\nCaptain Harry Kane said reaching back-to-back finals would be an \"amazing achievement\" as he aims to win a first major trophy of his career.\n\nBut Kane has been singled out for criticism back home for his sluggish displays in Germany, where he now plays his club football for Bayern Munich.\n\nThe 30-year-old has scored two of England's five goals at the tournament but has looked physically restricted after missing the end of the club season with a back injury.\n\nKane's lacklustre performances have been symptomatic of England's struggles as a team.\n\nTwice they have stared down a humiliating early exit only to fight back against Slovakia and Switzerland thanks to individual moments of magic from Jude Bellingham and Bukayo Saka.\n\nEngland arrived in Germany as one of the favourites thanks to a richly-talented squad and an upturn in their fortunes under Southgate.\n\nAnd he believes his players struggled to cope with that expectation early in the tournament.\n\n\"One of our strengths over the last eight years has been less fear, less inhibition but at the beginning the expectation weighed heavily,\" said Southgate at his pre-match press conference on Tuesday.\n\n\"Now we are into that moment in the tournament where it is what is possible? What is achievable? Rather than, what could go wrong?\n\n\"That is different for a player. This is now the chance to make history, first time to make a final not held in England.\"\n\nThe selection of referee Felix Zwayer has raised eyebrows after Bellingham was fined during his time at Borussia Dortmund for bringing up a historic charge of match fixing against the German.\n\nZwayer was handed a six-month ban in 2006 after he was investigated for taking a bribe from another official.\n\nBellingham was fined 40,000 euros ($43,000) for his outburst after Bayern Munich beat Dortmund in December 2021.\n\n- Dutch face travel chaos -\n\nThe Netherlands also had their troubles in the group stages as a 3-2 defeat to Austria saw them sneak through as one of the best third-placed sides.\n\nRonald Koeman's men have since found their groove in a 3-0 win over Romania in the last 16 before battling back to beat Turkey 2-1 in the last eight.\n\nThe Dutch boast one of the form attacking players in the tournament in Cody Gakpo, who is looking to move out in front in the race for the Golden Boot by adding to his three goals so far.\n\nThey have had to wait 36 years since their own sole major tournament triumph -- which came the last time the Euros were held in Germany.\n\nBut their preparations for the game were disrupted by issues with the German train system, which has caused chaos for fans throughout the tournament.\n\nThe Netherlands had planned to go from their base in Wolfsburg by rail to Dortmund.\n\nHowever, a blockage on the line meant a last-minute change of plans as they instead had to fly and missed their pre-match media duties as a result.\n\n\"We don't play until 9 pm (1900GMT) tomorrow. I'm sure they will still get dinner when they arrive,\" added Southgate.\n\n\"They've got plenty of time. I don't see it having any impact on the game.\"\n\nkca/nf\n\nMore from this section\n\nInformative Research Adds Brandon Hall as New EVP of Operations\n\nUnited Filmmakers Announces an Exciting {"uri": "8214166955", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-07", "time": "18:57:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-07T18:57:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-07T18:56:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.foxsports.com/stories/soccer/southgates-streetwise-england-finally-copying-most-successful-nations", "title": "Southgate's 'streetwise' England finally copying most successful nations", "body": "D\u00dcSSELDORF, Germany -- Style points and star power were the factors England's public expected its national team to use in building a Euro 2024 campaign.\n\nStreet smarts and scrappy steeliness is how it has actually turned out, and head coach Gareth Southgate is more than fine with that.\n\nLeading into Wednesday's semifinal against the Netherlands in Dortmund (3 p.m. ET on FOX and the FOX Sports app), Southgate said that for all the world-class players he has -- led by Jude Bellingham, Harry Kane, Phil Foden and Bukayo Saka -- it's something less tangible that will have been the key if England gets over the line and wins the trophy.\n\n\"We (didn't used to be) savvy,\" Southgate said in the wake of his team's quarterfinal win via penalty shootout against Switzerland, referencing historical \"heroic failures\" where the Three Lions fell just short.\n\n\"We weren't tournament-wise. This group [is] different. They keep possession for longer periods. We haven't always got it right, but, in general, we have shown the resilience that the teams that win tournaments have had for years and years.\n\n\"Italy, France, Spain -- it's not all pure football. It's other attributes that they've had. We are showing a little bit more of that streetwise nature.\"\n\nMake no mistake, this is an England team that has a gnarled edge. Real Madrid's Bellingham might be the leading contender for the Ballon d'Or based off his skill set, but he has an uncompromisingly ruthless side as well.\n\nSouthgate's men have also had to shrug off a torrent of criticism after their performances to date. Even the Switzerland result, in which they were forced to come from behind with 10 minutes of regulation left, was only a partial improvement. During the shootout, the five successful kickers and goalkeeper Jordan Pickford showed their reserves of fortitude.\n\n[Related: Jordan Pickford's wild water bottle is just the start of England's penalty preparation]\n\n\"We are fighting,\" Southgate added. \"We are not going to stop fighting. We are in another semifinal, and we will see where we can get to. You have to show other qualities to win in tournaments, and these players are showing unbelievable qualities of character (and) resilience.\n\n\"I spoke to them about it, it is not just about playing well. (In beating Germany), Spain mixed their game up. They took seven yellow cards. They found ways to win. (Our) players are showing all those other attributes. Dealing with everything that's around this. Twice coming from behind in games. Now a penalty shootout where their composure was impeccable. I am so, so proud of them.\"\n\nIf England is winning ugly, at least the team is winning. With only four teams remaining, there are 20 others who would gladly swap places with them, despite not a single standout performance to date.\n\nEvery game it is said they need to get better. It has only happened in small increments.\n\nBut Southgate also wants to dispel the notion that elegant displays are constantly present for great teams that win major championships. Realistically, it only feels like that, because time often makes us forget in-the-moment struggles.\n\nWhile the likes of Bellingham and Foden shined during the club season on teams that espouse rapid, fluid attack, Southgate insisted the comparisons are not entirely fair, based off the differing situations.\n\n\"These are not normal football matches,\" he said. \"These are national events with huge pressure, with really young men in the middle of it. Our team has been under enormous pressure from the start. They are doing so well, so well.\n\n\"We are not able to score a load of goals at the moment, but again, we have played three teams that have ... very well-organized defenses. None of this stuff is easy, but we are in a third semifinal in four tournaments.\"\n\n[Related: 'We can change our lives forever': England's shot at history still alive]\n\nEven the exception to those four, a quarterfinal defeat to France at the 2022 World Cup, was a laudable outcome.\n\nBy these metrics, Southgate is the most successful head coach in the history of the England men's team. He knows he'll never be regarded as such unless he delivers the country only its second major trophy to follow victory on home soil in the 1966 World Cup.\n\nHis squad came so close at the last Euros, when England led Italy in the second half of the final before being pegged back and losing on penalties.\n\nThe coach has been open about how the stresses of the job largely prevent him from feeling any sense of personal enjoyment. Widespread criticism of his methods during the group stage in Germany has only added to that notion. It is widely expected that he will leave the post after this tournament, even though his contract runs until December, having been in charge since 2016.\n\nDancing on the field with the players as they celebrated in front of the England fans in D\u00fcsseldorf was a rare moment of the 53-year-old letting his guard down.\n\n\"Every now and then you think surely there has to be some enjoyment in this job,\" he said. \"If I can't enjoy that moment then the whole thing is a waste of time, really. I love the players, I love being in that moment with them.\n\n\"I took this job to try and improve England football. I wanted us to regain credibility on a world stage. I can't deny when it's as personal as it has been the last few weeks, on a human level -- that's quite difficult.\"\n\n[Related: Bukayo Saka goal, shootout redemption sends England past Switzerland, to Euros semis]\n\nSpeaking of levels of difficulty, things only get harder from here. The Netherlands only finished third in its group, but has surged to two impressive wins since then, both within 90 minutes, while England has twice gone to extra time and now has a quick turnaround to contend with.\n\nThe Dutch crushed Group E winner Romania and then showed resolve in overturning a deficit against Turkey, and its huge support, in Berlin. Cody Gakpo, one of the World Cup's breakout stars, is firing again.\n\nSouthgate knows England hasn't played its best soccer and would rank last of the semifinalists in style points, even with France's scoring troubles. Instead, though, there's a certain beauty to be found in getting the job done regardless. After all, coaches are constantly reminded that this is a results-based business.\n\n\"There is what we ideally want to be and there's how we've needed to be,\" Southgate said. \"To find ways to
