{"uri": "8218374299", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "09:14:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T09:14:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T09:14:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://news.sky.com/story/england-v-netherlands-latest-england-fans-to-be-outnumbered-itv-curse-looms-over-southgates-men-13175582", "title": "England v Netherlands latest: England fans to be outnumbered; ITV curse looms over Southgate's men", "body": "\"My memories of playing Holland with the orange in the stadium are vivid, these are the matches we want to play in. You live for these tournaments, that's where you step up.\"\n\nFollowing the disappointment of a quarter-final exit at the World Cup in Qatar back in 2022, England comfortably qualified for Euro 2024 by finishing top of their group without losing a game.\n\nThe Three Lions were billed among the favourites for the tournament before it kicked off, and that didn't change when Gareth Southgate's 26-man squad announcement threw up some surprises.\n\nPrevious stalwarts from the last few major tournaments - Harry Maguire, Marcus Rashford, Kalvin Phillips and Jack Grealish - were left out entirely, while the then-unfit Luke Shaw was the only recognised left-back picked in the squad.\n\nRegardless, England still headed to Germany boasting a squad that included the best players from three of Europe's top divisions last season.\n\nFew could argue that Southgate didn't come into the tournament with the most exciting trio of attacking players on the continent in Manchester City's Phil Foden, Real Madrid's Jude Bellingham and Bayern Munich's Harry Kane.\n\nBut, despite that, England didn't look anywhere near their free-flowing best in Group C.\n\nGroup stages\n\nWith the previously mentioned trio of attacking players joined by Arsenal star Bukayo Saka in the starting XI, it was felt by many that England would be finding the net regularly.\n\nInstead, they only scored twice - Bellingham's header in the 1-0 win over Serbia to get the tournament started and a goal from Kane in a 1-1 draw with Denmark.\n\nA 0-0 draw with Slovenia ensured the Three Lions came through the group in top spot, but there were underlying worries over England's inability to cut their opponents open.\n\nOf the 24 nations participating in the group stage at Euro 2024, Southgate's side ranking 20th with just 29 shots, while they managed only 53 touches in the opponents' box.\n\nSome fans were at this point calling for Southgate to be replaced as manager mid-tournament, such was the disappointment among supporters at England's lacklustre start to life in Germany.\n\nOn the positive side, England looked solid in defence, conceding just a single goal during their three group games.\n\nThey were also the team with the lowest expected goals against (xGA) score - a metric that calculates the number of goals a team is expected to concede based on the quality of chances their opponents create.\n\nInto the knockouts\n\nAfter making it into the knockout stages, England were fortunate that their side of the draw had an absence of big hitters - Spain, Germany, Portugal and France were all on the other half of the bracket.\n\nStill, Southgate's side had to beat what was in front of them, and in the round of 16 that was Slovakia, ranked the 48th best country in world football ahead of kick-off.\n\nDespite this, England were seconds away from an embarrassing exit in Gelsenkirchen as Slovakia defended a lead they had held since the 25th minute thanks to Ivan Schranz's low finish past Jordan Pickford.\n\nThen came a moment of brilliance from Bellingham who, with an overhead kick in the final minute, sent Marc Guehi's headed flick into the net to spare England's blushes after a woeful performance.\n\nCaptain Harry Kane then emphasised England's new-found superiority with his headed winner, snatching victory from the jaws of defeat and setting up a quarter-final clash with Switzerland.\n\nA change of system beckoned for the last eight, but once again England laboured in the final third. And, once again, they went behind after Breel Embolo scored with 15 minutes remaining.\n\nThis time it was down to Bukayo Saka, not Bellingham, to be the hero, equalising with a fine finish through a crowded box before stepping up to slot home his penalty in the resulting shoot-out.\n\nIt was another performance at this tournament that won't live too long in the memory for England fans, not that Southgate will care.\n\n\"Winning tournaments isn't just about playing well,\" he said at full-time. \"I thought we did play well, but it's not just about that, you have to show all the other attributes to win, but we showed them tonight.\"\n\nSupporters came into Euro 2024 hoping to see England play their way to the final with free-flowing, high-scoring football.\n\nThey haven't managed it, but they are still in the tournament and are just two wins away from lifting a major trophy.", "source": {"uri": "news.sky.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sky News"}, "authors": [], underwhelming in the group stage and then needing extra-time and penalties to scrape past Slovakia and Switzerland - but now find themselves just two wins away from ending 58 years of hurt.\n\nRonald Koeman's Netherlands progressed to the knockouts as one of the best third-place teams before outclassing Romania and Turkey to set up a semi-final meeting with England in Dortmund.\n\nIn the other side of the draw, Spain take on France in a huge European clash at the Allianz Arena in Munich.\n\nOpta's supercompter has predicted the likely winners from each semi-final and revealed which team has the best chance of becoming European champions come Sunday evening.\n\nBoth semis are incredibly difficult to call, according to the data, with England given a 51.51% chance of progressing to the final as opposed to 48.49% for the Netherlands.\n\nSpain are the marginal favourites in the other tie with a 53.51% chance of making the showpiece event in Berlin.\n\nInterestingly, Opta's supercomputer currently gives England just a 22.58% chance of winning Euro 2024 - with only Netherlands given less of a chance.\n\nOn Spain's mouth-watering clash with France, analyst Tom Patey said: 'The Opta supercomputer backed Spain as the slight favourites for this one, with La Roja winning 38.2% and France triumphing in 31.8% of 10,000 pre-match simulations.\n\n'A draw would send this tie to extra time, as was the case in three of four quarter-finals, with that result forecast in 30% of data-led sims.'\n\nLooking ahead to England's match, analyst Patric Ridge added: 'England have been clear favourites, according to the Opta supercomputer, in every match they have played at Euro 2024 so far. But that is not the case for this tie.\n\n'The model gives England a 37.8% chance of victory, just marginally more than the Netherlands' 31.6%; the draw threat (so, the likelihood of a penalty shootout) is coming in at a relatively large 30.6%.'\n\nMORE : Gareth Southgate 'cannot' drop England star for Euro 2024 semi-final, says Alan Shearer\n\nMORE : England star Phil Foden responds to Southgate was pelted with beer cups after a 0-0 draw against Slovenia in the group stages and has faced a backlash for his perceived negative tactics with a richly-talented squad.\n\n\"I can't deny then when things get as personal as it has that does hurt. I don't think it's normal to have beer thrown at you,\" said Southgate of his detractors.\n\n\"But we're in a third semi-final in four tournaments, and I think we continue to give people fantastic memories.\n\nSo we'll keep grinding, we'll keep fighting, and we'll keep enjoying this journey.\"\n\nSouthgate is expected to stick by that 3-4-2-1 system with Marc Guehi returning from suspension to replace Ezri Konsa.\n\nThe England boss has bristled at suggestions his side ended up on the kind side of the draw, away from France, Spain, Germany and Portugal.\n\nYet, the Dutch can count themselves even more fortunate for their path to the final after finishing third in Group D behind France and Austria.\n\nLiverpool's Cody Gakpo has arguably been the form attacker at the tournament and is the only player to have scored three goals still alive in the competition.\n\nThe Dutch have had to wait 36 years since their own sole major tournament triumph, the last time the Euros were held in Germany.\n\nThat is also the only time they have ever made a European Championship final.", "source": {"uri": "urdupoint.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UrduPoint"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8216657890", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "09:38:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T09:38:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T09:38:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/sport/soccer/kane-call-contentious-ref-van-dijk-in-way-england-netherlands-talking-points-D6YJJBHGUJP2ZBOLZR65SBXWAI/", "title": "Kane call, contentious ref, Van Dijk in way - England-Netherlands talking points", "body": "The winners will play Spain or France in Sunday's Berlin showpiece.\n\nEngland face the Netherlands in Dortmund on Wednesday evening looking to book a place in back-to-back European Championship finals.\n\nGareth Southgate's side have been heavily criticised for their performances at Euro 2024 but are one game away from Sunday's showpiece in Berlin.\n\nHere, the PA news agency takes a look at some of the key talking points ahead of the meeting with the Dutch.\n\nIt would have been unthinkable before a ball was kicked at the Euros to consider that Harry Kane's place in Southgate's starting XI would be called into question.\n\nCaptain, all-time leading goalscorer and a man who hit the back of the net 44 times in 45 appearances for Bayern Munich last season.\n\nBut the 30-year-old has struggled throughout the tournament and in the the quarter-final win over Switzerland in particular, and has been substituted as many times as he has scored - twice - while Ivan Toney has impressed in his short outings from the bench.\n\nIn all likelihood, Southgate will stick with his talisman for such a big game, but the fact his place is even being speculated about speaks volumes for his summer so far.\n\nLuke Shaw made his long-awaited comeback from injury as he came off the bench against the Swiss, racking up his first minutes since a hamstring problem he suffered at Manchester United in February.\n\nThe 28-year-old had hoped to be available earlier in the competition as Southgate opted to bring just one recognised left-back in his 26-man squad - but a setback delayed his return.\n\nNow though, he insists he is ready to start against the Netherlands on Wednesday night.\n\nIf the Dutch are to down England and reach their first Euros final since 1988, the chances are a couple of Premier League players will have a big say.\n\nLiverpool duo Virgil van Dijk and Cody Gakpo have been crucial in the run to the semi-final for Ronald Koeman's men.\n\nCaptain Van Dijk, who turned 33 on Monday, remains one of the best centre-backs in Europe and will fancy his chances against whoever plays up front for England - while Gakpo is one of four players jointly leading the Golden Boot race having scored three goals in Germany.\n\nSouthgate made the call to switch to a back three against Switzerland and, while the tie was ultimately decided on penalties, England did produce an improved performance.\n\nShaw could now come in to help the balance even more, while Marc Guehi is available after serving a one-match ban.\n\nThe shift, though, has allowed Phil Foden and Jude Bellingham more chance to roam with the pair able to both operate centrally, while Bukayo Saka's turn at right wing-back saw the Arsenal man produce his best football of the tournament so far.\n\nAll in all, it now seems improbable Southgate would abandon the change in system after one game, although - unlike the Swiss - the Netherlands do usually operate with a back four.\n\nFelix Zwayer - a German referee who was banned over his part in a match-fixing scandal - will take charge of the game at Signal Iduna Park.\n\nThe 43-year-old was given a six-month ban by his country's football federation in 2006, having worked as an assistant referee alongside Robert Hoyzer.\n\nBellingham was fined by the German federation after he referenced Zwayer's involvement in that scandal after a defeat for his old club Borussia Dortmund against Bayern Munich in 2021.\n\nSpeaking ahead of the game, Shaw said the England players \"respect UEFA\" in terms of its selection of officials and that they were not concerned by Zwayer's appointment.", "source": {"uri": "irishnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "8217853273", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "01:48:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T01:48:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T01:46:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/euro-2024/miguel-delaney-grind-has-got-england-this-far-but-spectacle-is-needed-against-dutch/a1956782361.html", "title": "Miguel Delaney: Grind has got England this far, but spectacle is needed against Dutch", "body": "As the magnitude of the fixture becomes greater, England's preparation becomes less intense. The squad have done most of the work to get this far. A bit like their successful approach to penalties, there can be a danger of over-preparation.\n\nGareth Southgate is instead intent on doing most of the preparation in meetings, ensuring his players are conscious of the different challenges a competent Netherlands side pose.\n\nThis is the benefit of experience; Southgate has been in more semi-finals than any other England manager. As he prepares for his third at a major tournament, it feels less momentous for their fans, albeit no less invigorating. England just have bigger ambitions now.\n\n\"The great thing is we're not sitting here happy with a semi-final,\" Southgate said. \"We want to go further...\"\n\nThat is one fact amid all these different emotions that shouldn't be forgotten. England are just a match from one of the greatest stages in the game, offering a chance to rectify Euro 2020.\n\nThis is what England have long desired. Southgate even made a point of reminding people of that on the eve of the semi, as he compared the Dutch tournament record to England's. While this is their seventh semi-final, it is the Netherlands' 10th.\n\n\"Our semi-final tally looks a bit healthy now, looks a bit more like what we'd hope an England history would look like,\" Southgate said. \"But there are a lot of nations who have won the European Championship and we haven't - and we want to try and correct that balance.\"\n\nSouthgate stressed his team have constantly managed to \"break new ground\", be that winning big games away, triumphing in shoot-outs and, of course, regularly getting far in tournaments.\n\n\"We've never been to a final outside our own shores. These are opportunities to make a difference and that's how we have to look at it. We don't want to be burdened by what's happened before.\"\n\nIf we're looking to the past, the last meeting between these two teams in a major championship weighs over this and not just for how past results inform the psychology of a game. There were also the specifics of what happened and how they relate to now.\n\nThat match was in June 1996, when England had managed to come so far through a highly anticipated European Championships with some moments of individual inspiration but also so much inertia. They then stepped out against the Netherlands and put in one of the great tournament displays.\n\nThe late Terry Venables described that 4-1 win as \"perfection\" and his \"most thrilling experience in football\"; all the more satisfying for how it represented \"the culmination of two-and-a-half years of preparation\".\n\nSouthgate's work goes back much further, seven years. This tournament has been viewed as potentially his moment of deliverance when it could all come together. It's difficult not to feel that prospect still being dependent on the performance level finally rising; to putting in a properly convincing display - a spectacle.\n\nThe identity of the opposition and the resonance of the fixture only add to that, especially with how the \"grind\" of England's progress through Euro 2024 - to use Southgate's own words - has so strengthened resolve. The English hope it can bring the team to the point where the actual collective can finally reflect the great ability of the players.\n\nEngland's games have instead been absorbing for entirely different reasons. They have been psychodramas rather than spectacles as if the players had to confront many internal and external challenges as much as the opposition.\n\nMaybe, as in 1996, the will to come through so much might suddenly bring the explosion the English want.\n\nOr, it might just see more of the same. Issues remain. The elimination of Switzerland only emphasised some of them, not least the lack of fluency. It's why Southgate felt the need to talk about it with the players. It almost represented a form of team therapy.\n\n\"When you can sense that feeling, you need to confront it. It's no use avoiding it and hoping it will go away. In the end, we sort of had to grind it out on the pitch.\"\n\nThe line-up is expected to remain the same beyond the inclusion of Luke Shaw on the left and the return of the previously suspended Marc Guehi for Ezri Konsa.\n\nAs has become so apparent through England's campaign, however, how they start may not be as important as how they finish. That may be crucial, but right now, all that matters for them is reaching the final.", "source": {"uri": "independent.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish Independent"}, "authors": [], "concepts": "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southgate,_London", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Southgate, London"}, "location": {"type": "place", The game will kick off at 9 PM CET / 3 PM ET / 12 PM PT.\n\nSoccer aficionados in the States can catch the game live on TV on FOX. Alternatively, one can watch the game live on Foxsports.com, Fubo TV, and the Fox Sports app.\n\nAfter claiming a thumping 3-0 victory over Romania in the Round of 16, the Netherlands locked horns with stubborn Turkiye in the quarter-finals. The underdogs drew first blood through Samet Akaydin in the 35th minute, putting pressure on Koeman's side.\n\nHolland probed and pushed for the equalizer, but it did not arrive until the 70th minute. Center-back Stefan de Vrij emerged as the Netherlands' messiah, dispatching a thumping header to send Memphis Depay's cross into the back of the net. Six minutes later, the Oranje went 2-1 up, with Mert Muldur diverting Denzel Dumfries' effort into the back of the Turkish net. Turkiye pushed hard for the equalizer but the Netherlands held firm to secure the win.\n\nEngland, meanwhile, had to rely on penalties to book their place in the EURO 2024 semi-finals. Southgate's goal-shy England went behind in the 75th minute, with Breel Embolo tapping the ball in from close range. The Three Lions, however, were behind only for five minutes, as Bukayo Saka dispatched a gem of a left-footed curler to find the back of the net from outside the box. With the scoreline level at 1-1, the match went into extra time.\n\nNeither team managed to find the breakthrough in the added 30 minutes, which pushed the game to penalties. England commendably held their nerve in the shootout, claiming a 5-3 victory.\n\nTeam News\n\nThe Netherlands have all of their players fit and firing, so Koeman is unlikely to tinker with his starting XI. England, meanwhile, will have Marc Guehi available for selection after the center-back sat out the last game due to suspension.\n\nHead-To-Head\n\nThe two sides have 22 times since their first meeting on May 18, 1935. The Dutch have won seven times in their meetings whereas the Three Lions have claimed six times. There have been nine draws so far. Their most recent meeting came in the UEFA Nations League in 2019. The Netherlands thoroughly outclassed England in that game, bagging a 3-1 victory.\n\nNetherlands vs England - Prediction\n\nOn paper, England have a much superior team, but they have not fired as a unit this summer. {"uri": "8215153423", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "11:30:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T11:30:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T11:29:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.news9live.com/sports/football/uefa-euro-2024-the-rich-history-of-england-vs-netherlands-rivalry-2608714", "title": "UEFA Euro 2024: The rich history of England vs Netherlands rivalry", "body": "New Delhi: England and the Netherlands are preparing for the first semi-final in Dortmund, with the two teams having one of the fiercest rivals in football history. In the previous edition of the European Championship, England were runners-up, while the Netherlands were knocked out of the final 16.\n\nThe first time these two teams met was in 1935 when England won 1-0 in Olympisch Stadion, Amsterdam. Since then, the team have played nine draws, as England have won six games and Netherlands have won seven occasions.\n\nFor English football fans, one of the best memories against the Dutch team was their 4-1 win in the Euro '96. Both Alan Shearer and Teddy Sheringham scored braces, pushing the Three Lions to the quarter-finals.\n\nHowever, the team's performance in the nine matches since that spectacular night involves just one win. In the 1988 Euros, Marco van Basten's hat-trick ensured the Oranje won 3-1 against an English side that lost all three games of the tournament. The Netherlands would go on to win the championship that year.\n\nIn 1994, Netherlands and England were in the same group for World Cup qualifying. The Dutch team's 2-0 win over the Three Lions ensured that the latter failed to qualify for the World Cup, only the third time the team failed to do so.\n\nMaking their fifth semi-final appearance in the European Championship, the team arrived at the elimination stage third-placed behind France and Austria in their Group. Despite their shaky group stage performances, the Oranje team are two games away from their second Euro championship.\n\nTheir group-stage results weren't consistent. They won 2-1 against Poland and played a goalless draw against France before losing their final group game 3-2 to Austria. Despite how the scorecard may show the result, Austria and France's hald were constantly threatened by the Dutch players. Against Austria, Netherlands levelled the goals twice before Marcel Sabitzer sealed the Austrian fate.\n\nNetherlands picked the pace against Romania, ending the match with 3-0. However, they faced criticism for their goal-scoring frequency. Against Turkey, Netherlands went into half-time trailing 1-0. In the second half, the Dutch team made a strong comeback, scoring two goals within just six minutes.\n\nThe English side have lacked the flair that they usually play with. It is a team full of superstars who have struggled in all the five games they have played in the tournament. Their only win on the group stage came against Serbia in their opening game. They drew two games to top their group stage. In the Round of 16, they were out of the game for the full 90 minutes. They won the game with two goals in the extra time. Their performance was expected to get better in the quarter-finals. They drew the game 1-1 after Bukayo Saka, a leveller, within five minutes of the Swiss goal. {"uri": "8215525752", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "15:33:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T15:33:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T15:33:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/13175158/when-netherlands-manager-ronald-koeman-cheated-graham-taylors-england-in-1994-world-cup-qualifying", "title": "When Netherlands manager Ronald Koeman 'cheated' Graham Taylor's England in 1994 World Cup qualifying", "body": "David Platt bursts through on goal - this is the moment to send England to the 1994 World Cup.\n\nEngland only need a draw in Rotterdam against Netherlands but with almost an hour played and the game goalless, Platt can all but seal their spot.\n\nAndy Sinton's long ball over the top of the Dutch defence is met by the striker who only has goalkeeper Ed de Goey to beat. And then it happens. One of the most controversial moments in England's history.\n\nNetherlands captain Ronald Koeman reaches out with his right arm and hauls Platt to the turf. Referee Karl-Josef Assenmacher instantly charges over pointing to the penalty spot - and surely his next act will be to send Koeman off, who is adamant it should be a free-kick instead.\n\nBut Assenmacher reverses his decision, agreeing with Koeman, before most shockingly, showing the defender a yellow card.\n\n\"What are they being instructed?\" rages England boss Graham Taylor in footage later seen on Channel 4's documentary An Impossible Job. \"What sort of thing is happening here? Absolutely disgraceful.\"\n\nIt gets worse for Taylor and England. Five minutes later, Legendary ITV commentator Brian Moore's prophecy of \"he's going to flick one, he's going to flick one\" comes true as Koeman sends a free-kick into the top left corner to give Netherlands the lead.\n\n\"You know we've been cheated, don't you?\" Taylor says to the assistant referee. \"The referee's got me the sack. Thank him ever so much for that, won't you?\"\n\nEngland fall to a 2-0 defeat and despite a 7-1 win over San Marino a month later in November 1993, the Three Lions fail to qualify. Taylor resigns six days later.\n\nKoeman, the former Southampton, Everton and Barcelona manager, now in charge of Netherlands for a second time, has since admitted he should have walked.\n\n\"It was a clear foul,\" he said in 2018. \"Nowadays it would have been a red card for sure but I was very happy that the referee said it was a free-kick and not a penalty.\"\n\nEngland have won six and lost seven against Netherlands but their greatest day over the Dutch came at Euro 1996.\n\nPaul Gascoigne's iconic goal against Scotland had started the party but England's scintillating performance in the final group game had the country believing.\n\nDoubles from Alan Shearer and Teddy Sheringham had Terry Venables' England four up inside 62 minutes before Patrick Kluivert pulled one back late on - a goal that sent Scotland home.\n\n\"We took on Holland at total football and beat them,\" said Shearer. \"A performance I don't think England have bettered in my living memory, notwithstanding the five goals Sven-Goran Eriksson's team stuck past Germany in 2001.\"\n\nNetherlands have not reached a Euros semi-final since 2004 and Koeman is bidding for a unique double as player and now manager having featured in their Euro 88 success.\n\nHe began his first spell in charge by suffering a 1-0 defeat to England in March 2018 which was seen as somewhat of a statement victory for Gareth Southgate ahead of the World Cup.\n\nJesse Lingard scored his first international goal as England earned victory over Netherlands for the first time since Euro 1996 and their first in the Dutch capital since 1969.\n\nSouthgate continued his back three experiment and moved Kyle Walker onto the right side of the defence alongside John Stones and Joe Gomez as England extended their unbeaten run to seven matches despite being without Harry Kane.\n\nKoeman named Virgil van Dijk as his new captain while Stefan de Vrij, Memphis Depay and Wout Weghorst all featured and will do so again on Wednesday night.\n\nNetherlands roared back a year later, reaching the Nations League final in June 2019 with a 3-1 victory after extra-time over England, the last meeting between the two countries.\n\nMarcus Rashford scored from the penalty spot but in a sign of things to come under Southgate, England sat back and didn't build on their lead, allowing Matthijs de Ligt to equalise.\n\nJesse Lingard had a late winner ruled out for offside by VAR before errors from John Stones and Ross Barkley in extra time when trying to play out from the back led to an own-goal by Kyle Walker and a Quincy Promes {"uri": "8217481192", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:41:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:41:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:41:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/england-best-ever-tournaments-world-cup-euros-ranked/", "title": "England's 9 greatest tournaments of all-time have been ranked", "body": "Highlights England's football team has had a storied history in international tournaments, with a mix of triumphs and heartbreaks. They've reached the World Cup quarter-finals eight times, but only got to one final. With Gareth Southgate as manager, they are hoping to win the Euros for the first time in 2024, yet by reaching the semi-finals, it is already one of their best tournaments.\n\nEvery two years, England dream of glory. A major football tournament is one of the best things in the world -- and the pubs, gardens and streets fill up in the nation as everyone, from every background, unites to support the team. Sometimes, the Three Lions are seen as the laughing stock of international football; they've only won one tournament, but they have come close consistently.\n\nOver the years, England have had some of the greatest players of all time in their hands, yet they've often succumbed to the pressure in the most important matches. It's why being manager of the country is seen as one of the hardest jobs in football; the nation expects glory, but it is easier said than done.\n\nAs England look to end their years of hurt and win Euro 2024, we have ranked their nine greatest major tournaments based on where they finished. After beating Switzerland to reach the semi-finals in Germany, they have now reached the final four for just the seventh time in their history -- yet that could improve under Gareth Southgate.\n\nGreatest England Tournaments\n\nRank\n\nTournament\n\nYear\n\nFinishing Place\n\n1.\n\nWorld Cup\n\n1966\n\nWinners\n\n2.\n\nEuros\n\n2020\n\nRunners-Up\n\n3.\n\nEuros\n\n1968\n\nThird\n\n4.\n\nWorld Cup\n\n1990\n\nFourth\n\n5.\n\nWorld Cup\n\n2018\n\nFourth\n\n6.\n\nEuros\n\n1996\n\nSemi-Finals\n\n7.\n\nEuros\n\n2024\n\nSemi-Finals*\n\n8.\n\nWorld Cup\n\n2002\n\nQuarter-Finals\n\n9.\n\nWorld Cup\n\n2022\n\nQuarter-Finals\n\nRelated 10 Best England Wins in World Cup History (Ranked)\n\nEngland have only won the World Cup once in 1966, but have enjoyed some memorable wins over the years. Here are some of the best.\n\n9 2002 World Cup Quarter-Finals\n\nEngland have reached the World Cup quarter-finals on eight separate occasions, yet their run to that round in 2002 might be one of the most painful ones. The Three Lions hardly waltzed through their group, picking up five points to finish second behind Sweden.\n\nHowever, when they beat Denmark 3-0, partially thanks to a strike from wonderkid Michael Owen, they started to believe. When they took the lead against Brazil in the last eight, that only grew, but goals from Rivaldo and Ronaldinho, which David Seaman should have saved as his long-ranged free-kick looped over his head, ended their dreams. Heartbreak in Asia.\n\nTournament Record\n\nRound\n\nMatch\n\nGroup Stage\n\nEngland 1-1 Sweden\n\nEngland 1-0 Argentina\n\nEngland 0-0 Nigeria\n\nRound of 16\n\nEngland 3-0 Denmark\n\nQuarter-Finals\n\nEngland 1-2 Brazil\n\n8 2022 World Cup Quarter-Finals\n\n20 years later, England had every reason to be confident going into the tournament. They were truly one of the favourites, with a young and thriving squad ready to leave their mark in Qatar. Typically, the Three Lions start slowly in major tournaments, but that wasn't the case in 2022, as they won their first match 6-2 to outline their intentions.\n\nThey went on to finish top of their group and beat Senegal 3-0 in the Round of 16, yet one major test awaited them in the Middle East. It was billed as the match of the tournament -- and England narrowly lost 2-1 to France, as Harry Kane, normally one of the best players in the world, blazed his late penalty over the bar.\n\nTournament Record\n\nRound\n\nMatch\n\nGroup Stage\n\nEngland 6-2 Iran\n\nEngland 0-0 USA\n\nEngland 3-0 Wales\n\nRound of 16\n\nEngland 3-0 Senegal\n\nQuarter-Finals\n\nEngland 1-2 France\n\n7 2024 Euros Semi-Finals* Close\n\nEngland were the favourites among betting companies going into Euro 2024. It was expected to be Gareth Southgate's final tournament as manager -- and they finished top of their group in Germany. Maybe it was not convincing as they finished with five points, but they completed their initial job.\n\nDespite having a squad full of talent, they struggled against Slovakia in the Round of 16, winning 2-1 after extra time, before beating Switzerland on penalties in the quarter-finals. The style of play was dull, yet - somehow - they grounded out results. A match against the Netherlands in the semi-finals awaits as the Three Lions look to reach back-to-back Euro finals.\n\nTournament Record\n\nRound\n\nMatch\n\nGroup Stage\n\nEngland 1-0 Serbia\n\nEngland 1-1 Denmark\n\nEngland 0-0 Slovenia\n\nRound of 16\n\nEngland 2-1 Slovakia (aet)\n\nQuarter-Finals\n\nEngland 1-1 Switzerland (5-3 on pens)\n\nSemi-Finals\n\nEngland x-x Netherlands\n\n6 1996 Euros Semi-Finals\n\nThe year football 'came home'. England were hosting their first tournament since their 1966 triumph on home soil, but expectations were low after a challenging few years for the national team. However, by the time their second group game ended, that negativity was washed away, as they beat bitter rivals Scotland 2-0 at Wembley.\n\nThe following game saw them beat the Netherlands 4-1 -- a match which is widely considered one of their greatest wins of all time, whilst the Three Lions also had luck on their side to progress past Spain on penalties. Only a Gareth Southgate penalty miss in the following round against Germany stopped them from reaching the final.\n\nRelated 'England Boss Gave us One Night Out Before Euros - It Ended up as a 20-Man Bender'\n\nTeddy Sheringham shares all the details about the famous night out in Hong Kong before Euro '96.\n\nTournament Record\n\nRound\n\nMatch\n\nGroup Stage\n\nEngland 1-1 Switzerland\n\nEngland 2-0 Scotland\n\nEngland 4-1 Netherlands\n\nQuarter-Finals\n\nEngland 0-0 Spain (4-2 on pens)\n\nSemi-Finals\n\nEngland 1-1 Germany (5-6 on pens)\n\n5 2018 World Cup Fourth Place\n\nGareth Southgate's first major tournament was expected to be one of progress, but very few tangible results. It wasn't the nation's greatest team ever -- and there were noticeable weaknesses, yet they shone under the Russian sun in 2018. They qualified for the knockout stages after just two matches and a demolition job against Panama.\n\nIn the Round of 16, they won their first-ever shootout at a World Cup against Colombia before cruising past Sweden to reach their first semi-final at the biggest tournament since 1990. It wasn't to be on that occasion as they lost 2-1 to Croatia, yet they inspired the nation throughout.\n\nTournament Record\n\nRound\n\nMatch\n\nGroup Stage\n\nEngland 2-1 Tunisia\n\nEngland 6-1 Panama\n\nEngland 0-1 Belgium\n\nRound of 16\n\nEngland 1-1 Colombia (4-3 on pens)\n\nQuarter-Finals\n\nEngland 2-0 Sweden\n\nSemi-Finals\n\nEngland 1-2 Croatia (aet)\n\nThird-placed Play-off\n\nEngland 0-2 Belgium\n\n4 1990 World Cup Fourth place\n\n\"Italia 90\" holds fond memories for any Englishman growing up in the nation. It was truly a summer of glory for the Three Lions, as they started to dream of glory. Just like most tournaments, it was a slow start, picking up just one win in the group stage, but it was enough to face Belgium in the Round of 16.\n\nA famous David Platt volley secured victory in extra time, whilst two goals from Gary Lineker, who eventually won the Golden Boot, saw them beat Cameroon 3-2 to reach the semi-finals. However, their fierce enemy stood in the way once more, as West Germany beat them on penalties to leave Paul Gascoigne crying on the pitch. Yet more heartbreak for England -- and they failed to win the third-placed play-off as well.\n\nTournament Record\n\nRound\n\nMatch\n\nGroup Stage\n\nEngland 1-1 Ireland\n\nEngland 0-0 Netherlands\n\nEngland 1-0 Egypt\n\nRound of 16\n\nEngland 1-0 Belgium (aet)\n\nQuarter-Finals\n\nEngland 3-2 Cameroon (aet)\n\nSemi-Finals\n\nEngland 1-1 West Germany (3-4 on pens)\n\nThird-placed Play-off\n\nEngland 1-2 Italy\n\nRelated Every FIFA World Cup Logo From 1930 to 2026\n\nAs the United States prepares to host the 2026 World Cup, here is a list of all the logos created for the competition since 1930.\n\n3 1968 Euros Third place\n\nEuro 68 was the first time England had qualified for the European Championships -- and, compared to now, the format was drastically different. UEFA opted to have a prolonged qualifying round that spanned two years and a set of quarter-finals to determine the four teams which would compete at the Finals.\n\nEngland finally secured their place, but they lost 1-0 to Yugoslavia in the semi-finals. Two years after World Cup glory, it was bitterly disappointing, but they did regain pride by beating the Soviet Union 2-0, thanks to goals from Geoff Hurst and Bobby Charlton, to secure third.\n\nTournament Record\n\nRound\n\nMatch\n\nSemi-Finals\n\nEngland 0-1 Yugoslavia\n\nThird-placed Play-off\n\nEngland 2-0 Soviet Union\n\n2 2020 Euros Runners-up\n\nEverything about Euro 2020 was chaos. Taking place a year late due to the COVID-19 pandemic, England played all of their matches, bar one, at home, providing them with a clear advantage. They progressed through the group stages comfortably, before finally beating bitter rivals Germany 2-0 at a raucous Wembley, which was not even full due to restrictions.\n\nAfter destroying Ukraine, they produced one of the most memorable nights in the nation's history by beating Denmark 2-1 to reach the final, yet that's where the glory ended, as the Three Lions lost to Italy on penalties in the final. It was a day marred by violence, attempted break-ins and racial abuse, forever leaving a stain on the country.\n\nTournament Record\n\nRound\n\nMatch\n\nGroup Stage\n\nEngland 1-0 Croatia\n\nEngland 0-0 Scotland\n\nEngland 1-0 Czechia\n\nRound of 16\n\nEngland 2-0 Germany\n\nQuarter-Finals\n\nEngland 4-0 Ukraine\n\nSemi-Finals\n\nEngland 2-1 Denmark (aet)\n\nFinal\n\nEngland 1-1 Italy (2-3 on pens)\n\n1 1966 World Cup Winners\n\nWhen you ask any Englishman what is the greatest day in the country's footballing history, everyone will say their World Cup triumph in 1966. With a team featuring some of the greatest English players ever, they achieved the ultimate goal in football on home soil.\n\nThe group stages were relatively stress-free before the Three Lions scraped past both Argentina and Portugal to reach the final. In a match which was perfect for the biggest stage in the sport, England beat their main rivals, West Germany, 4-2 at Wembley to claim the title. A hat-trick from Geoff Hurst helped secure victory, yet one of his goals has forever been contested as it was unclear if it crossed the line.\n\nGIVEMESPORT Key Statistic: Kylian Mbappe is the only other player to score a hat-trick in a World Cup final after Hurst.\n\nTournament Record\n\nRound\n\nMatch\n\nGroup Stage\n\nEngland 0-0 Uruguay\n\nEngland 2-0 Mexico\n\nEngland 2-0 {"uri": "8218245049", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "07:50:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T07:50:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T07:50:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/sport/football/2024/07/10/can-england-go-all-the-way-key-talking-points-ahead-of-holland-semi-final-clash/", "title": "Can England go all the way? Key talking points ahead of Holland semi-final clash", "body": "England face the Netherlands in Dortmund this evening looking to book a place in back-to-back European Championship finals.\n\nGareth Southgate's side have been heavily criticised for their performances at Euro 2024 but are one game away from Sunday's showpiece in Berlin.\n\nHere, we take a look at some of the key talking points ahead of the meeting with the Dutch.\n\nNo Kane, no gain?\n\nIt would have been unthinkable before a ball was kicked at the Euros to consider that Harry Kane's place in Southgate's starting XI would be called into question.\n\nCaptain, all-time leading goalscorer and a man who hit the back of the net 44 times in 45 appearances for Bayern Munich last season.\n\nBut the 30-year-old has struggled throughout the tournament and in the the quarter-final win over Switzerland in particular, and has been substituted as many times as he has scored - twice - while Ivan Toney has impressed in his short outings from the bench.\n\nIn all likelihood, Southgate will stick with his talisman for such a big game, but the fact his place is even being speculated about speaks volumes for his summer so far.\n\nA Shaw thing\n\nLuke Shaw made his long-awaited comeback from injury as he came off the bench against the Swiss, racking up his first minutes since a hamstring problem he suffered at Manchester United in February.\n\nThe 28-year-old had hoped to be available earlier in the competition as Southgate opted to bring just one recognised left-back in his 26-man squad - but a setback delayed his return.\n\nNow though, he insists he is ready to start against the Netherlands tonight.\n\nLiverpool pair hoping to make Oranje boom\n\nIf the Dutch are to down England and reach their first Euros final since 1988, the chances are a couple of Premier League players will have a big say.\n\nLiverpool duo Virgil van Dijk and Cody Gakpo have been crucial in the run to the semi-final for Ronald Koeman's men.\n\nCaptain Van Dijk, who turned 33 on Monday, remains one of the best centre-backs in Europe and will fancy his chances against whoever plays up front for England - while Gakpo is one of four players jointly leading the Golden Boot race having scored three goals in Germany.\n\nThree and easy\n\nSouthgate made the call to switch to a back three against Switzerland and, while the tie was ultimately decided on penalties, England did produce an improved performance.\n\nShaw could now come in to help the balance even more, while Marc Guehi is available after serving a one-match ban. The shift, though, has allowed Phil Foden and Jude Bellingham more chance to roam with the pair able to both operate centrally, while Bukayo Saka's turn at right wing-back saw the Arsenal man produce his best football of the tournament so far.\n\nAll in all, it now seems improbable Southgate would abandon the change in system after one game, although - unlike the Swiss - the Netherlands do usually operate with a back four.\n\nThe man in the middle\n\nFelix Zwayer - a German referee who was banned over his part in a match-fixing scandal - will take charge of the game at Signal Iduna Park.\n\nThe 43-year-old was given a six-month ban by his country's football federation in 2006, having worked as an assistant referee alongside Robert Hoyzer.\n\nBellingham was fined by the German federation after he referenced Zwayer's involvement in that scandal after a defeat for his old club Borussia Dortmund against Bayern Munich in 2021.\n\nSpeaking ahead of the game, Shaw said the England players {"uri": "8219125838", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:13:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:13:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:12:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/euro-2024-netherlands-penalty-danger-men-and-england-shootouts-analysed-ahead-of-semi-final-clash", "title": "Euro 2024: Netherlands penalty danger-men and England shootouts analysed ahead of semi-final clash", "body": "Jordan Pickford has a good record in shootouts for England going back to the 2018 World Cup (Image credit: Alamy)\n\nDo we have the stomach to watch England in another penalty shootout, or are we at a place where we actually feel fairly confident about them now?\n\nActually, save that answer for tomorrow morning. But to try and settle our nerves a bit - or at least distract ourselves ahead of the Euro 2024 semi-final - we've had a look at how England and the Netherlands compare from the spot historically.\n\nThe data was provided to the BBC by Opta, and we've chopped it up a few different ways to see if we can learn anything from it.\n\nVIDEO How Spain's Lamine Yamal Just DESTROYED France\n\nIf you think penalty data from the early 90s is at all relevant to what might happen on the pitch in Dortmund this evening...well, we still don't have anything conclusive to tell you, weren't afraid.\n\nThe Netherlands have almost exactly the same conversion rate in shootouts (67.6%) as England (68% exactly), with a comparable win/loss record.\n\nBoth sides have overwhelmingly lost their shootouts in the past, though England have recently turned a corner on that front. Having won just one of their first seven, up to and including Euro 2012, Gareth Southgate's side have triumphed in two of their past three. Of course, they fell short where it mattered most, coming undone against Italy in the Euro 2020 final.\n\nThe Netherlands have meanwhile won just two of their eight shootouts, doing so in the Euro 2004 quarter-finals against Sweden and the 2014 World Cup quarter-finals against Costa Rica. The latter is the only time they have managed to score all of their spot kicks; England have done so twice, against Spain at Euro 96 and against Switzerland just a few nights ago.\n\nBut that's all in the past...what about the here and now?\n\nWell, the good news for England fans is the current Three Lions squad have had a lot more recent experience of stepping up from 12 yards than the Netherlands (at international level, at least).\n\nKieran Trippier and Harry Kane both scored against Colombia at the 2018 World Cup; Kane and Bukayo Saka stepped up against Italy (Kane scored, Saka's was saved); and Cole Palmer, Jude Bellingham, Saka, Ivan Toney and Trent Alexander Arnold all succeeded against the Swiss.\n\nAmong the Dutch contingent, only Virgil van Dijk and Wout Weghorst have taken shootout penalties for their country before, in their 2022 World Cup quarter-final defeat to Argentina. Van Dijk's was saved, Weghorst scored. Two other players who featured in that shootout, Teun Koopmeiners and Luuk de Jong, pulled out of the Netherlands squad injured before Euro 2024 began.\n\nEngland also have several more reliable players to call upon than the Netherlands. Across their careers for club and country, England have five players who have taken at least three penalties and maintained a 100% record: Palmer (12), Bellingham (5), Lewis Dunk (4), Alexander-Arnold (4), Anthony Gordon (3).\n\nConversely, Jordan Pickford has most cause to be wary of Steven Bergwijn, who has scored ten out of ten, and Denzel Dumfries, who has not faltered in his three goes to date.\n\nAs for the keepers...Transfermarkt credit Dutch number one Bart Verbruggen with just one penalty save in his career, with another 11 making it past him (8.3%).\n\nPickford's record? Outside shootouts, it's eight denied, 54 conceded (14.8%) - but for England in shootouts, it's five saved, 15 conceded (25%).\n\nGet a free live stream to watch Euro 2024 from anywhere in the world and catch the final stages of the summer's big tournament.\n\nWe have a guide on how to get Euro 2024 tickets if you're still looking to go to the final. It's added a different feel to the games, a different intensity. Our fans will make themselves heard, I'm sure.\"\n\nOn the clash with the Netherlands, Southgate said he has vivid memories from his playing days.\n\n\"These are the matches we want to play in. You live for these tournaments, that's where you step up.\"\n\nEngland fan James, who made the trip from London to watch Harry Kane and co, said he's hoping for an improvement in the Three Lions' performance.\n\n\"England firing on all cylinders can take on the best,\" he told Sky News.\n\n\"It's not been great but we've got the job done... {"uri": "8218176175", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "07:04:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T07:04:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T07:03:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/space-attack-why-dutch-plan-060306354.html", "title": "Space to attack into? Why Dutch plan might suit England", "body": "The Netherlands have really impressed me with their adaptability at Euro 2024, but the way they attack could give England some new opportunities in Wednesday's semi-final.\n\nI've co-commentated on two of their games so far - the 3-2 defeat by Austria in the group stage, and the 2-1 win over Turkey in the quarter-finals.\n\nThe Dutch had good and bad spells in both games, and are far from flawless, but they were able to react each time when things went wrong and that has kind of been the story of their tournament, whoever they have faced.\n\nIn terms of how they set up, the first thing I'd say about Ronald Koeman's side is they are not as high-energy or the kind of high-pressing, front-foot type of team you might expect.\n\nSo they will not come after England and try to press them high up the pitch - but when they have got the ball, they will throw numbers forward.\n\nThat is not something we have seen very often from the five teams that Gareth Southgate's side have faced so far in Germany, and it is definitely something England can take advantage of.\n\nMost of the time, the Dutch are set up a little bit lopsided because their right-back, Denzel Dumfries, pushes so high up the pitch as often as he can.\n\nSteven Bergwijn, who has started on that side in the past couple of games, has been drifting in to get close to Memphis Depay and Xavi Simons, who has really impressed me in the number 10 role.\n\nThey will obviously pose a threat with the way they link up but, on the flip side, when Dumfries flies forward it is going to leave some space for England to break into once there is a turnover in possession.\n\nThat could leave Stefan de Vrij a little bit isolated and, although he is a very experienced defender, he is not as quick as Virgil van Dijk or Micky van de Ven. There should be some chances to expose him.\n\nThe other area where I think England can get some joy in Dortmund is in central midfield.\n\nEngland have got a lot of players who like to pop up in the pockets in front of the opposition defence - Jude Bellingham and Phil Foden, for example - no matter which system we use.\n\nThe Dutch are without Frenkie de Jong, Teun Koopmeiners and Marten de Roon at these Euros because of injury, so are missing some top quality in those positions.\n\nJerdy Schouten and Tijjani Reijnders, who play in the middle for the Dutch, are both really elegant technical footballers, but they like to have the ball and I would not describe them as defensive-minded.\n\nThey fill in holes and do the job when their team is out of possession but they are not the same type of player as Declan Rice, and it is not their strong point.\n\nIn front of them, Simons tends to get forward, so there should be plenty of opportunities to get in and around Schouten and Reijnders, and get at the Dutch defence.\n\nThere has been a bit of talk that Koeman might change his formation against England and match up to Southgate's side by playing three at the back.\n\nThe way the Dutch have been playing, however, they kind of end up as a three anyway, with Dumfries going so high so early in such an unusual way.\n\nWhen that happens, Nathan Ake tucks in and then they have got him, Van Dijk and De Vrij as a three, and their system actually ends up looking a lot like the one England used against Switzerland anyway.\n\nCody Gakpo is a left-winger rather than a left wing-back but he gives them width on that side, like Bukayo Saka did on the right for England against the Swiss because we did not have the same threat on the other side of the pitch.\n\nBoth formations are a little unbalanced in that way, with players on each flank asked to do different jobs, and what tends to happen in that scenario is the team which has the better possession highlights the other's weaknesses more quickly.\n\nI am expecting a similar pattern to unfold this time. One team will take control - probably England if they maintain the same possession levels as in previous matches - and the other will have to adapt to that.\n\nAs I said at the start, what I really like about the Netherlands is that when things are not working, Koeman is not afraid to change it.\n\nFor example, in the Austria game, he brought Simons on for Joey Veermans after 35 minutes and ended up pushing Lutsharel Geertruida, who was playing at right-back instead of Dumfries, into an inverted midfield role that transformed the momentum of the game, even though they ended losing it late on.\n\nAt half-time against Turkey, when the Dutch were trailing 1-0, he basically went from a 4-3-3 to a 4-4-2 formation and put Wout Weghorst up front with Depay. This time, they were the winners.\n\nSo, however the Dutch are set up at the start of the game, you can be sure they will give England some different problems depending on what happens during it.\n\nHopefully England won't go behind and won't have to be reactive like that, but there is still likely to be a time in the game when they need to make changes too.\n\nThat was definitely the case against Switzerland when, even before the Swiss took the lead, it felt like Southgate needed to freshen things up.\n\nThis time, Koeman won't wait... and neither should he.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8217190897", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "15:02:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T15:02:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T15:02:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/au/football/news/england-netherlands-head-head-record-history-results/fc7595a5cd29adcc1275ad81", "title": "England vs. Netherlands head to head record, history, results, past games ahead of Euro 2024 semifinal", "body": "England take on the Netherlands in the semifinals of Euro 2024 with the Three Lions still aiming for a first title since 1966.\n\nGareth Southgate's team have battled through to the final four following a quarterfinal penalty shootout win over Switzerland in the previous round.\n\nThe Netherlands have improved as the tournament has progressed, after a mixed showing in the group stages, and they rallied to knock out Turkey in the quarters.\n\nA showdown in Dortmund is a huge clash for both sides and historical meetings between the two teams has thrown up some superb battles.\n\nMORE: Euro 2024 schedule and results, updated LIVE | Who will win Euro 2024? Latest odds and predictions | How to watch all the Euro 2024 action\n\nEngland and the Netherlands have faced each other 22 times since their first meeting 1935. That has included two meetings in the UEFA European Championships and once in the FIFA World Cup.\n\nThe overall record stands at six wins for England, compared to seven for the Netherlands, with nine draws.\n\nFollowing eight friendly meetings, in which England won four times, the first competitive clash came at Euro '88. Dutch icon Marco van Basten netted a superb hat-trick to secure 3-1 win in Dusseldorf.\n\nEngland were knocked out in the group stages as La Oranje went on to win the final against the Soviet Union and Van Basten netted one of the finest goals the competition has ever seen.\n\nThey met again in the group stages of the 1990 World Cup in Italy, and could not be split in a 0-0 draw, as England lost out to eventual champions West Germany in the semifinals.\n\nThe Dutch then ended England's chance of qualifying for the 1994 World Cup before the Three Lions secured some revenge as hosts of Euro '96.\n\nTwo goals each from Alan Shearer and Teddy Sheringham propelled England out of the group stages before again losing out on penalties to Germany in a semifinal.\n\nSince 1996, England have won just once in nine meetings with the Netherlands, including a 3-1 defeat in the 2019 UEFA Nations League semifinals\n\nUSA: England vs. Netherlands will be televised in the United States on FOX, while Spanish TV broadcasts are provided by Univision and TUDN. These channels are all available to stream on Fubo, who are offering a FREE seven-day trial. ViX is also an option for Spanish viewers.\n\nRadio coverage of the match can be followed on SiriusXM FC.\n\nUK: Wednesday's match will be shown in the UK on ITV 1 / STV Scotland and fans can stream on ITVX / STV Player.\n\nCanada: TSN are the main English-language broadcasters for Euro 2024 while TVA provides French options.\n\nAustralia: Australia's sole broadcaster for the European Championship is Optus Sport.\n\nIndia: Euro 2024 matches are available to watch on JioTV and Sony LIV. England vs. Netherlands can also be viewed on Sony Ten Network on TV.\n\nIf this match is not available to watch live in your location, or if you're traveling abroad, you can use a Virtual Private Network (VPN). The English side finished first in their Group but had won only one game (1-0 vs Slovakia) whilst drawing against Slovenia and Denmark. They then went on to face Slovakia in the Round of 16 and were almost knocked out of the tournament if it was not for a bicycle kick by Jude Bellingham in the 95th minute of the game that revived the English side as they went on to win 2-1 in extra time. Germany Referee Felix Zwayer Once Linked To Match-Fixing Will Oversee England's UEFA Euro 2024 Semifinal Match Against Netherlands.\n\nThey then faced a strong Switzerland side and found themselves trailing by a goal heading into the final ten minutes. Now we want to deliver one more thing - we have never been to a final outside England, never won a Euros, so there are two bits of history we would love to create,\" said Southgate to BBC five.\n\nNetherlands on the other hand have won only one major tournament in the country's history (1988 Euros) and find themselves with an opportunity to recreate history. The Dutch side, like their opposition have not been at their strongest through the campaign. A dismal outing in the Group Stages saw them qualify after finishing third in their group behind Austria and France.\n\nAlthough a strong outing in the Round of 16 saw them defeat Romania (3-0) with comfort, they struggled heavily against Turkey in the quarterfinal and trailed for a majority of the game before scoring two late goals to secure a 2-1 victory. many people's dark horses at the tournament - took the lead 10 minutes before half-time, but two goals in quick succession in the final 20 minutes turned the game in the Netherlands' favour.\n\nAfter scraping through into the knockout stages as one of the best third-place finishers in the group stage, Ronald Koeman's side beat Romania 3-0 before then seeing off Turkey.\n\nVan Dijk and the Netherlands will now meet England in the semi-finals on Wednesday, and the Liverpool star was shocked when he was told that the Three Lions are the favourites to win the whole tournament.\n\nSpeaking ahead of the Monaco Grand Prix in May, Sky Sports F1 correspondent Craig Slater relayed the news to the Reds star, who seemed surprised.\n\nAfter being told that England are the favourites, the star defender replied: \"Are they?!\"\n\nThe 32-year-old, however, admits England have a strong squad as he also mentioned France.\n\n\"England has a very, very good team and squad,\" he added. \"France is very strong.\"\n\nEngland booked their place in the semi-finals with a penalty shootout victory against Switzerland on Saturday.\n\nGareth Southgate's side have failed to impress in Germany, but they have showed impressive resilience and mental strength by pulling off a late comeback win against Slovakia before scoring all five of their penalties against the Swiss.\n\nEngland's last Euros campaign was ended in the final in 2021, when they lost to Italy on penalties.\n\nAsked if his side are capable of going one step further, Gareth Southgate replied: \"I'd be an idiot if I said no, but if I said yes, that doesn't mean there's not a lot of work ahead of us.\n\n\"There's no doubt what is possible. The team has been close already. They know what is possible, they know what they've won at club level and what that's taken.\n\n\"And equally, you can see cup football, which we're going into, we know you have to navigate game by game and qualify from the group.\n\n\"But in knockout football, the Champions League showed that Man City and Arsenal were in the best three teams this year and didn't get to where they wanted to, as it's one moment and fine margins.\n\n\"That is our world. {"uri": "8216791061", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "11:01:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T11:01:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T11:00:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/euro-2024-england-france-face-105247707.html", "title": "Euro 2024: England and France face moment of truth in the fight of style vs substance", "body": "England had won on penalties to reach a third semi-final in four tournaments, but if Gareth Southgate was expecting an easy ride in the press conference room after Saturday's meeting with Switzerland, he was mistaken.\n\n\"Is there any thought of entertainment for the neutrals when you plan games?\" the England manager was asked by a foreign journalist.\n\nAnother reporter from Germany then put it to Southgate that England had faced only middling opposition and would his team, perhaps, play \"better football\" against stronger opponents? Southgate was not going to let anything spoil his mood, and he responded to both questions with his usual thoughtfulness and tact.\n\nIf it was not already clear, though, England do not go into Wednesday's semi-final here as the neutrals' choice.\n\nSouthgate's side have ground their way to this stage, providing little in the way of entertainment -- spectacular goals from Jude Bellingham and Bukayo Saka aside.\n\nFrance, who face Spain in Tuesday's other semi-final, have been equally dull, more able to create openings than England, but even less capable of finishing one; a French player is still yet to score from open play.\n\nThis commitment to functional football is part of the story of the two semi-finals. On one side, you have Spain and Holland, the two nations who have done more to champion style and entertainment in the modern era than any others. On the other, there is France and England, both successful tournament teams run by arch pragmatists, for whom the result trumps the need to put on a show.\n\nThe question tonight is whether France's experience and defensive nous will prove too much for a vibrant but youthful Spain side, who have been the easiest on the eye at the tournament.\n\nEngland are unlikely to face a Dutch side playing Cruyffian 'total football' -- in fact, they are expected to counter-punch -- but it still feels like a contest between style and substance, one team which never loses sight of the need to entertain versus a side for whom winning is everything.\n\n\"Whether you play good or bad football, the most important thing is winning games,\" said Luke Shaw yesterday, neatly summing up England's mentality.\n\n\"And at the moment, we're doing that. Whether people like or not how the team are playing, we're in the semi-finals. For us, that's all that matters.\"\n\nFor Southgate's disciples, the end justifies the means, and the parallels with France are no coincidence. The England manager has studied his French counterpart Didier Deschamps, and believes his approach is the best way to deliver at major tournaments.\n\nMinimise risk, keep it tight, rely on moments of brilliance from big players. There is every reason to think their approach is justified; Deschamps' France won the World Cup in 2018, in between losing the finals of Euro 2016 and Qatar 2022, while England have enjoyed unprecedented success under Southgate without yet getting over the line.\n\nLow-risk teams, built on defence, tend to win tournaments, and even the celebrated Spain side won every knockout game 1-0 at the 2010 World Cup.\n\nIn responding to the barbed lines of questioning on Saturday, Southgate pointed out that \"these are not normal football matches\" but \"national events\" which come with enormous pressure for his young players.\n\nThere is, however, also a degree of risk in the manager's reluctance to play to the strengths of his top-heavy squad. When winning is all that matters, winning is all there is.\n\nPlaying safe arguably raises the stakes further, because if England fall short this week, what is left behind?\n\nWhile Deschamps has already achieved immortality, Southgate's legacy will be altogether more complicated if England do not go all the way in Germany; for all their progress, there will be a sense they could have done even more with an attacking approach.\n\nAs English, perhaps we should accept that \"national events\" come with a degree of boredom -- royal weddings spring to mind -- and what does it matter if the end result if positive?\n\nThat is Southgate's calculation, even as the neutrals long for a Spain-Holland final.", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports {"uri": "8217444387", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:10:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:10:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:09:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.101greatgoals.com/news/euro-2024-england-v-netherlands-kane-van-dijk-saka-gakpo-and-the-key-battles-to-watch-in-semi-final/", "title": "Euro 2024: England v Netherlands - Kane, Van Dijk, Saka, Gakpo and the key battles to watch in semi-final", "body": "Lebouef slams 'boring' England and France and hopes for a Spain v Netherlands final at Euro 2024\n\nAfter reaching just one semi-final in the first 56 years of the European Championships, England are potentially one game away from reaching back-to-back continental finals.\n\nThe Netherlands stand in the way of a date against Spain or France in the Euro 2024 final in Berlin's Olympiastadion on Sunday night.\n\nCurrent boss Ronald Koeman starred as the Netherlands won Euro 88 - which was also held in Germany - and scored the equaliser as Oranje came from behind to beat the host nation 2-1 in the semi-final. It was the only success in their five previous Euro semi-finals.\n\nThe omens are less good on the English side as Gareth Southgate's most telling contribution to the semi-final of Euro 96 was missing a penalty in England's semi-final shootout defeat to Germany.\n\nThe sides will do battle in Dortmund's Westfalenstadion on Wednesday at 8pm BST with England seeking to win a semi-final at a major tournament on foreign soil for the first time.\n\nLet's take a closer look at five key battles which we feel could decide the last-four match, shall we?\n\nThis looks like it could be the key match-up in the middle of the park.\n\nFrenkie De Jong was a big miss for the Netherlands after failing to recover from an ankle injury sustained in March but his play-making responsibility for the Dutch has fallen to 21-year-old Xavi Simons, playing slightly advanced of Jerdy Schouten and AC Milan's Tijani Reijnders, who has been particularly impressive so far in the Oranje campaign.\n\nSimons has assisted three goals already, putting him level with Spain starlet Lamine Yamal at the top of the tournament standings, and his ability to drift into space and drive forward on the counter attack mean Rice is going to need to keep his eyes on him.\n\nRice has covered more ground than any other player at Euro 2024, clocking an eye-watering 39.8 miles across England's five games so far.\n\nThis has been helped of course by the fact that he has played extra-time in his last two matches, whereas the Dutch players are relatively fresh having seen-off Romania in the Round of 16 and then Turkey in the last-eight in 90 minutes.\n\nEngland fans will hope he's made the most of his three-day recovery period and is ready to go again in Dortmund, a stadium where Simons inspired Leipzig to a 3-2 win in the Bundesliga last December, picking up an assist.\n\nThe Yellow Wall will become orange for the night, and Simons will hope for a repeat outcome.\n\nThe Netherlands might not play the attractive total football of their predecessors, but they have made their functional style work for them.\n\nOnly Spain and Germany have scored more than their nine goals in the tournament so far - by contrast England have scored just five.\n\nCody Gakpo is the favourite to land the Golden Boot at the competition - he is joint top of the standings with three goals but temporarily thought he had four before the Dutch winner against Turkey went down as an own-goal by Mert Muldur.\n\nJust as he did in his successful spell at PSV, Gakpo has enjoyed service from the right flank from marauding full-back Denzel Dumfries.\n\nThe Liverpool forward operates from the left for the Dutch which means the responsibility for looking after him falls to Kyle Walker.\n\nFor whatever reason, off-field distraction, different system, you name it, Walker has failed to hit the heights he did with Man City in the five games England have played so far. There have been highly unusual lapses in concentration which have seen him gift possession to the opposition and lose his man more than once. England fans will hope this is back to the norm for Walker as anything less than that could prove problematic against in-form Gakpo.\n\nMan City and Arsenal's Premier League rivalry resumes on the biggest stage.\n\nWhile he tends to operate in the left-sided centre-back role for Pep Guardiola, Nathan Ake is used as a left-back by Ronald Koeman, which should put him in direct opposition to... Bukayo Saka.\n\nFor the Netherlands Ake tends to sit back at left-back and slot in when Denzel Dumfries on the opposite flank makes his trademark roams up the field from right-back.\n\nThis might work to the Netherland's advantage, given Saka's obvious danger, meaning Ake is less likely to be caught out of position. However it does raise the possibility of an overload on the right with Saka and Ake's Man City teammate Kyle Walker bombing on.\n\nSaka missed the home game against Man City in the league this year and was subbed early in the return at the Etihad, which ended goalless. England fans will be hoping he finds more joy in Dortmund.\n\nThe absence of Frenkie De Jong has also hurt Memphis Depay. De Jong was the one who pulled the strings in most of the Dutch attacks and threaded passes through the deep lying defences which have been a feature of at this tournament.\n\nDepay has not been particularly effective leading the line as a central striker, scoring only once in the 3-2 defeat to Austria, and there is a growing clamour for Wout Weghorst to be given the nod through the middle from the start, having scored the winner in the opening group game against Poland and then changing the game after coming off the bench in the quarter-final against Turkey.\n\nIf that happens then expect Memphis to slide right. If it does not then he will have to try to find his way past John Stones, his old cross-Manchester rival.\n\nStones did make a rare costly slip which allowed Switzerland to pinch an opener in the last round, but he will know the dangers of Depay only too well and would possibly prefer facing him than the battering ram which is another former Man United man, Weghorst.\n\nOn paper, we're saving the best for last. But if we are honest, these two have failed to hit the heights they are capable of so far in Germany this summer. Is this the match in which they both spring to life?\n\nVan Dijk's partnership with Stefan De Vrij in the heart of defence is so enduring that Micky van de Ven of Tottenham and Man United target Matthijs de Ligt can't get in the team.\n\nDefence is definitely the Dutch's strongest area these days, but Van Dijk in particular has shown signs of being fallible, particularly in the 3-2 group stage defeat to Austria and spells of the Turkey quarter-final.\n\nThe thought of a country leaving out their captain and record goalscorer in a semi-final is so far-fetched it's almost laughable, however there is a huge section of the England faithful who think Harry Kane should be dropped for this last-four tie.\n\nWhether he is carrying a lingering injury, or whether a season in Germany has dulled the sharpness and fitness built up over a decade in the Premier League, we may never know, but although he has scored a couple of handy goals, he has contributed very little across the five games and, if anything, has made things harder for his teammates by dropping deep and leaving no focal point up top.\n\nIvan Toney caught the eye in cameos against Slovakia and Switzerland but, much like with Cristiano Ronaldo and Portugal, there is simply no way Kane won't be lining up in Dortmund before kick-off.", "source": {"uri": "101greatgoals.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8219049595", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:15:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:15:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:15:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.news9live.com/sports/football/uefa-euro-2024-key-talking-points-ahead-of-netherlands-vs-england-semi-finals-2611970", "title": "UEFA Euro 2024: Key talking points ahead of Netherlands vs England semi-finals", "body": "New Delhi: Netherlands will face England in the semi-final of UEFA Euro 2024. Netherlands are chasing their second European Championship title while England were runners up of the previous edition.\n\nNetherlands started their tournament with a 2-1 win over Poland, a draw with France, and a 3-2 loss to Austria. The Oranje entered the knockout stage with inconsistent performances. However, they showed character in both their elimination stage games.\n\nGiven that Romania were considerably inexperienced in this tournament, the Dutch side took advantage of this and ended the night with a 3-0 win. Progressing to the quarter-finals, Netherlands next opponent were the highly spirited Turkey. In the half-time, the game favoured Turkey as they headed in the break 1-0. Netherland needed a comeback and it came in the 70th minute with Stefan de Vrij scoring the levelling goal followed by an own goal from Turkey with Cody Gapko charging into the nets.\n\nEngland on the other hand are yet to hit the intensity level expected of a team playing in the elimination. Throughout the tournament they haven't performed well despite having star players in their side and won once in the group stage and drawing twice. Until the round of 16, the team had a total of four goals with Harry Kane and Jude Bellingham scoring two each.\n\nAgainst Slovenia in the knockout 16 stage, England won the game only in the extra time thanks to Bellingham and Kane both firing quick goals. In the quarter-final, the game remained goalless till the 75th minute when Breel Embolo scored for Switzerland. In the 80th minute, Bukayo Saka helped England with a levelling goal. The match went into the extra time and was finally decided with spot kicking which England won 5-3.\n\nEngland's attackers have been appalling in many senses. They have scored only five goals in this entire tournament. The likes of Bellingham, Kane and Phil Foden haven't been in the impressive form they had been during their club games. A lot of expectation was on Bellingham who was the joint third-highest goal scorer with 19 goals in La Liga season 2023-24. Though the midfielder has scored twice, it hasn't been at the flair expected from him. His captain, too, has scored twice in this tournament. Kane had helped Bayern Munich go undefeated this season, scoring 36 goals from 32 appearances.\n\nBukayo Saka had scored 16 times this season for Arsenal in the Premier League but, so far in the tournament, has only one goal. Phil Foden had a good season with 19 goals in the Premier League for Manchester United but, so far, hasn't made any impact in this tournament. The Three Lions also have the second lowest chances created in this tournament. What England does need to address now is their low-scoring and tactical challenges. Their star players must attack the opposite goalpost more in the remaining two games.\n\nWhile England's attack isn't solid, they have been one of the best sides in this tournament in terms of their defence line. While they have conceded only thrice, the Dutch side is much more susceptible to attacks on their goalpost.\n\nAs soon as they are in possession, Netherlands back-four converts to a three-man defence, with Ake moving forward. This means there's an extra player in their attack but that also means their defense is under pressure. The backline often presses high in order to cross the halfway line and apply pressure on the opposition. They have to ensure that they are not so vulnerable during counter attacks.\n\nThe two sides first met in 1935 in Olympisch Stadion, Amsterdam where England won 1-0 and have since played each other 22 times. Through the years thewse two sides have met each other at crucial stages.", "source": {"uri": "news9live.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News9live"}, "authors": [{"uri":
