{"uri": "2024-07-416072560", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "10:26:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T10:26:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T10:03:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://internewscast.com/?p=3084448", "title": "Jamie Carragher talks about how England's disappointing performance at Euro 2024 is similar to Greece's unexpected success in 2004, stating that England is very fortunate and exceeding expectations. - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Jamie Carragher has branded England 'extremely lucky' to have qualified for the semi-finals of Euro 2024, while claiming, if the Three Lions win the tournament, it will be akin to Greece's Euro victory back in 2004.\n\nGareth Southgate's side have come under fire for their performances in Germany, with many questioning the manager's squad selections and his side's struggles to create and finish off chances.\n\nBut amid their underwhelming form, the Three Lions have still managed to reach the semi-finals of the competition after they beat Switzerland on penalties in Dusseldorf on Saturday.\n\nWhile England have stepped up when it has mattered most, former Liverpool and England star, Carragher, has claimed that should the Three Lions go on and win Euro 2024, they will not be remembered as one of the great champions of the tournament.\n\n'Some great teams have made their mark on the history of the European Championship. Regardless of whether they deliver the ultimate success from this point on, this England side will not be remembered as one of them,' Carragher wrote in a column in The Telegraph.\n\n'When you think of the elite-level winners, France in 2000 or Spain in 2008 and 2012 are still fresh in my memory.\n\n'If England go all the way, they will not be taking their place in such esteemed company. What we will have witnessed will be comparable to the victories of Greece in 2004 and Portugal in 2016, when a series of underwhelming displays led to improbable success.'\n\nGreece, seemingly bumbled their way through to the finals at Euro 2004, scoring only three goals across all three of their knockout fixtures, beating France 1-0, Czech Republic 1-0 and claiming a 1-0 win against Portugal in the final.\n\nPortugal, meanwhile, would finish third in their group, with Hungary and Iceland qualifying for the last 16 as the top two sides in the group. The Selecao, similar to Greece, would go on to score just four goals in each of their four knockout matches, notably also beating Poland on penalties in the quarter-finals.\n\n'As was the case with the Portuguese eight years ago, England are defying football logic to still be in the conversation. It is highly unusual for a strong nation to play so consistently poorly in a major tournament and reach the semi-final,' Carragher added.\n\n'We can't escape reality. We cannot dress it up any other way. England have been extremely lucky, first against Slovakia and now Switzerland. They are through to the last four despite performances, rather than because of them.'\n\nYet, some have lauded Southgate for his epic record as England boss, having transformed England's fortunes in recent years.\n\nBut Southgate leads the way having won more major tournament knockout games, seven, compared to any other England manager since 1966 combined.\n\nCarragher's Sky Sports colleague, Gary Neville, lumped praise on the Three Lions boss during ITV Football's live broadcast of Netherlands vs Turkey.\n\n'Southgate's record is absolutely brilliant and when you think about where we were before we came in. When you think about the reception he got when he got the job - I have to say He's the Englishman who knows more about tournament football than anyone in English football history,' Neville said.\n\n'He knows about youth tournaments playing in tournaments and managing tournaments. He knows the good the bad and the ugly.\n\n'We've challenged him to make changes in every game, he makes one change in every game and he's proven himself right. He's got more experience than all of us.'\n\nSouthgate, meanwhile, heaped praise on his side's character and resilience to come up trumps on penalties against Switzerland.\n\nDuring his post-match press conference, the England boss said: 'If I can't enjoy that moment, then the whole thing is a waste of time. I took this job to help. I can't deny when it's as personal as it's been in recent weeks...\n\n'But we're still fighting.\n\n'We showed unbelievable qualities of character and resilience. You have to find ways to win and dealing with everything around them.\n\n'To twice come from behind and and to have that composure was impeccable.'", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": While he didn't get the score correct - backing a 1-0 win rather than the penalty shoot-out victory which transpired - it capped a four-out-of-four return in his quarter-final predictions.\n\nHe got two of the other three results spot on, backing 2-1 wins for Spain against Germany and the Netherlands against Turkey, while expecting France to be more comfortable against Portugal than their eventual shoot-out win. If he gets things right again for the semis, we'll be looking at an England vs France final.\n\n\"I don't think anything is going to drastically change in the way England play - they are not going to suddenly find some amazing patterns of play that break the Netherlands down,\" Sutton wrote in his BBC column. \"Instead, if England are going to reach their second successive Euros final, they are going to have to rely on individual brilliance again.\n\n\"I have not just been blindly backing them to get through each knockout round in Germany but they are definitely on the more gentle side of the draw. These channels are all available to stream on Fubo, who are offering a FREE seven-day trial. ViX is also an option for Spanish viewers.\n\nRadio coverage of the match can be followed on SiriusXM FC.\n\nUK: Wednesday's match will be shown in the UK on ITV 1 / STV Scotland and fans can stream on ITVX / STV Player.\n\nCanada: TSN are the main English-language broadcasters for Euro 2024 while TVA provides French options.\n\nAustralia: Australia's sole broadcaster for the European Championship is Optus Sport.\n\nIndia: Euro 2024 matches are available to watch on JioTV and Sony LIV. England vs. Netherlands can also be viewed on Sony Ten Network on TV.\n\nIf this match is not available to watch live in your location, or if you're traveling abroad, you can use a Virtual Private Network (VPN). VPNs offer a secure and private online connection, allowing you to bypass geographical restrictions to access your favorite streaming services from any device anywhere in the world.\n\nWATCH FROM ANYWHERE: Sign up for NordVPN (30-day moneyback guarantee)\n\nThis Euro 2024 semifinal kicks off from the Signal Iduna Park on Wednesday, July 10 at 9 p.m. local time in Dortmund, Germany.\n\nHere's how that time translates across some of the major territories around the globe:\n\nEngland's much-discussed switch to a three-man defence for the Switzerland game hardly proved to be a significant change from previous lacklustre displays, but Luke Shaw made his long-awaited return from injury as he came on in the second half of the quarterfinal, so he will likely be in serious contention to replace right-footed Kieran Trippier here to provide proper balance on the left side.\n\nHarry Kane was forced off in extra time with an injury picked up during the game, but it seems like he will recover in time to keep his place in the starting XI for this one, despite calls for the captain to be dropped following some anonymous centre-forward displays.\n\nThe Three Lions will also welcome back Marc Guehi from his one-game ban, and he should start alongside mainstay John Stones even though Ezri Konsa performed admirably in his absence last time out. Konsa could keep his spot should Southgate persist with a back three, though.\n\nKobbie Mainoo has enjoyed a positive summer over in Germany and the 19-year-old Manchester United midfield sensation will continue to partner Declan Rice in the engine room.\n\nEngland predicted lineup (4-2-3-1): Pickford (GK) -- Walker, Stones, Guehi, Shaw -- Mainoo, Rice -- Saka, Bellingham, Foden -- Kane.\n\nNetherlands boss Ronald Koeman stuck with the same starting lineup for both of his side's knockout games so far, but there could be one change in the offing in Dortmund.\n\nSteven Bergwijn has been unimpressive on the right wing and his place is under threat from Donyell Malen, who bagged a quick-fire brace in the Round of 16 against Romania. Jeremie Frimpong, who typically plays right-back for Bayer Leverkusen, is another possible option.\n\nWith RB Leipzig's playmaking sensation Xavi Simons sitting behind Memphis Depay and Liverpool's Cody Gakpo posing a serious danger on the left wing, notching three goals in his five Euro 2024 outings and leading the Golden Boot race, the Dutch have deployed a pretty fluid 4-2-3-1 formation. Super-sub Wout Weghorst would be the go-to option off the bench.\n\nExperienced Inter Milan star Stefan de Vrij will again support captain Virgil van Dijk at the heart of Koeman's defence. Nathan Ake is expected to stay at left-back ahead of Tottenham's Micky van de Ven, while Denzel Dumfries offers a bombarding option on the opposite flank.\n\nNetherlands predicted lineup (4-3-3): Verbruggen (GK) -- Dumfries, De Vrij, Van Dijk, Ake -- Schouten, Simons, Reijnders -- Malen, Depay, Gakpo.\n\nThe Three Lions undeniably boasts more talent and experience in these high-profile games. Southgate emphasized this fact following the victory over Switzerland, and it's a factor that should heavily influence the outcome here.\n\nDespite their impressive defensive work, England have struggled to decisively finish off their chances, while their vulnerability to counter-attacks becomes evident whenever they take offensive risks.\n\nThe Dutch, however, are not without their own flaws. Their defense can be sluggish and cumbersome, and they've often lacked midfield dominance and a clinical edge in attack. Nevertheless, they pose a threat with their ability to deliver dangerous crosses, execute quick interchanges on the ground, and unleash powerful shots from distance.\n\nThis clash is shaping up to be a tight contest that could very well go the distance. Almost as boring as POR-FRA, which is really astonishing with all the quality in these teams, to produce such boring games. Though to be fair, Portugal were a man down from the first whistle.\n\nSpain vs Germany was the only other quarter final that had me invested and amused.\n\nPrediction time, if England get their act together and start to believe in themselves and play some actual free flowing football they should probably come out on top against a somewhat toothless Netherlands. We have the quality and will come out of the gates roaring like we did against Turkey, so withstand that initial onslaught and your experience of semi-finals might pull you to the final.\n\nHowever, if you make it there, you have no shot against Spain, who are better at our game then we are.. or the Master vs Apprentice battle that France will offer by being even more boring and have even more quality in their team.\n\nBring on Wednesday!\n\nStijn (wonder who the ref will be) Amsterdam\n\nMORE ON ENGLAND FROM F365:\n\n\ud83d\udc49 16 Conclusions on England beating Switzerland: drop Foden and Kane, Southgate subs, Saka phenomenal\n\n\ud83d\udc49 Harry Kane is an England 'passenger'; Gareth Southgate should 'crash tackle' him again\n\n\ud83d\udc49 Gareth Southgate 'state of statis' is weird way to 'get behind' England manager\n\nPROS\n\nOnly one player playing slightly out of position (Palmer) but he can handle it.\n\nFour ace penalty takers on the pitch from the kickoff.\n\nNo misfiring Trippier, Walker, Gallagher, Foden, or Kane!\n\nCONS\n\nI really wanted to get Eze into the team, but there's no room, so he'll have to settle for super sub.\n\nI don't pick the team. Southgate does.\n\nBad Hamster (forgive me, I've just had a brainectomy), Manila\n\n...Having seen England limp to another unconvincing result via multiple different formations thrown out there in desperation, Southgate would do well to try a diamond 4-4-2 and go for it against the Dutch.\n\nGK: Pickford\n\nDEF: Trent-Guehi-Konza-Shaw\n\nDM: Stones\n\nCM: Rice-Mainoo\n\nAM: Bellingham\n\nFW: Saka-Palmer\n\nTrent has to start on the right as Walker has been a liability from matchday 1. Guehi and Konza in the middle, as they've both proven they belong on the big stage. A now fit Shaw has to start as Trippier has been less than useless as an outlet on the left. If Shaw can't last the game, then surely give Gomez a chance off the bench, otherwise what was the point of bringing him.\n\nStones has played DM for City as much as he has in defense, plus it would make much better use of his passing range. When the fullbacks bomb forward, he can slot back in to create a solid back 3. Plus it frees up Rice to move further up the pitch, where he's played his best for Arsenal.\n\nRice and Mainoo in the middle, as they're both much more adept at carrying the ball forward and creating something for the attackers.\n\nBellingham at the tip of the diamond, where he's excelled all season long for Madrid. With no Foden or Kane (both truly disappointing so far) crowding into his zone, expect him to get involved and make things happen much more frequently.\n\nUp top, Saka and Palmer as wide forwards with license to roam and switch sides. With them (+Jude) England would have plenty of pace and guile to terrorize the opposition defense, rather than a lumbering, static and seemingly not 100% fit Kane.\n\nOf course, we can fully expect Southgate to start a 5-4-1 formation next and play for penalties.\n\nSanjit (Spain will still win it though) Randhawa, Kuala Lumpur\n\nGareth Southgate makes England suck less\n\nEnglish expectations are out of balance with their team. When we drew with Slovakia they were ecstatic, we were morose.\n\nIf we were to fully realise how poor we are at the Euros maybe we'd be happier with the team and what Southgate is doing.\n\nHere's the finals results of the other 'big 5' leagues in Europe, or those with the biggest population to draw from:\n\nTeam 1st 2nd Total\n\n-- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- --\n\nGER 3 3 6\n\nSPA 3 1 4\n\nITA 2 2 4\n\nFRA 2 1 3\n\nENG 0 1 1\n\nUntil Southgate came along there was a big fat zero in the total column for England. It took us 60 years to get to the final.\n\nWe clearly suck at the Euros.\n\nWe should not expect to win it, we should be happy to make the quarters.\n\nEngland are basically PSG in the Champions league. Got to the final once, semi-final a few times and spent a fortune getting that.\n\nFanmail for Johnny\n\nI see John Nic is on another contrarian rant today. Apparently, we're all wrong to expect England to play better than the absolute dross we've currently been served up. Indeed, we're wrong to believe that players who have demonstrated their ability vs their peers at the upper levels of the club game to be able to do it in a different context.\n\nAnd critically, we're wrong to be frustrated that Southgate continues to be timid in his selections and changes and should just \"shut up\" as we've never had it so good.\n\nFirst off then, the players. We know they can play well, we've seen each player doing better and against stronger teams, but it's fair to acknowledge that they do this generally in different positions to the ones they're being put in. One of the few players who is in his normal position is Saka, and coincidentally he's our best performer so far. Mainoo has slotted in, in his preferred position and is doing well too.\n\nThree of the defence are playing in theirs and the two centre-backs at least have generally been good. The rest are not really playing where or how they usually do, certainly in terms of what the players around them are doing. The answer is likely as I've always said: don't pick try to pick all your best/favourite players, pick the ones that make the best team.\n\nOn to the manager, is it not ok to be frustrated that a manager blessed with an array of attacking talent that mostly matches the best in the tournament refuses to use it? We should just accept it, meekly and quietly and just be delighted that we're somehow squeezing through against weaker teams.\n\nTo be clear, it isn't a surprise. This is how Southgate operates. God forbid that anyone dare complain. I mean, no one mentions Brexit any more, do they John? And yes, fortune has given him the best record. So we should just sit on the sidelines, and pour on our adulation even as our eyes bleed. If you dare to show dissent, you must be \"hard of thinking\" and be pilloried. A desire to see our team actually play nice football is just a \"precious sense of aesthetics\". Maybe we should all be more like that horse Boxer, eh John?\n\nI'll say it once again: we don't watch football matches for the result, we watch it because of the reasons that make it the \"beautiful game\". It sounds like you've drunk the Kool Aid, John. My, how things have changed. No more raging against the machine, we should instead worship it.\n\nBadwolf\n\n...Any chance Johnny N would think Southgate was rubbish if his team played exactly like they have been playing, got the same results, but Gareth voted Reform and thought Brexit was the best decision ever?\n\nJust wondering.\n\nG Thomas, Breda, The Netherlands (Hup Holland Hup)\n\nMORE ON ENGLAND FROM F365:\n\n\ud83d\udc49 16 Conclusions on England beating Switzerland: drop Foden and Kane, Southgate subs, Saka phenomenal\n\n\ud83d\udc49 Harry Kane is an England 'passenger'; Gareth Southgate should 'crash tackle' him again\n\n\ud83d\udc49 Gareth Southgate 'state of statis' is weird way to 'get behind' England manager\n\nNot a fan of Lineker\n\nSpeak for yourself when saying we all listen to Lineker.\n\nHe's only become a hippie since he split up with his wife. {"uri": "8219161401", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:41:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:41:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:40:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.fourfourtwo.com/news/euro-2024-who-is-the-referee-and-var-for-england-vs-netherlands", "title": "Euro 2024: Who is the referee and VAR for England vs Netherlands?", "body": "England are bidding to reach a second consecutive European Championship final - but who will be officiating the action?\n\nGareth Southgate's England side are 90 minutes away from a second consecutive European Championship final as they undergo their final preparations to face the Netherlands in Dortmund this evening.\n\nSpain await the winners of tonight's clash in Sunday's Euro 2024 final following their exciting 2-1 win over France last night. England have needed an extra-time win over Slovakia and a penalty shootout victory over Switzerland to get this far, while Ronald Koeman's Netherlands side have seen off Romania and Turkey in the knockout stages.\n\nIt promises to be a tense affair, while the refereeing appointment for this match has been a controversial one. FourFourTwo take a look...\n\nVIDEO Why Cody Gakpo's A Huge Problem For England\n\nThis has perhaps been the most controversial refereeing appointment of the tournament, with UEFA handing the job to German official Felix Zwayer. The 42-year-old has plenty of big-match experience, not least the 2023 UEFA Nations League Final between Croatia and Spain, but his appointment has seen his role in a 2005 match-fixing scandal which saw him banned for six months in 2006 come back into the spotlight.\n\nThat's largely because England midfielder Jude Bellingham was fined \u20ac40,000 back in 2021 for describing him as \"a referee that has match-fixed before\" following a clash between Borussia Dortmund and Bayern Munich in 2021 that saw Bayern awarded a controversial penalty.\n\nZwayer refereed Italy versus Albania and Turkey versus Portugal in the group stage at Euro 2024, plus the Netherlands' 3-0 last-16 win over Romania and will be joined by assistants Stefan Lupp and Marco Achm\u00fcller.\n\nThis all-German officiating crew will see Daniel Siebert as the fourth official, with the 39-year-old have refereed two matches in the group stage, plus games at Euro 2020 and the 2022 World Cup.\n\nFinally, Bastian Dankert will be on VAR duties and brings a decade's worth of experience as a FIFA-listed official.\n\nGet a free live stream to watch Euro 2024 from anywhere in the world and catch the final stages of the summer's big tournament\n\nEuro 2024 isn't even over - one Euros star has already scored a Champions League hat-trick\n\nQuiz! "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/m7qyhxFiX7WD7SLADFgY66-1200-80.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9712618", "eventUri": "eng-9712618", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.05098039215686279, "wgt": 124, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-416968794", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "05:27:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T05:27:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T05:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/sport/football/asked-england-fans-care-football-boring-3160619", "title": "I asked England fans if they care the football is 'boring' - here's what they said", "body": "It's not only evident in the furious radio phone-ins, the YouTube rants and pundit debates, nor confined to the coverage within Europe's borders, including the newspaper papers of semi-final opponents the Netherlands, where England's performances have been described as \"barely watchable\" and \"ultra conservative\".\n\nThe Japan Times ran an article citing Southgate's comments about England \"grinding\" out results. The Ringer, an American sport and popular culture website, published an article with the headline: \"Can England Bore Its Way to Euros Glory?\"\n\nUndeniably, England have been dull. According to analysis by statisticians Opta, England have had fewer shots -- only 45 -- and shots on target -- 15 -- than any of the teams that reached the quarter-finals.\n\nTheir expected goals - the statistic that predicts how many goals a team should score based on the volume and types of chances created - is 4.36, beneath Georgia, Croatia and Slovakia, none of whom made it to the quarter-finals.\n\nBy comparison, Spain's xG (prior to their semi-final) was 10.31 and the Netherlands' 7.65, making them almost twice as likely to score.\n\nDoes it matter if it's boring? Is it an issue that a squad worth more than a billion pounds has failed to record more than one shot on target in each of the last two knockout games?\n\nShould fans and neutrals expect more from a front line that includes the Bundesliga top scorer, the Premier League and La Liga player of the year, and Bukayo Saka, the player who has asked them to hold his beer while he shows them all how to do it?\n\nFrance and their manager Didier Deschamps - a finalist in the last two World Cups, winning one - have faced the same accusations. \"If we're boring you, you can watch something else, it doesn't matter,\" Deschamps replied bluntly when questioned about it.\n\nSouthgate, when asked if entertainment ever crossed his mind shortly after beating Switzerland on penalties, offered a sarcastic apology, insisting, \"These are not normal football matches, these are national events. Huge pressure. With really young men in the middle of it. Our team's been under enormous pressure from the start and they're doing so well. So well.\"\n\nWe all know about the fans shouting loudly about how boring it is, but when I canvassed the opinion of supporters on the ground who have been in the stadiums in Germany I was surprised to discover a different perspective.\n\nGeorge Smith, 41, has been at all the England games at Euro 2024 and is travelling back to Dortmund for the semi-final. \"We are two more boring performances from glory, I would take that any day,\" he says. \"I think we have a great group of penalty takers now so would be confident if it goes that far again.\"\n\nSmith, who has wide-ranging perspective of England having been at every tournament since the Germany World Cup in 2006, adds: \"While the performances have not been great at all, it's the sign of a good team to win when not playing well.\n\n\"If that's true we are a very good team although it does feel like we have played our get out of jail free card with Jude Bellingham's magic versus Slovakia. The games being so tight have made them emotional rollercoaster for the fans in the stands.\"\n\nNed Pendleton, 38, has been to all bar the Slovakia game. \"The dull football hasn't affected my enjoyment at all -- I've felt this throughout,\" he says.\n\n\"It's just been such great fun going to the matches, drinking with my friends and all the England fans during the day. Then there's been great atmospheres in the stadium, the crowd have been so supportive during the matches.\"\n\nHe recalls the second half of the goalless draw with Slovenia in England's third group game, when the England fans created such a phenomenal atmosphere for almost the entirety that it has been referenced several times since by Southgate.\n\n\"That was one of the best atmospheres I've ever been part of,\" Pendleton says. \"The fact the football was boring was almost a reason why the fans decided to go for it and make their own entertainment.\n\n\"I think it has helped that this is the first tournament since 2016 in an easily accessible fun country where lots and lots of fans have travelled.\"\n\nAndy Hughes went to all the group games and the quarter-final. \"It doesn't matter whether we win ugly or if the football's a little bit boring,\" he says.\n\n\"If a lot of England fans are being honest -- and I go to every game -- we don't expect the football to be as expansive as some of the best teams in the Premier League. That's not how England have been set up under Southgate. And we're OK with that.\"\n\nHis issue, however, is that you can still play good football while not being so expansive and that in recent months England have failed to do that, citing struggles against North Macedonia, Malta, losing to Iceland and Brazil, almost losing to Belgium.\n\n\"We've not won any game in our last 10 games comprehensively,\" he says, but adds: \"All of that said -- I don't think it matters. England fans at the games just want to go through. It's tournament football it doesn't matter how you get there, win ugly, just get through.\"\n\nAhead of the quarter-final I asked friends and family back home about the atmosphere, expecting it to start ramping up, in spite of the football. But Bellingham's stoppage-time overhead kick against Slovakia was not the match thrown onto the petrol-soaked bonfire I anticipated.\n\nIt was a \"weird vibe with England\" one said. Very flat. Another recalled seeing a large pile of flags and bunting in a local shop and asking the owner how many they'd sold. They hadn't sold any.\n\nShouldn't England at major tournaments be about getting excitement bubbling back home? The looking forward to the games, the planning where to watch them, the St George's flags flapping on every other car you drive past, the fun, the excitement, the suspense? The flames of hope fanned by a team going for it in games, daring to take risks for the sake of entertainment?\n\nThose who believe this will never see eye-to-eye with Southgate on the issue.\n\nHe has watched the nations that have come before and lifted trophies on the back of a solid defence and few goals and knows their fans only remember the glitter of silverware, not how they got there.\n\nItaly won the 1982 World Cup after three draws in the group stage, progressing in second place. They scored only nine goals in the six games leading up to the final (adding three in the final). England have scored five goals so far so it would require a four-goal haul against the Netherlands to match that low tally.\n\nCameroon one-nilled their way to the 1988 Afcon, scoring four goals in five games.\n\nDenmark reached the Euro 1992 final with a back five and abused the time-wasting tactic of goalkeeper Peter Schmeichel passing out to a defender, receiving the ball back and picking it up so extensively that Fifa subsequently banned back-passes after the tournament.\n\nSpain, with its exquisitely gifted midfield of Xavi, Iniesta and David Silva, lifted the 2010 World Cup despite losing 1-0 to Switzerland in the opening game and then managing one-nil wins in every knockout round. It was the moment people started getting bored by tiki-taka.\n\nIn a way, Southgate's brutally efficient, data-driven, consultant-like approach to managing England is, in itself, taking a great risk. Do you remember who played in the semi-finals of previous World Cups and European Championships? Not generally. Maybe if pushed.\n\nHis big gamble is to sacrifice the thrill and excitement for an entire tournament if it means England winning a first European Championship in history.\n\nHe will face fan mutiny if it fails. If he succeeds? The achievement will not only travel around the world but will be remembered throughout time in the years ahead.", "source": {"uri": "inews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "inews.co.uk"}, "https://wp.inews.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/SEI_212136591.jpg?crop=0px%2C181px%2C2500px%2C1411px&resize=1200%2C675", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9712618", "eventUri": {"uri": "8218093895", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "06:01:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T06:01:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T06:01:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/07/10/netherlands-scouting-report-england-can-expect-euro-2024-semi-final-21190747/", "title": "Netherlands scouting report: what England can expect in Euro 2024 semi-final", "body": "The Three Lions take on Oranje on Wednesday night in Dortmund with a place in the final in Berlin up for grabs.\n\nThis will be by far Gareth Southgate's toughest test of the tournament - even more so given his side's underwhelming performances - with the Dutch emerging as a formidable team despite a rough start to their campaign.\n\nWith world-class talent in defence and attack, here's everything you need to know about the Netherlands - and how England can stop them:\n\nThe Netherlands were dealt a tough draw in Group D, but got off to a decent start, coming from behind to beat Poland 2-1, with super sub Wout Weghorst scoring a late winner.\n\nThey were held to a goalless draw by France, with Xavi Simons having a late winner controversially ruled out by VAR, before losing 3-2 to the impressive Austria.\n\nThat meant they only qualified as one of the best third-place teams, but they appear to have reserved their best form for the knockouts, defeating Romania 3-0 in an end-to-end last 16 tie.\n\nTheir quarter-final clash was equally thrilling, coming from behind again to beat the entertaining Turkey 2-1 and set up the England semi-final.\n\nA Euro 1988 winner and one of the greatest central defenders of all-time, Ronald Koeman's managerial career hasn't been as successful as his playing one but still boasts an incredible list of clubs on his CV.\n\nThis includes Ajax, Benfica, PSV, Valencia, Feyenoord and Barcelona, though he is best known to English fans for his time in charge of Southampton and Everton.\n\nInterestingly, his first game as Netherlands boss was a 1-0 friendly defeat to England in 2018, but the 61-year-old got his revenge, overseeing the last meeting between the two countries in the 2019 Nations League semi-final which ended 3-1 to the Dutch after extra-time.\n\nPrior to the tournament, captain and towering centre-back Virgil van Dijk was easily considered the Dutch's best asset, but at Euro 2024 it's been a different Liverpool star: Cody Gakpo.\n\nThe speedy forward hasn't always looked comfortable at Anfield, but has come alive on the international stage, with three goals putting him on course for the Golden Boot.\n\n'Gakpo's had a good tournament so far, lively, played with a lot of confidence,' Dutchman and former Manchester United assistant manager Rene Meulensteen told Free Bets.\n\n'He's a little bit of what we had with Arjen Robben so many years ago, coming in on the left foot and putting it in the top corner. Cody is the exact same coming off the right.'\n\nKoeman has tinkered around with his side throughout the Euros but appears to have settled on an XI at last, with the highlight being an imperious defence featuring Van Dijk, Stefan de Vrij, Nathan Ake and Denzel Dumfries.\n\nGakpo will start on the left-wing, but there are other attacking threats to be wary of as Meulensteen reveals: 'Xavi Simons can do things, he's a good player but hasn't been at his best and then you've got impact players.\n\n'I don't know what Koeman's going to do on the right-hand side, whether [Donyell] Malen, [Jeremie] Frimpong or [Steven] Bergwijn. I hope he's going to play Malen because I think he has something, he's got a change of pace, can come inside, outside.\n\n'Bergwijn was a bit questionable, people thought why did you play him but that was more to release Dumfries on the right hand side. If he can run forward, he can cause problems Dumfries.\n\n'From set pieces, Van Dijk with his head is strong. Those are the players I'd say can cause real problems for England.\n\n'I think they'll try to dominate possession, try to get hold of the ball and move it around. When you get possession but lack the purpose of trying to open the opposition up, you just keep shifting the ball for sake of it and give it away.\n\n'You can look at the possession stats, but if nothing came of it, you got nowhere. So I really hope that the Netherlands use that possession constructively, to make sure we move it well, quickly and through the lines, asking questions of England.\n\n'Every team that has gone more on the front foot and moved to press England, they were giving the ball up easily and quickly, allowing the opposition all the opportunity to create chances. That's what I want Holland to do.'\n\nMan-to-man, England are probably stronger than the Dutch but have thus far lacked their cohesion and effective tactical set-up.\n\nThere were signs of improvement from the Three Lions in their quarter-final though and with the Netherlands unlikely to sit deep they may have more freedom to finally utilise their impressive attacking talent.\n\nAnd even though Oranje are strong offensively, they have lacked a clinical touch at times at the Euros, and if Southgate can mastermind a plan to stop Gakpo it could give them the edge.\n\n'The only problem is the Turkish team dealt with [Gakpo] really well by doubling up on him, so every time he came inside there was another player to stop that space, so he never had a chance to shoot,' Meulensteen noted.\n\n'You need to counterattack that by having overlapping runs, so he has an option to play somebody in with a reverse pass. Cody against Kyle Walker will be difficult.'\n\nMORE : How England went from dreadful to joyous at Euro 2024 under our greatest ever manager\n\nMORE : Spain boss Luis de la Fuente slams fans who booed optimistically some English bookies' pre-tournament favourites - have so far produced a series of painfully plodding displays from their galaxy of star names.\n\nThey limped through the group stages with just one victory after being roughed up by the likes of Denmark, Serbia and Slovenia.\n\nREAD MORE: BREAKING: Spain through to Euro 2024 final after 2-1 win over France\n\nThe Slavic theme followed with a second-round tie against Slovakia, who were 30 seconds away from a famous victory that would have sent English football spiralling into a months-long state of depressive introspection.\n\nYet their star names finally came to the rescue, with Bellingham's famous overhead kick followed up by a Harry Kane header early in extra-time to send England through to a quarter final against Switzerland.\n\nPerennial middle-weights, the Swiss had looked seriously impressive against Germany in the group stages, where they were denied a famous victory by a last-gasp equaliser.\n\nBut they proved that was no fluke by expertly sending Italy packing in the second round with a solid 2-0 victory.\n\nIn the quarter-final, England were forced to up their game to match the Swiss and the tie was fairly even, with an 80th minute Bukayo Saka equaliser earning the Three Lions extra time and penalties.\n\nAnd it was the unprecedented expertise and nerveless confidence with which England's penalty specialists scored all their kicks that will give the Three Lions confidence that perhaps they might be leaving it late to grow into the tournament.\n\nREAD MORE: 'I'm supporting Spain all the way!' fellow heavy-weight for the first time in the tournament.\n\nThe Dutch no longer field the star names of ten years ago, and man-for-man England will fancy their chances.\n\nLike England, they struggled in the group stages, but seem to have clicked into gear in the knockout rounds, with a 3-0 win over Romania followed by a more nervy 2-1 victory over Turkey.\n\nPerhaps the real star of Holland's tournament so far have been the sea of orange-clad hard-partiers that have taken over every city where their national team has been playing.\n\nVideos have gone viral of the Dutch fans bouncing left and then right with arms linked to their unofficial anthem Links Rechts (or 'Left Right') by europop group Snollebollekes.\n\nDespite being overshadowed by the England players' greater It's a huge game. I think we felt at the start of the tournament that England had a decent chance of going far in the Euros,' ex-England and Liverpool defender said on Sky Sports.\n\n'You need a little bit of luck, anyone does in a knockout competition, and we had that in the last couple of rounds.\n\n'But I think with the players we've got, the squad we've got and our recent success in terms of getting to the latter stages of tournaments, we always felt we would get to this stage.\n\n'We're here now so this almost where it all begins for us.'\n\nWhile Kane has performed well below par this summer, Carragher believes the Dutch defence will give England's out-of-sorts attack opportunities to score in Dortmund.\n\nAsked if the match can be boiled down to a clash of the two captain, Kane and Virgil van Dijk, Carragher replied: 'I think there will be a lot more to it than that. I think it's fair to say that Harry hasn't been at his sharpest in this tournament.\n\n'He's got a couple of goals but he's coming up against one of the best and, for me, Virgil van Dijk over the last few years has been one of the best centre-backs in not just European football but world football.\n\n'But he [Van Dijk] has had a couple of moments in this tournament as well where he probably hasn't done as well as they would have liked. The Austria game in the group stage comes to mind.\n\n'And the last game that Holland played, they did well to come back against Turkey, but there was a lot of hairy moments towards the end of the game as well.\n\n'So there is certainly things to look at there and not just Harry Kane, all of England attacking players, that they can capitalise if those chances arise.'\n\nOn the back of a string of uninspiring performances, Carragher is hopeful that it will finally click for the Three Lions against the Netherlands.\n\nHe added: 'We need to see the real England and that may come through playing better opposition because up until now, with some of the players we've got, we just haven't seen enough of what we'd expect, nowhere near.\n\n'When you consider what we've seen from certainly Spain, who await in the final. Even Holland have had a couple of bumpy moments but in the main they've done quite well.\n\n'They have scored goals, looked quite dangerous, and we haven't quite done that yet so hopefully that changes tonight.'\n\nAsked for his prediction, Carragher replied: 'I think England just do it, yeah. Their journey hit a bump with a thrilling 3-2 defeat to Austria, but they managed to advance as one of the best four third-placed teams.\n\nIn the Round of 16, they made a statement, dismantling Romania 3-0 and showcasing their true attacking firepower. Their resilience shone through again in the quarterfinals, where they clawed back from behind to secure a hard-fought victory over Turkey, scoring twice in a frantic six-minute spell in the second period.\n\nStefan de Vrij's strike and an own goal swiftly nullified Samet Akaydin's opener, confirming a place in a European Championship semifinal for the first time since 2004.\n\nElsewhere, Gareth Southgate's Three Lions managed to clinch the top spot in Group C despite not playing up to their full potential. Phil Foden, Harry Kane, and Jude Bellingham all showed moments of brilliance during the three games, but consistency to churn out chances was sorely missing. Bellingham's incredible overhead kick necessitated extra time in the Round of 16 win against Slovakia, resulting in Kane's decisive goal.\n\nIn the quarterfinal encounter with Switzerland, England overcame a deficit with Bukayo Saka's equalizer, eventually prevailing in the penalty shootout by flawlessly dispatching all five spot-kicks. The Three Lions now stand just one victory away from securing a second consecutive European Championship final berth.\n\nMORE: Euro 2024 schedule and results, updated LIVE | Who will win Euro 2024? Latest odds and predictions | How to watch all the Euro 2024 action\n\nThis Euro 2024 semifinal kicks off from Signal Iduna Park on Wednesday, July 10 at 9 p.m. local time in Dortmund, Germany.\n\nHere's how that time translates across all of the time zones in North America:\n\nUSA: England vs. Netherlands will be televised in the United States on FOX, while Spanish TV broadcasts are provided by Univision and TUDN. These channels are all available to stream on Fubo, who are offering a FREE seven-day trial. ViX is also an option for Spanish viewers.\n\nRadio coverage of the match can be followed on SiriusXM FC.\n\nCanada: TSN are the main English-language broadcasters for Euro 2024 while TVA provides French options.\n\nIf this match is not available to watch live in your location, or if you're traveling abroad, you can use a Virtual Private Network (VPN). VPNs offer a secure and private online connection, allowing you to bypass geographical restrictions to access your favorite streaming services from any device anywhere in the world.\n\nWATCH FROM ANYWHERE: Sign up for NordVPN (30-day moneyback guarantee)\n\nEngland's much-discussed switch to a three-man defence for the Switzerland game hardly proved to be a significant change from previous lacklustre displays, but Luke Shaw made his long-awaited return from injury as he came on in the second half of the quarterfinal, so he will likely be in serious contention to replace right-footed Kieran Trippier here to provide proper balance on the left side.\n\nHarry Kane was forced off in extra time with an injury picked up during the game, but it seems like he will recover in time to keep his place in the starting XI for this one, despite calls for the captain to be dropped following some anonymous centre-forward displays.\n\nThe Three Lions will also welcome back Marc Guehi from his one-game ban, and he should start alongside mainstay John Stones even though Ezri Konsa performed admirably in his absence last time out. Konsa could keep his spot should Southgate persist with a back three, though.\n\nKobbie Mainoo has enjoyed a positive summer over in Germany and the 19-year-old Manchester United midfield sensation will continue to partner Declan Rice in the engine room.\n\nEngland predicted lineup (4-2-3-1): Pickford (GK) -- Walker, Stones, Guehi, Shaw -- Mainoo, Rice -- Saka, Bellingham, Foden -- Kane.\n\nNetherlands boss Ronald Koeman stuck with the same starting lineup for both of his side's knockout games so far, but there could be one change in the offing in Dortmund.\n\nSteven Bergwijn has been unimpressive on the right wing and his place is under threat from Donyell Malen, who bagged a quick-fire brace in the Round of 16 against Romania. Jeremie Frimpong, who typically plays right-back for Bayer Leverkusen, is another possible option.\n\nWith RB Leipzig's playmaking sensation Xavi Simons sitting behind Memphis Depay and Liverpool's Cody Gakpo posing a serious danger on the left wing, notching three goals in his five Euro 2024 outings and leading the Golden Boot race, the Dutch have deployed a pretty fluid 4-2-3-1 formation. Super-sub Wout Weghorst would be the go-to option off the bench.\n\nExperienced Inter Milan star Stefan de Vrij will again support captain Virgil van Dijk at the heart of Koeman's defence. Nathan Ake is expected to stay at left-back ahead of Tottenham's Micky van de Ven, while Denzel Dumfries offers a bombarding option on the opposite flank.\n\nNetherlands predicted lineup (4-3-3): Verbruggen (GK) -- Dumfries, De Vrij, Van Dijk, Ake -- Schouten, Simons, Reijnders -- Malen, Depay, Gakpo.\n\nThe Three Lions undeniably boasts more talent and experience in these high-profile games. Southgate emphasized this fact following the victory over Switzerland, and it's a factor that should heavily influence the outcome here.\n\nDespite their impressive defensive work, England have struggled to decisively finish off their chances, while their vulnerability to counter-attacks becomes evident whenever they take offensive risks.\n\nThe Dutch, however, are not without their own flaws. Their defense can be sluggish and cumbersome, and they've often lacked midfield dominance and a clinical edge in attack. Nevertheless, they pose a threat with their ability to deliver dangerous crosses, execute quick interchanges on the ground, and unleash powerful shots from distance.\n\nThis clash is shaping up to be a tight contest that could very well go the distance. It has reached crazy levels during this tournament and has even seen fans throw beer at Southgate after the goalless draw with Slovenia.\n\nBut England now have a Euros semi final with Holland in Dortmund on Wednesday night and Southgate says he is using the abuse to drive him on. Southgate said: \"Look, I can't deny that some of the personal nature... this is a job where you get ridiculed, and your professional capability is questioned beyond belief, and I don't think it's normal to have beer thrown at you either.\n\n\"But I'm fortunate that my life's taken me through a lot of resilience-building and it's made me more determined and I'm just using it as fuel. Virgil Van Dijk, Cody Gakpo of Liverpool and Manchester City's Nathan Ake to name three decorated Premier League stars.\n\nThe Netherlands, however, were also not at their best during their group matches and only qualified as one of the best third-placed teams.\n\nSince then though, their form has improved dramatically with five goals in two games since going through to the knock-out stages.\n\nGakpo is out in front in the race for the Golden Boot having notched three times; Harry Kane is only one behind him, and while the England captain's performances so far have divided opinion, he has a very good record when he's come face to face with Van Dijk.\n\nIt's likely to be a tight, tense night and it would surprise no one if it meandered to extra time and {"uri": "8218705768", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:36:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:36:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:35:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-13616615/england-netherlands-euro-2024-euro-96.html", "title": "Where are they now: England's stars from 4-1 win over Dutch at Euro 96", "body": "LISTEN to It's All Kicking Off! EUROS DAILY: Have England really been playing with fear at Euro 2024?\n\nTuesday the 18th of June 1996 was a remarkable day for English football as a 4-1 demolition of a star-studded Netherlands team saw the Three Lions qualify for the last 16 of the European Championship in style.\n\nTeddy Sheringham and Alan Shearer, who was on the brink of a record breaking transfer to his boyhood club Newcastle at the time, both scored twice on a memorable day at Wembley.\n\nVictory over the Dutch, and the manner of the win, raised belief that England could go all the way at their home Euros but their dream came crashing down after a heartbreaking defeat by Germany on penalties in the semi-finals.\n\nThe side from the hammering of the Netherlands 28 years ago have gone on to take very different paths with some having remained in the football industry and others choosing careers outside of the game.\n\nEngland have the chance to go one further on Wednesday night when they face the Netherlands in the Euro 2024 semi-finals in Dortmund. Here, Mail Sport looks at the Three Lions' team of 1996 and where they are now.\n\nEngland beat the Netherlands 4-1 at Euro 96 - and take on the Dutch for a place in the Euro 2024 final\n\nPodcast All episodes LISTEN: Southgate only England manager to be criticised whilst winning PODCAST: The REAL reason England through despite playing badly PODCAST: 'Just ONE good performance' could change England's fortunes PODCAST: Are the England team buying into Southgate's style of play? PODCAST: Is Martinez 'spineless' over Cristiano Ronaldo management? Play on Apple Spotify Goalkeeper - David Seaman\n\nThe Arsenal and England legend was a key member of the team at Euro 96 and enjoyed a stellar career in the game, winning three league titles, four FA Cups and the European Cup Winners' Cup.\n\nAfter retiring in 2004, Seaman has dabbled in reality TV, winning the first edition of Strictly Ice Dancing, played in all six Soccer Aid matches for England, done a considerable amount of work for charity - and even appeared in The Masked Singer with his wife, Frankie Poultney.\n\nHe now hosts his own weekly football podcast, Seaman Says. Seaman lives with Ms Poultney, his third wife, and has four children.\n\nRight back - Gary Neville\n\nIt is fair to say that Neville, a one-man club, has been busy since his trophy flooded career was brought to a close.\n\nIn 2011 he decided to remain in football and enjoyed a largely seamless and transition into broadcasting for Sky Sports.\n\nFour years later, he made the move into management but endured a disastrous spell with Valencia. After losing his job at the Spanish club, he said that he was doing 'all the things he says not to do on television'.\n\nNeville is now a businessman as well as a well-known pundit, recently appearing on Dragon's Den. He is listed as a director for 56 businesses including hotels, pubs and restaurants and has an estimated net worth of \u00a370m.\n\nDavid Seaman has enjoyed a successful career post-retirement and hosts his own podcast\n\nGary Neville moved into punditry after ending his career and also works in business\n\nCentre back - Tony Adams READ MOREEXCLUSIVE Have England been playing with fear at Euro 2024 and can they shake it off for Netherlands semi-final showdown?\n\nAdams, captain of the team which thrashed the Netherlands, retired from football in 2002 following fitness problems.\n\nThe ex-Arsenal legend has openly discussed suffering from drug and alcohol addiction, and in 2015 underwent heart surgery which he later said had saved his life.\n\nAdams, whose spell as a manager took him to far-flung places including Azerbaijan, has also appeared on Strictly Come Dancing but his time on the show was cut short due to injury.\n\nCentre back - Gareth Southgate\n\nSouthgate, capped 57 times by England, featured in the 4-1 win over the Netherlands and will now aim to guide the country to the final of the Euros as manager.\n\nHe has been in charge of the The Three Lions since 2016 and reached three semi finals in major tournaments, making him undoubtedly the most successful English manager since Sir Alf Ramsey.\n\nEuro 2024 could be his last chance to taste glory with England and they will move a step closer to ending their long wait for a major trophy if they can repeat the exploits of Southgate's team from 28 years ago by beating the Dutch on Wednesday night.\n\nGareth Southgate starred for England at Euro 96 and is now plotting another Dutch downfall\n\nLeft back - Stuart Pearce\n\nPearce became the face of England's bid to win the tournament in 1996 after an infamous celebration for his penalty which represented the joy of a nation.\n\nThe England star retired in 2002 but briefly appeared for non-league club Longford AFC who had lost 18 consecutive games on the bounce and had a -178 goal difference.\n\nSince calling time on his career, Pearce has managed teams including the Team GB football side at London 2012, Manchester City and Nottingham Forest. He is now a pundit, appearing regularly on talkSPORT.\n\nRight midfield - Darren Anderton\n\nEx-Tottenham and Portsmouth midfielder Anderton retired from football in 2008 after recording 30 caps and scoring on seven occasions.\n\nAnderton now lives in the United States, following his beloved Spurs from afar, and works as a pundit on US and Canadian television and in print.\n\nStuart Pearce enjoyed a career as a manager after retiring and now works as a TV and radio pundit\n\nCentre midfield - Paul Ince\n\nPaul Ince who made history becoming the first black man to captain England has moved around managerial jobs in the lower leagues since his retirement from professional football in 2007.\n\nThe former Man United midfielder has since managed the likes of MK Dons, Blackburn Rovers and Notts County.\n\nHis last job came at Reading, where he was sacked in April 2023. Ince is currently employed as he plots a way back into management.\n\nPaul Ince (centre-right) also went into management following the end of his playing career\n\nCentre midfield - Paul Gascoigne\n\nThe star of England's run to the semi-finals at Euro 96, Gascoigne is still fighting his never ending battle to stay sober. Four months ago, the 57-year-old revealed that he was homeless and living in his agent's living room.\n\nGascoigne suffered and is suffering with mental health problems and has been diagnosed multiple times with different conditions.\n\nSince retiring, Gascoigne has been open about his battle against alcohol addiction and he has admitted that he is back attending Alcoholics Anonymous meetings.\n\nThe England footballing genius, who is also known as 'Gazza', has also appeared at charity football matches and on TV since retiring.\n\nPaul Gascoigne, one of England's greatest ever, has opened up on his struggles with alcohol and depression\n\nLeft midfield - Steve McManaman\n\nMcManaman retired from football in 2005 after being released from Manchester City after a two year spell at the club.\n\nHe has followed the likes of Neville into the media and works as a co-commentator for ESPN and TNT Sports.\n\nThe ex-Liverpool man has a passion for horse racing and has owned several horses.\n\nSteve McManaman regularly covers big matches in his work as a pundit for TNT Sports\n\nStriker - Teddy Sheringham\n\nSheringham entered management in the 2014/15 season for Stevenage and after 33 games it was deemed that he had failed.\n\nThe next step of his managerial career was a move to ATK in the Indian Super League where he was sacked after half a season after winning three out of his ten games in charge.\n\nSince his failed career in management, Sheringham has appeared on the Masked Singer - he was 'Tree' in the first edition of the series in 2020 - and is often seen on Sky Sports News to discuss the latest football stories.\n\nSheringham has appeared on the Masked Singer - he was 'Tree' in the first edition of the series in 2020\n\nStriker - Alan Shearer\n\nThe Premier league's all-time top goalscorer Alan Shearer is now a pundit and co-commentator for the BBC.\n\nShearer, now 53, also appears on the Rest is Football podcast with Gary Lineker and Micah Richards.\n\nHe also has a charity, The Alan Shearer Foundation, which raises money to buy supplies for a disability centre in Newcastle which provides free sensory and specialist leisure activities.\n\nAlan Shearer works as one of the BBC's main pundits and appears on the Rest is Football podcast\n\nSubstitute - Robbie Fowler\n\nFowler has taken his career on an interesting path having moved around managerial jobs in Australia, India and the second division of Saudi Arabia.\n\nHe has said that he is open to a potential move back to England and in the Premier League if the right job opens up.\n\nHe has also increased his net worth to about \u00a330m due to a series of investments into businesses, properties and companies.\n\nSubstitute - David Platt\n\nPlatt is another to have gone into management, working at Nottingham Forest and Sampdoria as well as being Roberto Mancini's assistant at Manchester City.\n\nHe has previously worked as a pundit and consultant for the City Football Group, while he founded a company called Golazzo Group, which helps grassroots clubs source equipment.\n\nSubstitute - Nick Barmby\n\nBarmby briefly managed Hull City after retiring from the game. {"uri": "2024-07-414856751", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "09:51:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T09:51:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T09:45:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://www.joe.co.uk/news/dutch-media-slams-england-team-ahead-of-semi-final-446742", "title": "Dutch media slams England team ahead of semi-final", "body": "Dutch media have slammed the England team ahead of their semi-final clash with the Netherlands on Wednesday.\n\nGareth Southgate's men were once again lucky to stay in the tournament after coming from 1-0 down to eventually beat Switzerland on penalties.\n\nIn the aftermath of the game, press all around Europe were eager to give their thoughts on another drab England performance, despite many at home thinking it was their best yet.\n\nThe criticism came heavily from Marcel van der Kraan of De Telegraaf who described the match as \"more like a William Shakespeare tragedy\" while saying the most entertainment part of the England team is the usual fanfare around their wives.\n\nThe journalist said: \"For almost 75 minutes, England-Switzerland looked more like a William Shakespeare tragedy than a tough battle for a place in the European Championship semi-finals. The English, with their abundance of talent and quality, did not provide entertainment in any way.\n\n\"The greatest amount of entertainment surrounding the England team this tournament comes not from the players but from their wives. They provide more pages of entertainment, arguments and glamour performances in Germany than their highly paid men.\"\n\nHe added: \"That those affairs and the ladies in pink slippers and Chanel bags on the runway in front of half a dozen private jets score more headlines than Harry Kane, who again had the fewest kilometres to his name against Switzerland, or the entire, very boring England team says everything.\"\n\nVan der Kraan was also critical of the Swiss.\n\nHe said: \"Fifteen minutes before the end, everyone in the packed D\u00fcsseldorf stadium thought that a team worth one and a half billion euros was being sent home by a country where they have 450 types of cheese and barely 11 reasonable football players.\"\n\nSuch criticism comes despite the Netherlands not exactly experiencing a vintage tournament either.\n\nLucky to beat the Polish last minute and loss to Austria, the Dutch had to once again come from behind late on to beat Turkey in the quarter-finals.\n\nThe press in other European nations were equally keen to hop on the England-critical bandwagon.\n\nSpanish paper Marca focused on Real Madrid star man Jude Bellingham saying \"he did little, like the rest of the team.\"\n\nVictor Romeo wrote: \"Jude Bellingham is exhausted and if the helmsman does not pull the cart, the cart will not go forward.\n\n\"England went through to the semi-finals of the Euro Cup, but their great star is far from the best level. Like the rest of his team-mates, with the exception of the scorer Saka against Switzerland.\"\n\nIn the lead up to the big semi-final showdown between the Netherlands and England, Dutch players have had their say on the England squad.\n\nLiverpool's Cody Gakpo said: \"But they win. They win. That's a good sign. Like us. [Winning] is all that matters, at the end. It's the most important to win. You can play very good football, but if you don't win, you're out.\"\n\nNathan Ake of Manchester City compounded this idea.\n\nHe said: \"Sometimes, tournament football is not always about playing great. They are in a semi-final again. I think every team in the semi-final deserves to be there otherwise they wouldn't be there.\"", "source": {"uri": "joe.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "JOE.co.uk"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8217657288", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "21:36:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T21:36:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T21:35:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/soccer/2024/07/09/southgate-urges-england-to-change-history-in-euro-2024-semi-final-against-the-netherlands/", "title": "Southgate urges England to 'change history' in Euro 2024 semi-final against the Netherlands", "body": "Gareth Southgate has \u00adchallenged \u00adEngland to \u00adforget past disappointments and \"change \u00adhistory\" by \u00adreaching a first big \u00adtournament final on foreign shores when they face the Netherlands on Wednesday night.\n\nEngland enter their Euro 2024 semi-final as favourites despite a slow-burning month's work that has received heavy criticism at times. But they are one game from entering uncharted territory and, if they can negotiate a pressure-cooker \u00adatmosphere in Dortmund to win the 23rd meeting of these old rivals, they will have achieved something unmatched by their male predecessors.\n\nThree years ago Southgate's players reached the final at Wembley after beating Denmark. But their previous last-four appearance, against Croatia at the 2018 World Cup in Russia, ended in heartbreak and the manager hopes such setbacks fuel their hunger to take the next step.\n\n\"We've risen well to those \u00adchallenges over the years and used them as motivation to break new ground,\" Southgate said of the task England face at the Westfalenstadion \u00adin Dortmund. \"We've never been to a final outside our own shores. These are opportunities to make a \u00addifference and that's how we have to look at it.\n\n\"We don't want to be burdened by what's happened before. We've got to use this opportunity to change \u00adhistory as a motivation, and that's how the players see it. It's about their moment now, nothing that's gone on in the past. None of that is their fault or concern.\"\n\nAlthough not without flaws, the shoot-out win over Switzerland was England's best performance of the tournament and suggested an improvement at the right time. Southgate spoke of a \"fascinating experience\" overseeing a team he felt was \"fearful\" in earlier fixtures.\n\n\"[They were] almost concerned about what could go wrong,\" he said. \"We haven't had that for a few years. Maybe that was expectation, maybe that was a lot of external things as well. But now they're very much in a 'what's achievable, what's \u00adpossible?' sort of mindset. I think we saw a truer reflection of ourselves in the last game.\"\n\nThe response, inside and outside his squad, to England's second group game, against Denmark, concerned Southgate and prompted him to address their trepidation head-on. Before they met Slovenia he showed them photographs of other sides' more carefree reactions. \"We definitely spoke about it,\" he said. \"When you can sense that feeling you need to \u00adconfront it. It's no use avoiding it and hoping it will go away.\n\n\"The Denmark game, the point we got, there's a picture of the \u00adplayers looking distraught. They've got a point that essentially ensured us qualifying. Every other team was \u00adcelebrating with their fans at that, and we were on our knees. So I had to correct how they were viewing things. That feeling was being \u00adreinforced so vocally and actively outside, and I think they were picking up on that too much.\"\n\nSpeaking after England had \u00adcompleted a training session in temperatures exceeding 30 degrees, Harry Kane suggested the sheen acquired through recent successes can carry them through when performances falter. The real fear factor, he observed, may be transmitted by England's players to their opposition.\n\n\"We still haven't reached the full potential you've seen for several years now,\" Kane said. \"But we're still in a good place and leaning on a lot of experience. We're leaning on being here before, even just the perception from other teams. When you've been in finals, semi-finals, on a consistent basis that gives you a certain aura as a team that other nations look at.\n\n\"We've built that up over past \u00adtournaments and now we're in a \u00adsituation where we deserve to be [here]. It's not easy getting through any round and we've found a way to do it.\"\n\nKane acknowledged semi-finals are viewed differently, comparing this year with the newness of \u00ad\"riding that wave\" in 2018. \"You have to \u00adhandle a different kind of pressure,\" he said. \"If you get knocked out in the quarter-finals or round of 16 there'll be a lot more uproar than in previous tournaments.\"\n\nA goal return of two, coupled with some below-par showings, has brought calls for Kane to be dropped but he dismissed suggestions he is struggling physically. \"Sometimes when I don't score I think the fitness one is an easy one to throw in: 'Why? Is there a reason? Is it his fitness?' But I felt I had a good preparation going into the tournament; I feel I'm \u00adgetting better and sharper as the games go along.\"\n\nEngland can call on a fully fit squad who have enjoyed smoother \u00adpreparation than their opponents. The Netherlands' train from their camp in Wolfsburg was cancelled on Tuesday afternoon and led to a hastily scheduled evening flight. Southgate's biggest selection call will involve Marc Gu\u00e9hi, who is pushing to regain his place from Ezri Konsa after \u00adsuspension. Luke Shaw staked a claim in returning against \u00adSwitzerland but will be hard-pressed to displace Kieran Trippier at left back.\n\nSouthgate wants Wednesday to be merely the start of a summer success story. \"Our semi-final tally looks a bit more like what we'd hope an England history would look like,\" he said. \"But there are a lot of nations who have won the European Championship and we haven't. We want to try and redress that balance.\" -- Guardian", "source": {"uri": "irishtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Irish Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "https://www.irishtimes.com/resizer/ISoanpjUwwWCpb6aHuPdrgnwLgU=/1200x630/filters:format(jpg):quality(70)/cloudfront-eu-central-1.images.arcpublishing.com/irishtimes/K5RMPJW7L56XYD7OFMMGNIVVXY.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9712618", "eventUri": "eng-9712618", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.003921568627450966, "wgt": 121, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-415247388", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "15:26:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T15:26:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T15:24:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/sport/football/gareth-southgate-most-patient-english-football-lost-it-3158453", "title": "How the most patient man in English football finally lost it", "body": "The England manager always knew the job would be like this but it appears it has taken its toll over the course of the tournament\n\nBLANKENHAIN -- \"You either die a hero, or you live long enough to see yourself become the villain,\" Harvey Dent says to Bruce Wayne when discussing Batman in one of the most haunting and profound lines from The Dark Knight.\n\nIt applies to many historic figures and describes a similar trajectory followed by Gareth Southgate as England manager: the unlikely hero who revived a national team and led them to a World Cup semi-final and a European Championship final, yet here he is in Germany, in the last four yet again but somehow, eight years after taking the job, in the eyes of so many the villain.\n\nOn the way here he has had plastic beer cups thrown at him, had his team described as \"s**t\" by one of the most influential figures in English football, heard his team booed at half-time, full-time, even during games when the players have been passing the ball around the defence too much.\n\nThere was euphoria after the incredible set of penalties against Switzerland that sent England into the semis -- Southgate pumping his arms on the pitch in an endearing dad dance with the fans one of the rare moments he has allowed his emotions to spill over.\n\nHe had just guided the team to a third semi-final in four tournaments -- more than England had seen in the previous 50 years. No other nation has been more consistent in recent history.\n\nBut when he walked into his post-match press conference, deep in Dusseldorf Arena, to reflect on the occasion, if Southgate thought he was stepping into a celebration he would have been bitterly disappointed.\n\nInstead he faced questions about the lack of entertainment and their \"easy\" tournament opponents.\n\nIt had started relatively jovially, but then Southgate was asked about Jordan Pickford having penalty instructions written on his water bottle and he vented, sharing his frustrations that in the build-up to the tournament England's preparations had been revealed to all by experts who had worked with him to fix that particular problem in 2018.\n\nThat he lost the \"element of surprise\" when his decision to switch formation to a back three for the first time in the tournament had been revealed three days before the game.\n\n\"A lot of our processes have been shared,\" he said, with an exasperated laugh.\n\nAnother question asked if there was \"any thought of entertainment when you plan games, when you plan the way you play, for the neutrals? Because being not easy on the eye is part of the game\".\n\nSouthgate looked taken aback, mustering a measured answer and concluding that \"none of this stuff is easy. But we're in a third semi-final in four tournaments. And for the staff and players involved in that... yeah I think that's a pretty good achievement.\"\n\nHe was asked about his little celebratory dance with the fans after all the criticism.\n\n\"Every now and then you think surely there has to be some enjoyment in this job,\" Southgate said.\n\nWhat a statement to make. And it didn't end there.\n\n\"If I can't enjoy that moment then the whole thing's a waste of time really.\n\n\"I love the players, I love being in that moment with them. I took this job to try and improve English football. Not the seniors but when I first joined the Football Association. And I wanted us to regain credibility on the world stage.\"\n\nThere was a long pause.\n\n\"I can't deny that when it's been as personal as it's been in the last few weeks, on a human level that's quite difficult.\"\n\nThen came a moment that really shocked.\n\nAnother journalist asked: \"The tournament three years ago, the opponents you had to play it was Croatia, Scotland, the Czech Republic, a poor German team, Denmark -- .\"\n\nSouthgate cut him off: \"A poor German team? It had about eight Champions League winners in, yeah?\"\n\nThe most patient man in England, finally losing it.\n\nThe journalist persisted: \"The German team three years ago.\"\n\nSo did Southgate: \"I'm saying they had eight Champions League winners.\"\n\nThe journalist, speaking in non-native English, pressed on: \"And this tournament -- Denmark, Slovenia, Slovakia and Switzerland. Avoiding Netherlands, Spain, France, Portugal. Is it better for you to play better football if the team on the other side is better or are you afraid of coming up against them?\"\n\n\"Are you sure you're not English?\" Southgate asked. It was a joke, but the underlying point remained that he usually gets this kind of thing from his own country -- this was all foreign journalists.\n\nSouthgate made an attempt to explain his view on that but finished with: \"I'm not really sure what to say.\" Another exasperated half-laugh. \"It's the madness of this job, but we've had an enjoyable night and I'm going to try to keep it enjoyable if that's OK.\"\n\nThese are not the words, nor the demeanour, of a man who is overly happy in his job, of someone who is fine with continuing valiantly to keep the tsunami of negativity and criticism at bay, somebody who is planning on sticking around when he lands back in England, regardless of what happens in the next week.\n\nSouthgate always knew the England job was like this -- he has such a rich history with the national team, it is intrinsic to his identity: as a fan, then a 57-cap player, then taking a back-room job at the FA trying to fix the system that underpinned the national team, then as Under-21 head coach, then the first-team manager.\n\nHe knew about the impossible job, as it became forever known after a 1990s documentary, even felt he had helped remove some of that stigma when managers such as Mauricio Pochettino and Thomas Tuchel made it be known they would be interested in taking over from him.\n\nIt was always Southgate's superpower to cut out the crap. But maybe eight years of it and those powers are flickering and fading. During tournament camps Southgate avoids the news, TV, radio, podcasts, papers. He has never much been into social media anyway.\n\nBut the messages still seep through on WhatsApp. Gary Lineker's did, when the former England striker described his team as \"s**t\".\n\nAnd this time the criticism is closing in from everywhere. Those mood-dampening questions half an hour after his quarter-final victory were not from English journalists, but elsewhere. The foreign presses have been savage.\n\nDe Telegraaf, the largest daily newspaper in the Netherlands, described England's win over Switzerland as \"like a William Shakespeare tragedy\".\n\n\"Fifteen minutes before the end, everyone in the packed Dusseldorf stadium thought that a team worth one and a half billion euros was being sent home by a country where they have 450 types of cheese and barely 11 reasonable football players,\" the report read.\n\nFrance's L'\u00c9quipe, with its famous ratings, have been scathing of England's players throughout the tournament, and gave Kyle Walker his third 3/10.\n\n\"In difficulty, the English have relied on their best weapon since the start of this Euro: individual exploits,\" a report read. \"This time it came from Bukayo Saka, a rare brilliance in a dreary evening.\"\n\nSpain's Marca, focusing on Real Madrid star Jude Bellingham, reported that \"Jude Bellingham is exhausted and if the helmsman does not pull the cart, the cart will not go forward,\" claiming that his only \"significant\" moment in the game was when he dribbled down the wing in the 31st minute. \"Before and after that, he did little, like the rest of his team.\"\n\nOnline, closer to home, it has been a relentless tide of hatred. The endless clips, designed to go viral, of fans calling for Southgate to go have been posted since day one. One fan was asked what they wanted to see in the second half of a game and they said for Southgate to resign.\n\nWhy does the reaction not reflect the achievements? Southgate is to his bones a good bloke -- not necessarily a nice manager, he has ruthless streak that is a necessity of the job -- he is measured and calm and reflective, and maybe people refuse to accept those characteristics in their heroes.\n\nHaving covered all of Southgate's major tournaments, this one has felt different. In the short times we get to speak with Southgate he has seemed jaded, a touch short, snappy.\n\nMaybe there is a personal disappointment that he hasn't been able to get this unbelievably talented group of players to put on the sort of thrilling performances that are the only thing that keep the masses at bay. Maybe even the most resilient and thick-skinned person reaches the point where they no longer have the energy to keep those defences up.\n\nYou either die a hero, or you live long enough to see yourself become the villain. Southgate has been long enough in the job to watch himself become the villain.\n\nOr maybe England reach the final, and win it, and Southgate is the hero, after all. He lives to be the hero, and walks away the hero.\n\nThere is always an anomaly to the rule, and perhaps Southgate can defy that convention. {"uri": "8217519841", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "19:17:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T19:17:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T19:17:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://www.caughtoffside.com/2024/07/09/gareth-southgate-england-euro-2024-2/", "title": "Gareth Southgate admits big strength of his England side is \"not luck\"", "body": "Gareth Southgate is preparing his England side for a Euro 2024 semi-final clash with the Netherlands and the Three Lions boss has admitted that a strength of his squad is \"not luck\".\n\nPenalties have been a thorn in the side of the English for many years and Southgate knows this as much as anyone, having missed a crucial spot-kick in a semi-final clash against Germany at Euro 1996, which resulted in England's elimination.\n\nThe 53-year-old has worked on penalties since taking over as coach of England and their record has improved under his watch.\n\nThe Three Lions experienced a shoot-out win against Switzerland in the quarter-final and ahead of their semi-final clash against the Dutch, Southgate has admitted that this new strength of his team is \"not luck\".\n\nWhat was evident in England's most recent win over Switzerland was how much they prepared for penalties; from the instructions on Jordan Pickford's water bottle to the buddy system that was in place after a player was done with their spot-kick.\n\nSouthgate is trying to get the edge on other nations at Euro 2024 when it comes to penalties and the Three Lions coach has now commented on it as the 53-year-old believes it is an element of the game that he can \"take some control of\".\n\n\"We feel it is something that you can prepare for and that you can take some control of,\" Southgate told BBC. \"In my opinion, it's not a lottery, it's not luck.\n\n\"Of course, the outcome can go either way, but there are a lot of things that you can have influence on and a lot of things that you can control.
