{"uri": "2024-07-417335916", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:13:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:13:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:13:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "url": "https://www.moroccoworldnews.com/2024/07/363799/netherlands-vs-england-euro-2024-semi-final-match-preview-and-prediction", "title": "Netherlands vs England: Euro 2024 Semi-Final Match Preview and Prediction", "body": "The two giants face a closely contested game, with both teams having nearly equal chances of winning, and a significant possibility of a draw leading to penalties.\n\nRabat - In what promises to be a defining moment for English football, the Three Lions face their toughest challenge yet as they prepare to clash with the Netherlands in tonight's semi-final showdown at BVB Stadion Dortmund,8 p.m. local time.\n\nThe stakes are high, with both teams eyeing a spot in the final.\n\nEngland's journey through the tournament has been a rollercoaster of tension and close calls, marked by dramatic late-game heroics and thrilling encounters.\n\nGareth Southgate's men navigated the group stage with two draws and a narrow victory, showcasing resilience but also raising questions about their ability to assert game dominance decisively.\n\nTheir hopes were kept alive by Jude Bellingham's dramatic 95th-minute strike against Slovakia, while a tense penalty shootout against Switzerland in the quarter-finals provided another stern test of their resolve.\n\nDespite the tense performances, England possesses a talented squad with the capability to overturn any match situation. Meanwhile, the Netherlands, under the guidance of Ronald Koeman, have experienced their own highs and lows.\n\nInitially casting doubts with a third-place finish in the group stage, they swiftly rebounded with a convincing victory over Romania in the round of 16. Their quarter-final clash against Turkiye also demanded an extreme spirited comeback.\n\nRead Also: Euro 2024: France vs Spain Semi-Final Match Preview and Prediction\n\nThe Dutch have been on fire lately, finding the net nine times in five matches and boasting impressive scoring statistics. In contrast, England's pragmatic style has enabled them to secure victories through astute game management and crucial interventions when needed.\n\nThis marks the fourth encounter between England and the Netherlands at a major tournament. The Oranje triumphed 3-1 at Euro 88, courtesy of a memorable Van Basten hat-trick. This was followed by a goalless draw at the 1990 World Cup and a decisive 4-1 victory for England at Euro 96.\n\nThe clash tonight is not just about securing a place in the final, but also about proving what they are made of on the grand stage of European football.\n\nFor England, the goal is simple: to harness their potential and deliver a performance that secures passage to the final.\n\nFor the Dutch, it's about capitalizing on their momentum and seizing the opportunity to reclaim their status among Europe's elite.\n\n\"For the whole nation, it's something special. We are a small nation and we're in the semi-finals with England, France and Spain. We are really proud. We had to suffer but it's a great success to get the opportunity to play in a semi-final,\" stated coach Koeman to UEFA.\n\nTonight's encounter is set to be a spectacle of skill, determination, and raw emotion -- a fitting crescendo to what has already been a thrilling Euro 2024 tournament.\n\nAs the clock ticks down to kick-off, one question looms large: who will take that final step to Berlin?\n\n\u00a9 Morocco World News. their Euro 2024 semi-final against England in Dortmund, with the Westfalenstadion's Yellow Wall set to turn orange for the game.\n\nThe 25,000-capacity southern terrace of Borussia Dortmund's home ground is one of the most famous stands in world football and rivals Anfield's equally iconic Kop for the atmosphere fans there generate.\n\nEurope's largest freestanding grandstand looks poised to become a sea of orange rather than white on Wednesday thanks to the Netherlands being notionally designated the home team for the fixture.\n\nThat has seen Uefa hand the Dutch Football Association (KNVB) 8,000 tickets in the stand for its supporters, with its English counterpart given tickets at the opposite end of the ground.\n\nAlthough England fans could still get their hands on many of the remaining seats in the southern terrace, they are likely to be competing against other Dutch supporters, who are expected to dominate that section of the stadium.\n\nDortmund is staging the joint most matches at Euro 2024, with Wednesday's the sixth and last to be played there.\n\nThe previous five have all seen the notional home team take over the southern terrace, with Turkey twice turning it into a Red Wall during the group stages. It was predominantly blue for Italy and France's group games there, while it became white for Germany's dramatic last-16 victory over Denmark. Indeed, the stadium has become something of a fortress for the Germans down the years.\n\nThe fortunes of other teams whose fans have colonised the southern stand at Euro 2024 have been decidedly mixed. In the defence, Arnold at right-back, Gomez left-back and the rest the same as the current team. As it stands the midfield is just non-existent and you always need 2 up front.\n\nMark\n\nNursing a semi\n\nI'm excited. Spain. France. Holland. England. If four supercars in varying nick with varying attributes lined up for a day at the track, you might believe that not pushing excessively hard, staying out of the marbles and taking your laps safely and assuredly could be enough to clock the fastest time of the day. Gareth is absolutely the kind of dude that would be looking for an eco-mode toggle in a Bugatti, he might just bring this thing home you know.\n\nEric, Los Angeles CA (Also looking forward to Colombia vs Uruguay but that would be less a supercar matchup than guys on dirt bikes maybe.)\n\nREAD NEXT: France will obviously bounce Spain out of Euro 2024 because life and the universe are just that cruel\n\nChrist, the redeemer?\n\nOne of the things that really got on my nerves this weekend was this idea spread by commentators that Saka had \"redeemed\" himself by scoring a penalty.\n\nSaka didn't \"redeem\" himself any more than Pearce did in 1996 as there is nothing to forgive.\n\nWe're in the semis so stop moaning - and kudos to Konsa - what a player!\n\nGraham Simons, Gooner, Norf London\n\nIceberg ahoy?\n\nIt's a results business and Southgate now has a World Cup semi-final and quarter- final, and a Euros Final and (at least) semi-final to his name. The question remains as to whether this is because of Southgate or despite him. These are signs I suppose that he has made us \"tournament savvy\", but personally I'm still in the latter camp. I think we could and should have gone at least one step further in each of those competitions, and a better coach might have seen us do that.\n\nThat said, \"style of play\" criticisms, are perhaps a little unfair. When you look back at previous tournaments over the last 50 years or so, how often has the winning team \"won it in style\", having played like Brazil 1970, or anywhere near it? Not that many, especially since the turn of the century, Winners seem to have mostly ground their way through the tournament winning mini-wars of attrition , achieving marginal gains via favourable refereeing decisions, making fewer mistakes than their opponents, being better at penalties, and dumb luck. Or in the case of Spain, passing opponents to death until they surrender out of sheer boredom.\n\nIn my previous email I, among myriad others, said a back 3 plus wing backs was the way to get some attacking width. Well Gareth went for it, kind of, but ultimately his only change in personnel was the enforced one of Konsa for Guehi. So he basically just shuffled the dysfunctional deckchairs he'd used previously, still keeping Trippier on the wrong side and denying us any kind of left side width - yet somehow managing to avoid the iceberg. It was slightly better but only because Saka had the beating of his man down the right. The \"tried and trusted\" full backs continued to be largely awful. Whether playing as a conventional RB or in a back 3, Walker still seems unable to kick a ball in a straight line to one of his own team-mates, or even their general vicinity.\n\nSaka, who I previously criticised as predictable, was finally able to use his go-to \"cut in onto his left and cross/shoot\" move to good effect. It might have had something to do with him having finally gone down the outside on his right most times before that. The double markers were probably expecting him to do that again, which allowed him a bit of space when he surprised them by reverting to type. I guess that's what mixing it up a bit can do.\n\nI've been a big fan of Kane but he looks old and tired in this tournament. Nowhere to be seen when Saka played a cross into a dangerous area, but then neither were Foden or Bellingham. I can't see Gareth dropping any of his stalwarts though. I expect a similar 11 for the semi, and a similar grinding out of whatever result we get. Oh well.\n\nCredit though to Gareth and the players for practising the and keeping their nerve. Awful way to decide top level games though.\n\nKevin Villa (were you watching Glenn Hoddle?)\n\nMORE ON ENGLAND AT EURO 2024\n\n\ud83d\udc49 No Kane or Foden in England teams picked to play the Netherlands\n\n\ud83d\udc49 The ten greatest England players in European Championship and World Cup history features Southgate pair\n\n\ud83d\udc49 Why England and Southgate must drop Harry Kane at Euro 2024: his record in semis and finals is shocking\n\nGreat news on a personal level. Gareths record is unarguable. This is as good as we have ever had it. All this is true\n\nBut .. and I hate using a 'But'... I would 100% rather be England than Germany or Portugal (both touted as 'definite possible' winners playing great football as a team only a game ago)\n\nThe argument if we had lost on pens would have been 'see - the 1st decent team we played we lost'. Before him we lose that shootout (unproveable Jonny I get ya..) but history is proof enough if you are using the same arguments!\n\nWe still might go out to the Dutch.. and they might then be the '1st good team we play' or it might be France / Spain.. or we might win the whole thing\n\nEither way... The bulk of England's players are too thick to learn tactics. So Gareth decides they have to stick with one basic structure for the duration of the tournament, and build that based on facing the best team in the final - an all or nothing approach. But, it doesn't really matter who that is because we know it will be a team better than us. So, he sets us up to kill the game, play sideways and backwards, try not to give away a goal and be ready to nick it on pens. If we get it wrong and go out before the final, it doesn't matter because we're there to win. It's only the final that matters.\n\nTo back this up, he creates a smokescreen suggesting the team isn't playing that well, and hoping it gets better. But he knows he won't change it. They are playing exactly as he wants them to. Everyone sees it as dull. He sees it as honing the approach. If there's no time to drill the team in training, drill them during the real games. He hopes to get pelters because that takes the heat off the team. But in reality, he finds everyone is actually being quite reasonable, so he has to pretend he's deeply hurt by it all and poke the public - who then become angry at being attacked, the criticism becomes real and truly does take the heat from the players.\n\nGareth, you are a genius. An honorable and gallant man, and I salute you. From the moment Southgate was named England manager they have had nothing but glorious luck on their side and have still been unable to get over the line. I fear this occasion may well be the occasion they finally manage to do it. A dour tournament where sides seem absolutely determined to play the most boring brand of football will be won by an England side who have benefitted from one of the most jaw droppingly easy draws I can remember seeing.\n\nThey have managed to make the semi final after managing one win in regulation time against Serbia. Then having to get past the might of Slovakia and Switzerland in the knockout stages. The Netherlands are not the force they once were and will be easily dispatched. Then there's the winner of Spain v France in the final. Whichever side prevails from that game will be knackered as a result of having had to play against actual opposition. Plus France's best player is clearly not fit and unable to see properly.\n\nEngland will win it, the media will make out it's the greatest tournament victory of all time and we will never hear the end of it!\n\nWorld-class Gaz\n\nWith people desperate to credit Southgate as a resounding success because of his amazing record while managing one of the most talented squads of players (currently ranked 5th, only France left above us at the Euros). The key thing seems to be comparison with previous managers. And while it's apropos to consider this list includes luminaries such as McClaren, Allardyce, the Turnip and Hodgson - along with Sven whose only club successes came while bankrupting Lazio - it's also reasonable to consider how he ranks against actually good managers. I look world-class at dancing if you compare me to Ed Balls.\n\nLet's start with that, at \u00a34.9m per year, he is by far the highest paid at the Euros and I believe the most of any International manager. Incidentally, Xabi Alonso gets paid \u00a34m pa.\n\nWhen you take account for it being basically a part-time job (100 games over 8 years is an average of 12.5 per year, vs 45-60 for a top-end club manager), his approx \u00a3286k per game puts him well within the \"salary per game\" range of Emery: \u00a3100k; Arne Slot: \u00a3128k per game; Ancelotti: \u00a3160k; Arteta: \u00a3183k; Klopp: This group are different. They keep possession for longer periods.\n\n\"We haven't always got it right. {"uri": "8217499329", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:59:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:59:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:58:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4509803950786591, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/gareth-southgate-addresses-prospect-earlier-185723943.html", "title": "Gareth Southgate addresses prospect of earlier substitutions against Netherlands at Euro 2024", "body": "Gareth Southgate acknowledged he may need to make more substitutions or earlier ones than he has so far in the Euro 2024 knockouts, when England take on Netherlands in the semi-finals on Wednesday.\n\nThe Three Lions boss only made one change before the 84th minute in the round of 16 against Slovakia, and none at all before the 78th in the quarter-final against Switzerland. England have played 120 minutes twice, and the manager opted against making the sixth change available to him in the added 30 minutes on both occasions.\n\nFollowing the last-eight shootout win, he spoke about several players including Harry Kane and Jude Bellingham being out on their feet and, given the high temperatures in Dortmund ahead of the semi-final encounter, fatigue may be an increased concern for England this time around.\n\nBut changes for changes' sake aren't on the agenda, nor a specifically early change - with Southgate insisting only the flow of the match would decide for him when subs were needed.\n\n\"There are different reasons for making changes, we were happy with the way the team was playing in those knockout games,\" he said. \"We made a sub at half time, too [in the groups against Slovenia], so we don't have a preconditioned way of operating. You look at physical freshness and how they operate individually and collectively, and if they will improve us or not.\n\n\"It's a strange thing that in the biggest games you get less time to recover; we haven't been able to get on the training pitch, and it's been more having meetings. So there's a different physical aspect now, but the players are well recovered and over the next 24 hours we will keep assessing, and the game direction will make those decisions for us.\"\n\nSouthgate further praised the collectiveness of the group and reiterated his belief they would come together to overcome whatever challenges arise, in this game and beyond, should England progress.\n\nAdded to the options - from the start or as sub - is now Luke Shaw, and Southgate all but confirmed he has a part to play against the Dutch, though Kieran Trippier also remains well in the frame.\n\n\"I'm very fortunate to have a fabulous group of players, and we've always worked as a team. When we talk about games we've done, it's always reviewed as how the players and ourselves as staff can do better.\n\n\"This time, it's [noteworthy] how the group has bonded. We've had 21 who have been on the pitch and none have been dead rubbers or unimportant [appearances].\n\n\"Luke has been injured for four months, so it wasn't a possibility to play earlier, but [against Switzerland] he made a good contribution. He gives us balance with the team, but Kieran has done a fantastic job. [Trippier has] played in big nights for us over seven or eight years, and he's been so important in those occasions and around the squad and staff.\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", {"uri": "8215567539", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "16:05:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T16:05:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T16:04:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4509803950786591, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/england-fans-slammed-gareth-southgate-33195618", "title": "England fans slammed by Scott Parker over treatment of Gareth Southgate", "body": "Gareth Southgate has been stoutly defended by Scott Parker, who insists no manager should have objects hurled at them.\n\nSouthgate had paper cups thrown at him by angry England fans after the Three Lions' disappointing goalless draw with Slovenia. Parker was appalled by the supporters' antics and says Southgate has done \"a brilliant\" job in transforming the team and guiding them to three semi-finals in four tournaments.\n\nEngland face The Netherlands in the semi-finals on Wednesday and the new Burnley head coach and former England midfielder said: \"No human being deserves to have paper cups chucked at them.\n\n\"He's fundamentally a good man and whether people agree or don't agree with certain things he does, no-one deserves to have paper cups chucked at them. He's a family man, with children and a wife, and I think that's what sometimes people don't understand.\n\n\"This is a guy at the cutting edge and I'm sure Gareth would be the first to say there are certain elements that are not to his liking. But he's in the semi-finals of the Euros and in terms of that, I think he's done an incredible job.\n\n\"This is a man who has come into an England set-up and changed the culture and changed the environment. Now you're looking at a team that's enthusiastic to be a part of things.\n\n\"I've stood in those shoes as an England player and I look at this squad and the feeling they give you, and that's all down to Gareth.\"\n\nParker, 43, won most of his 18 caps under Fabio Capello and Roy Hodgson and says the England squad back then was fractured by club cliques. He says Southgate has ended all that and made playing for England enjoyable again.\n\n\"I was in a generation where it probably wasn't like that, and that's been well documented by many players, senior players, who have said sometimes the way of England was very fractious in certain moments,\" he said. \"It was different units in those times.\n\n\"I think it's very different now, and like I said, I think that's absolutely full credit to Gareth and his skill set. He's obviously got a huge skill set and that's not easy. He's brought England teams to semis and finals. He's done a brilliant job for me.\"\n\nParker insists England can beat the Netherlands and reach their first overseas final. \"Yeah definitely I fancy them,\" he said.\n\n\"I thought the last game we played, I thought we played very well against Switzerland. I thought that would be the case. In the group stages, I thought we were up against very disciplined, strong teams in terms of their defending.\n\n\"Switzerland, I felt they showed real quality and I think that will be the same with Holland. They are a modern, expansive team, who like to attack and I certainly think we've got the players to attack too. So, I really hope that Netherlands use that possession constructively, to make sure we move it well, quickly and through the lines, asking questions of England.\n\n\"Every team that has gone more on the front foot and moved to press England, they ended up making them give the ball up easily and quickly, allowing the opposition all the opportunity to create chances. Cody is the exact same coming off the right.\n\n\"The only problem is the Turkish team dealt with that really well by doubling up on him, so every time he came inside there was another player to stop that space, so he never had a chance to shoot.\n\n\"You need to counterattack that by having overlapping runs, so he has an option to play somebody in with a reverse pass. {"uri": "8218174167", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "07:02:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T07:02:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T07:02:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4509803950786591, "url": "https://thechronicle.com.gh/netherlands-vs-england/", "title": "Netherlands vs England - The Ghanaian Chronicle", "body": "A high-stakes showdown in Dortmund determines which team progresses to Sunday's decider, where either France or Spain will await.\n\nThrough to a third major tournament semi-final in four attempts - but only by the skin of their teeth - England have become a regular fixture at the sharp end of both Euros and World Cups without claiming the prize, so only silverware will do for Gareth Southgate's squad this summer.\n\nThe Three Lions reached a fourth European Championship semi-final overall by seeing off Switzerland in last week's quarter-finals, despite trailing to a late Breel Embolo goal heading towards the final whistle in Dusseldorf.\n\nBUKAYO SAKA\n\nBukayo Saka sensationally equalised to force extra time, and spot kicks were ultimately required to decide the outcome of a finely-balanced battle. England went on to clinically dispatch all five of their penalties and Jordan Pickford saved from Manuel Akanji, so for the second round running, Southgate's side squeezed through.\n\nHaving previously limped through the group phase, then required Jude Bellingham's stunning strike to spark a fightback against Slovakia, it has been a far from convincing journey to this point - but results are all that matter in knockout football.\n\nSouthgate's 101st game in charge will see England try to become just the sixth team to make consecutive European Championship finals, and a familiar foe stands between them and a place in Sunday's showpiece in Berlin.\n\nHEAD-TO-HEAD\n\nThe Three Lions now face a fourth major-tournament meeting with the Netherlands: the Oranje won 3-1 en route to glory at Euro '88, thanks to a Marco van Basten hat-trick, then a forgettable goalless draw at the 1990 World Cup was followed by a famous 4-1 England win in 1996.\n\nHowever, having won just one of the nations' last nine meetings in all competitions, precedent is not on the side of an English team packed with attacking talent but yet to find rhythm or inspire confidence among their fans.\n\nThe most recent of those nine encounters also came in a semi-final, with the Netherlands winning 3-1 after extra time in the UEFA Nations League - both Southgate and Ronald Koeman were in the dugouts on that occasion too.\n\nKOEMAN'S MEN\n\nSeeking their second European title, after lifting the Henri Delaunay trophy in Germany 36 summers ago, Koeman's men are making their way through the so-called 'weaker' half of the draw, having only emerged from Group D in third place.\n\nFollowing victory over Poland, a draw with France, and an eventful defeat to Austria, the Oranje were handed a relatively kind last-16 tie against Romania, in which they ultimately ran out 3-0 winners.\n\nHowever, a squad led by captain Virgil van Dijk will attempt to win just a second European Championship semi-final tie for the Netherlands; and with a dismal record of four losses from the previous five, the burden of history weighs heavily on their shoulders.\n\nPREDICTION\n\nWhile each game sees a fresh page written, England's history against their Dutch counterparts has been littered with defeats: of all nations they have faced more than 20 times to date, only versus Brazil do they have a lower win-rate (27%).\n\nThat trend could continue in the Euro 2024 semi-finals, as the Oranje's talented attackers are starting to click and will surely punish another tame Three Lions performance. {"uri": "2024-07-413941479", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-07", "time": "09:10:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-07T09:10:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-07T08:57:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://www.telegraphindia.com/sports/football/england-manager-southgate-defends-streetwise-tactics-at-euro-2024-and-says-backlash-is-difficult/cid/2032123", "title": "England manager Southgate defends 'streetwise' tactics at Euro 2024 and says backlash is difficult", "body": "Southgate admitted the criticism he's faced over England's pragmatic, cautious style -- he says his team is \"streetwise\" -- has stung\n\nEngland is in the semifinals of Euro 2024. Some of its fans won't credit manager Gareth Southgate.\n\nAfter beating Switzerland on penalties in the European Championship quarterfinals on Saturday, Southgate celebrated in front of a stand packed with England fans, his players dancing in a line behind him.\n\nIt felt like an answer to his detractors, some of whom even threw plastic beer cups in his direction less than two weeks ago.\n\nSouthgate admitted the criticism he's faced over England's pragmatic, cautious style -- he says his team is \"streetwise\" -- has stung.\n\n\"Every now and then you think, Surely there has to be some enjoyment in this job?' So if I can't enjoy that moment, then I think it's a waste of time. I love the players, I love being in that moment with them,\" Southgate said.\n\n\"I can't deny that when it's as personal as it's been in the last few weeks, on a human level it's quite difficult, but we're fighting. We're not going to stop fighting.\"\n\nEngland has been to the semifinals in three out of four major tournaments during Southgate's eight-year tenure.\n\nNo other England manager in history has achieved that kind of consistent success -- though the team hasn't won a title.\n\nIncreasingly, fans have showed their unhappiness with Southgate's cautious instincts and the fact that the team has rarely played an entertaining style, especially at Euro 2024. Of England's five games, Southgate's team won only once in 90 minutes, the 1-0 opener over Serbia.\n\nAll too often in the past, England started well but couldn't finish off games, Southgate argued. \"We weren't savvy, we weren't tournament-wise,\" he said.\n\nThat's something he's tried to change since taking charge in 2016, when England had just gone out of the European Championship to Iceland under Roy Hodgson.\n\n\"The games that we've ultimately gone out (of tournaments), people can always look back and highlight things. But in general, we've shown the resilience that the teams that win tournaments have had for years and years. Italy, France, Spain,\" he added.\n\n\"It's not all pure football. It's other attributes that they've had, and we're showing a little bit more of that streetwise nature.\"", "source": {"uri": "telegraphindia.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Telegraph"}, I don't fear it anymore, even after just one shoot-out win.\n\nBut I think we'll get it done. If create that one moment, he will score it.\n\nSometimes I feel like there is a lack of respect for what he's done. He's England record goalscorer of all-time. And it's not like he's off playing in Saudi Arabia like Ronaldo, for example - he's just scored a load of goals for one of the biggest clubs in the world last season.\n\nI know he didn't win the league, but f***ing hell, come on! He's class act.\n\nI'm not going to get away from the fact that he's been pretty anonymous in some of the games and he's not played as well as others, but I'd still stick with him and I think he'll score on Wednesday night.\n\nHe had a great game against Switzerland, got a goal and has been England main source of creativity in the tournament. I'll take him to have another effort on target here.\n\nCody Gakpo to Have 1 or More Shots on Target\n\nHe's got three goals already and is clearly the biggest threat for the Dutch. {"uri": "8216933112", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "12:26:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T12:26:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T12:26:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/sport/24440293.england-v-netherlands---five-memorable-matches-teams/", "title": "England vs Netherlands - Five games that helped make a footballing rivalry", "body": "John Stones shows his disappointment during England's Nations League defeat to the Netherlands in 2019 (Image: PA)\n\nThe most recent meeting between the two teams came in the semi-finals of the Nations League in the summer of 2019.\n\nEngland took a first-half lead in Guimaraes, with Marcus Rashford converting from the penalty spot after he had been fouled by Matthijs de Ligt, who was robbed while trying to play a back-pass in his own area.\n\nDe Ligt atoned for his error by claiming a Dutch equaliser in the second half, and after Jesse Lingard had what would have been a late winner ruled out by VAR, England imploded in extra-time.\n\nJohn Stones hesitated in possession, losing the ball to Memphis Depay, and while Jordan Pickford saved the Dutch striker's shot, Kyle Walker could only bundle the rebound into his own goal under pressure from Quincy Promes.\n\nThere was more calamitous defending for the Netherlands' third goal, with Ross Barkley losing the ball deep in his own half after a poor pass from Stones, enabling Depay to tee up Quincy Promes, who rolled home.\n\nEngland: Pickford; Walker, Maguire, Stones, Chilwell; Rice (Alli 106), Delph (Henderson 77); Sterling, Barkley, Sancho (Lingard 61); Rashford (Kane 46).\n\nThe best-ever display by an England team at a major tournament? Quite possibly, with Terry Venables' side ripping apart a strong Dutch line-up in the group stage of Euro 96.\n\nRoared on by a partisan Wembley crowd, England claimed the lead midway through the first half when Danny Blind felled Paul Ince in the area, enabling Alan Shearer to step up to score from the spot.\n\nEngland were rampant after the break, scoring three goals in the space of 11 minutes either side of the hour mark to establish a four-goal lead. Teddy Sheringham scored two, with Shearer claiming the other, as England's slick passing ripped the Dutch defence apart.\n\nThe pick of the goals was Shearer's second, with the number nine firing home after Sheringham slid him the ball sideways to round off a superb passing move that had the mercurial Paul Gascoigne at its core.\n\nPatrick Kluivert claimed a Dutch consolation with 12 minutes remaining, but England's dominance was pronounced as they headed into the knockout stages of a competition that would eventually see them suffer penalty heartbreak at the hands of West Germany in the semi-finals.\n\n\"We took on Holland at total football and beat them,\" said Shearer recently. \"It was a performance I don't think England have bettered in my living memory.\"\n\nEngland: Seaman; Neville, Adams, Southgate, Pearce; Anderton, Ince, Gascoigne, McManaman; Sheringham, Shearer.\n\nDo I not like orange? The game that heralded the demise of Graham Taylor is remembered for all the wrong reasons by England fans, with one of the most controversial refereeing decisions in the history of the national team sealing their side's fate.\n\nEngland needed a draw in Rotterdam to reach the 1994 World Cup finals in the United States, and when David Platt broke onto Andy Sinton's long ball on the hour mark, they looked certain to take the lead, only for Ronald Koeman to tug the midfielder to the ground.\n\nThe referee, Karl-Josef Assenmacher, initially pointed to the penalty spot and looked certain to send Koeman off, only for the defender's protestations to see him reverse his decision and award a free-kick on the edge of the box. Koeman was then booked rather than sent off.\n\n\"What are they being instructed,\" raged Taylor, in footage subsequently shown on the documentary, 'An Impossible Job'. \"What sort of thing is happening here? Absolutely disgraceful.\"\n\nTo make matters worse, not only did Koeman remain on the field, but the current manager of the Netherlands went on to open the scoring five minutes later with a direct free-kick, with Dennis Bergkamp adding a second goal soon after.\n\n\"It was a clear foul,\" Koeman has said subsequently. \"Nowadays, it would have been a red card for sure, but I was very happy that the referee said it was a free-kick and not a penalty.\"\n\nEngland: Seaman; Parker, Adams, Pallister, Dorigo; Merson, Ince, Palmer (Sinton 46), Sharpe; Merson (Wright 69); Shearer.\n\nThe last time the European Championships were held in Germany (then West Germany), England met the Netherlands in a group game in Dusseldorf.\n\nSir Bobby Robson's side were already in deep trouble after losing to the Republic of Ireland in their opening group game, and things were to get worse against the Marco van Basten-inspired Dutch.\n\nEngland were actually the better team in the opening stages of the game, with Gary Lineker and Glenn Hoddle both hitting the post, but they fell behind just before half-time when Ruud Gullit dispossessed Gary Stevens and crossed for van Basten to swivel away from Tony Adams and shoot past Peter Shilton.\n\nBryan Robson equalised for England in the early stages of the second half, but the Dutch were in the groove and after Gullit laid on another inch-perfect pass for van Basten, the striker spun away from Adams once again before firing home.\n\nVan Basten completed his hat-trick with 15 minutes remaining, connecting with a flick-on from a corner, and England went on to also lose their final group game against the Soviet Union to complete a miserable campaign.\n\nEngland: Shilton; Stevens, Wright, Adams, Sansom; Steven, Robson, Hoddle, Barnes; Beardsley, Lineker.\n\nNovember 1946 - England 8 Netherlands 2\n\nThe first meeting between England and the Netherlands came in 1935 and saw England scrape home via the only goal of the game. The second game between the two nations, however, was rather more one-sided.\n\nEngland hosted the Dutch in a friendly played at Huddersfield's Leeds Road ground in 1946 and scored eight goals, six of which came before the interval.\n\nTommy Lawton scored four for Walter Winterbottom's side, with his tally including an 11-minute hat-trick scored between the 24th and 35th minutes.\n\nThere was a strong North-East look to the scoresheet, with Wearsider Raich Carter, famously of Sunderland but by then playing with Derby County, scoring twice and Middlesbrough-born Wilf Mannion, still then playing for his hometown club, also finding the net before the break.\n\nMannion's fellow Teessider, George Hardwick, who was captaining the side, missed a penalty just before the interval, but England added a further second-half goal through Tom Finney.\n\nThe Netherlands' goals were scored by Ko Bergman and Kick Smit, but England were able to reflect on a job well done, having also seen off Wales, thanks to two more Mannion goals, earlier in the month.\n\nEngland: Swift; Scott, Hardwick; Wright, Franklin, Johnston; Finney, Carter, Lawton, Mannion, Langton.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8217070844", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "13:55:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T13:55:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T13:53:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4431372582912445, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13615905/Euro-2024-semi-final-Netherlands-England-Dutch-fans-Aalten.html", "title": "Dutch fans invade Germany ahead of tomorrow's semi-final with England", "body": "Euro 2024: England v Netherlands semi-final is tomorrow at 8pm on ITV1\n\nAn Orange Army has begun invading Germany ahead of the crunch game between England and Holland tomorrow evening - with almost 100,000 Dutch fans expected to travel.\n\nAnd for the first time since the European Championships started, England supporters are set to be significantly outnumbered when Harry Kane and his team kick-off their match in Dortmund.\n\nBecause it's under 50 miles from the Dutch border to the city - about the same distance between London to Brighton - tens of thousands of Dutch fans are expected at the game even though most have no hope of getting a ticket.\n\nWhereas England fans will have to rely on expensive flights, long car journeys and trains and then face paying over the odds for hotel rooms and tickets in the middle of the working week - so far fewer are expected to turn up for the match.\n\nMailOnline today monitored the beginnings of the orange invasion - in which almost 90,000 Netherlands fans are expected to converge in Dortmund.\n\nLibrarian Babs Vroegindewry, pictured in Aalten, Holland, close to the border with Germany\n\nRaymond Stegers, 63, has installed flags and bunting in orange at his home in Aalten\n\nWe headed to the border town of Aalten, one of the first Dutch and German Schengen crossing points, where many residents are on the move.\n\nRead More England must banish the RONALD KOEMAN CURSE when they face the Dutch in their Euros semi-final\n\nAmong them was restaurant manager Loes Oonk, who has decorated the front of her home with a giant Dutch flag with the lion emblem.\n\nShe will travel the 60-minute journey from Aalten, which has a population of just 27,000, with seven friends for tomorrow's match in a mini bus.\n\n'It is very easy for us to reach Dortmund, but not so easy for the English supporters. I think it will give our team an advantage to have so many people in orange shirts in the stadium to support them.\n\n'Maybe the English will have to work and will not be able to come in so many large numbers because of their jobs, but we will be able to come home the same evening from Germany.\n\nThe border town of Aalten is one of the first Dutch and German Schengen crossing points\n\nLoes Oonk has decorated the front of her home with a giant Dutch flag with the lion emblem\n\n'The match is the talk of Holland. We are also excited and really looking forward to it. Everyone is talking about it in this town too and getting their flags and orange shirts ready. Football is very important in the Netherlands, just like it is in England.\n\nRead More Gary Lineker and Alan Shearer name their England XIs to face the Netherlands in Euro 2024 semi-final\n\n'My favourite player is Virgil van Dijk who plays for Liverpool. I think he will be a very important part of the game for us.\n\n'I think we will beat England. My prediction is that we will win 2-1, but the match will be in extra time.'\n\nAcross the street from her home, businessman Raymond Stegers, 63, had installed flags and bunting in orange as well as a giant Dutch flag.\n\nMr Stegers, who wore an orange hat and scarf in support of Holland, said: 'It is going to be a tough match for both sides.\n\n'England have great fans, but so does the Dutch team. I know that there are many people from the border towns going to the game because it is so easy for us.\n\nLocal publican Wilco Leuven said tomorrow night is 'going to be a very busy night in the bar'\n\nMany residents in the border town of Aalten are on the move to get to Germany for the game\n\n'I think it will be 2-2 at full-time and then we will win. I hope in extra time. I pray that it does not go to penalties, because we are not so good at them.'\n\nRead More Moment Jude Bellingham launched astonishing attack on 'match fixer' referee Felix Zwayer\n\nThe staunch Feyenoord fan, who has travelled to England to see Holland play and regularly goes to matches, added: 'I have seen on the television that the English have had incredible support in the stadiums. They have nearly filled them and really love their team.\n\n'But because of the proximity of Holland to Germany, it will be like having an extra player because we will have so many fans more than the England supporters. We will make a lot of noise and sing for our team.'\n\nLocal publican Wilco Leuven said: 'There are many people from Aalten going to the match with England to Dortumnd. But my bar will be full because many will come to watch it on the TV.\n\nA thumbs-up for the Dutch team from this resident of Aalten, which has a population of 27,000\n\n'It is going to be a very busy night in the bar. Maybe the Dutch team will hear our cheers from here!'\n\nRead More ALL 26 England players train on the eve of Netherlands semi-final at Euro 2024\n\nLibrarian Babs Vroegindewry said: 'I am not so confident as others who live here. The England team is very strong and I think we may lose this game.'\n\nBut her friend Juan Lammers, 59, said: 'We have a very good player in Cody Gapko of Liverpool. I think it will be a wonderful match and everybody here is both anxious and excited. I hope Netherlands are the victors.'\n\nIt is reported that upwards of 50,000 Dutch supporters will be inside the BVB Stadion Dortmund, which has an 81,000 capacity, for the match - outnumbering England fans who have been allocated just 6,500 tickets.\n\nThat means around 35,000 ticketless Dutch fans are set to mix with thousands of England supporters without tickets on the streets of Dortmund.\n\nMany of the Dutch fans are planning to gather before kick off, with some travelling from Aalten\n\nThe build-up to the match has seen tickets, accommodation and airline prices surge amid increased demand, with many people facing paying thousands for their journey.\n\nRead More 'Killjoy' London mayor Sadiq Khan blasted over lack of England fan zones\n\nPrime seats - those situated by the halfway line - have been listed for as much as \u00a317,000, while the cheapest seats up in the gods, which usually go for around \u00a370, are barely available for less than \u00a3600, an increase of nearly 1,000 per cent.\n\nFor many of the Netherlands' matches during the tournament, the host city has been packed with Dutch supporters filling up fan zones in their iconic orange livery.\n\nMany of the Dutch fans are planning to gather before kick off and proceed on an 'orange march' to the stadium, letting off flares and singing for their team.\n\nWest Ham fan Barry Hunt, 24, from Dagenham, who has been to three of England's matches and arrived in Dortmund last night said: 'It looks like Holland fans will have it their way on Wednesday.\n\n'A lot of my mates have to work on Wednesday or have run out of money on the first games. My granddad gave me \u00a3500 so I could come to this match.\n\n'I don't have a ticket and I am trying to buy one, but I want to be here singing with the England fans and drinking the beer. Southgate said: \"I'm not too worried about that. When I grew up, I didn't see the 1974 Dutch team but I remember the 78 team.\n\n\"I definitely remember the 1988 team. They played incredible football, in the finals of two World Cups, winning the European Championship, outstanding individual players. I loved watching the Dutch teams.\n\n\"In actual fact Ronald Koeman as a player was somebody I admired very much. We didn't really see centre-backs stepping out of the ball and spraying passes around the pitch in that way. I know we see that more in the English game now but that was unique when I was growing up.\n\n\"The first thing for us now is we've got one game ahead of us and we've got to get that right. So we always want to play as well as we can. The tournament, there's 13 goals fewer than the last Euros. A lot of teams have been really well organised. We've played three teams that play a back five.\n\n\"But we want to make this a memorable night. One of those enjoyable nights when everyone comes together and enjoys themselves. So, without a doubt, we want it to be another one of those.\"\n\nSouthgate has also admitted fatigue could be an issue for England ahead of their semi-final showdown. England have had back-to-back knock-out games of 120 minutes with a penalty shootout needed to beat Switzerland while Holland have won both theirs inside 90 minutes.\n\nSouthgate has been reluctant to make changes in this tournament and is likely to resist again with Marc Guehi pushing to replace Ezri Konsa in defence. Three Lions boss Southgate said: \"It's always a consideration on picking the team, managing the squad. Recovery strategies now are outstanding. There's so much science involved in recovering players.\n\n\"But things will happen over the next five-six days for all of the teams involved where people might start games and get an early injury because you're not able to train as fully as you might to assess all the players.\n\n\"Squads are going to be important, all of the games of the latter stages are quick turnarounds and we've learned from going the distance in two tournaments already the physical demands on these tournaments are really high.\n\n\"It's been factored into all our operations for the last few years. For not just managing the day to day but the weeks we've been away. Managing staff energy, managing players' energy.\n\n\"We cover all of those things. Because all of the staff need to be fresh as well. They need to make big decisions, they've got to work long hours. The travel is a factor. We're covering all of those basis.\"\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp communityand receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. {"uri": "2024-07-416616993", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "19:03:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T19:03:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T19:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.43529412150383, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/sports/betting/euro-2024-semifinal-england-netherlands/article_b1d7a138-42d0-557e-bd34-ec33295c7f30.html", "title": "Euro 2024 semifinal odds, preview & picks: England vs. Netherlands predictions for Wednesday", "body": "Grant Mitchell | For FrontPageBets\n\nIf you make a purchase after clicking on links within this article, Lee Enterprises may earn affiliate commissions. The news and editorial departments had no role in the creation or display of this content.\n\nThe semfiinals continue Wednesday at Euro 2024 as the pre-tournament favorite takes the pitch to keep its European dreams alive:\n\nEngland (-130 to advance) vs. Netherlands (+100) - 3 p.m. ET (Dortmund)\n\nBelow are our Euro 2024 England vs. Netherlands odds and picks for the first semifinal in Munich:\n\nEuro 2024 betting sites, apps & soccer sportsbook bonuses\n\nEuro 2024 semifinal odds, preview & picks: Best bets for England vs. Netherlands odds on Wednesday\n\nEngland entered the tournament as the odds-on favorite to win the competition but was down to second at +250 ahead of the semifinals following a string of unconvincing performances. They needed penalty kicks to get past Switzerland in the quarterfinal and were rescued by Jude Bellingham five minutes into stoppage time the round before.\n\nOn the other side is the Netherlands, which has +440 odds to win the competition. They've scored more goals than any of their remaining opponents, but haven't looked solid in defense either. Luckily, they face a Three Lions club that appears more than willing to play a cagey affair.\n\nEuro 2024 semifinal England vs. Netherlands predictions: Regulation Draw (+190 or better), Under 2.5 goals (-210 or better)\n\nSimilar to France, England has not been anywhere near one of the four best teams at this tournament. Their reluctance to attack, questionable substitutions and dependence on late-game miracles have been extremely frustrating for arguably the most talented team at the tournament.\n\nThe Netherlands team doesn't mind leaving itself stretched at the back if it means it can commit more bodies to the attack. They scored five goals in two knockout matches and regularly both score and concede lots of goals. That sets up an interesting stylistic showdown between an England team which is often hesitant to come out of its shell.\n\nEngland manager Gareth Southgate will not play on the front foot unless he is coerced into doing so. The Netherlands' commitment to sending bodies forward but also to leaving itself vulnerable in defense leads us to believe that this will be a back-and-forth match that is ultimately decided on penalties.\n\nThere are multiple ways to bet such a situation, beginning with looking for value with a draw at a strong +190 price. just as they did in the previous round against Slovakia - rallied and found an instant equaliser through Bukayo Saka's crisp strike.\n\nPenalties were required as the teams could not be separated after extra time and England were faultless in the shootout, scoring all five efforts while Manuel Akanji missed for Switzerland.\n\nThe Three Lions, who were beaten finalists at the last European Championship, will face the Netherlands next after they came from behind to defeat Turkey.\n\nTurkey enjoyed an impressive run to the quarters and looked set to extend their stay in Germany when Samet Akaydin gave them the lead before half time.\n\nBut the Netherlands scored twice in six second-half minutes - first through Stefan de Vrij and the second an own goal - to turn the tie around and progress to their first Euros semi-final since 2004.\n\nNeville described the semi-final clash in Dortmund as a 'proper game' and suggested an England win was 'written in the stars' as they continue to advance despite failing to find their top form.\n\n'That's a proper game,' Neville said on ITV. 'You're always going to face the best teams at some point in the competition.\n\n'England's route so far has been pretty favourable. This is a step-up but you'd expect that in a semi-final.'\n\nPressed for his prediction, Neville added: 'Do you know something? {"uri": "8216680242", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "09:53:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T09:53:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T09:52:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4274509847164154, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/netherlands-route-euro-2024-final-090000899.html", "title": "Netherlands route to the Euro 2024 final: Oranje one win away from Berlin", "body": "Netherlands are in the Euro 2024 semi-finals, so we've taken a look at who they might face en route to a potential final.\n\nUnlike in previous tournaments, Netherlands were not among the pre-tournament favourites to win Euro 2024, and they didn't finish strongly in their group. However, Oranje did enough to make it through to the knockout stages and are now in the semi-finals.\n\nSo, who could Netherlands face in Europe's biggest international football tournament?\n\nLast 16: 3-0 vs Romania - The Netherlands produced an excellent all-round performance, especially after Cody Gakpo gave them the lead halfway through the first half. Two Donyell Malen goals put some well-deserved gloss on the scoreline as Romania rarely threatened to come back into the game.\n\nQuarter-finals: 2-1 vs Turkey - Unlike the previous round, this game showcased the Netherlands' powers of recovery as they came from a goal behind to seal a first European Championship semi-final appearance in 20 years.\n\nSemi-finals: Netherlands will face Group C winners England -- having avoided Gareth Southgate's men in the round of 16.\n\nFinal: Awaiting in Berlin will be the winner of the first semi-final between Spain and France. The former would be a repeat of the 2010 World Cup final, which Netherlands lost; the latter, of course, a replay of the group stage match in June.\n\n2-1 vs Poland - Netherlands had to come from behind to beat a stubborn Poland side but they showed the grit and perseverance needed to win. The Oranje ended the game with 20 shots and there was certainly some promise but their deficiencies were also on show, conceding seven shots on goal and being overrun in midfield at times.\n\n0-0 vs France - In recent history France had been a dominant force against Netherlands, winning seven of their last eight showdowns. They even won two contests 4-0, including on Koeman's first game back in charge. This time we got the first 0-0 in 51 European Championship games. Xavi Simons could have scored the winner, had the referee not disallowed his late strike in a contentious VAR decision.\n\n2-3 vs Austria - Netherlands went into this game top of the group, knowing their destiny was in their hands. But they went behind three times, and failed to comeback the third and final time to fall to a 3-2 defeat. It saw Netherlands drop to third, which was unthinkable at the start of the tournament.\n\nOranje faced an existential crisis not long ago, failing to qualify for back-to-back tournaments. The dearth of talent and a lost generation were cited for this sharp decline on the international stage. Under Koeman's initial leadership, the ship had turned, and now qualification is no longer taken for granted. He can call upon an exciting crop of emerging stars and credible veterans who are mainstays at Europe's biggest clubs.\n\nHowever, recent championship performances have seen the Dutch fall below expectations, and their exit from Qatar 2022 -- losing to eventual winners Argentina on penalties after staging a remarkable turnaround -- still hurts. But, again, the calibre of players at Koeman's disposal can be described as an embarrassment of riches; there are match-winners capable of changing games from seemingly nowhere.\n\nIt is said that a fish rots from the head down. There are doubts about Koeman's ability to lead this generation of players, and questions about his tactical prowess remain. Since his re-appointment, the process hasn't been smooth, with a few uninspiring performances and questionable team selections.\n\nFurthermore, they have struggled with the long-standing issue of players not being able to replicate their club form at the international level, with some high-profile players being singled out. This is where Oranje could unravel. Koeman's pragmatism has frequently stifled any Dutch creativity, and if he goes into this competition with a defensive mindset, then Netherlands progression could be limited.\n\nWhile the talent pool is not in question, the one pulling the strings determines whether they can recreate the summer of 1988 or endure another frustrating tournament campaign.\n\nDuring the qualifying campaign, Koeman experimented with different formations, starting with a 4-3-3 variant before switching to a back-three, which for a while seemed likely how Oranje would play this summer. But he's reverted to the back four at Euro 2024.\n\nNathan Ake shifts over to the left, with Virgil van Dijk and Stefan de Vrij the centre-backs. This allows Netherlands to transition to a back three if the game dictates at times. Denzel Dumfries provides attacking threat from the right.\n\nFrenkie de Jong was guaranteed to start in the heart of the Netherlands midfield but has been ruled out through injury, meaning PSV duo Jerdy Schouten and Joey Veerman occupy the central midfield positions alongside Tijjani Reijnders.\n\nHowever, after his brutal substitution against Austria, there could be limited time for Veerman going forward, which opens the likelihood of Xavi Simons moving into a No.10 role with Jeremie Frimpong or Donyell Malen occupying the vacant right flank.\n\nDespite Netherlands' impressive footballing history, fans often have high expectations for their national team in tournaments. While the team has won one major trophy and appeared in three finals, expecting them to perform at the same level as Europe's top teams is unrealistic.\n\nMany observers now recognize this fact, and even though fan support remains strong, there is a growing sense of realism. However, missteps will be scrutinised and overanalysed, especially since the Dutch will field a squad of talented players.\n\nIf the team clicks and goes on a successful run, expect enthusiastic support that could rival Max Verstappen's popularity.\n\nNetherlands finished second in Group B to qualify for Euro 2024, losing twice to eventual winners France.", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports Canada"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Koeman", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"uri": "2024-07-416143037", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "11:24:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T11:24:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T11:22:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4274509847164154, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/sport/football/england-semi-final-everyone-angry-odd-country-3159746", "title": "England are in a semi-final and everyone is angry - what an odd little country", "body": "Let's never take England in the last four of the European Championship for granted - and try and remember what went before Gareth Southgate\n\nEngland with a good man manager and an evidently decent bloke but who, eight years on from his first match, had become unpopular in the national consciousness. Doubts over the attack after only scoring twice in three group stage games, although England did only concede once (a 1-1 draw).\n\nA young attacking midfielder who seemed to carry the responsibility for acting as the antidote to the tactical conservatism and yet still played with freedom. A scratchy last-16 victory after extra-time against unfancied European opposition. Progress that required a late comeback in the quarter-final, albeit against a team that had beaten the defending champions earlier in the tournament.\n\nHave you got the joke by now? Yes, all the above refers to Italia '90, that cultural cornerstone when everyone fell back in love with the England national team despite pre-tournament protestations that it had lost its way. That, it seems, is the point at which 1990 and 2024 differ. World Cup 1990 brought us all closer together; Euro 2024 has been set upon dividing us, or allowing us to divide ourselves.\n\nTo an extent, this is merely a question of timing. Back when Sir Bobby Robson was doing his touchline jig, England's public were waiting for something to love. The domestic game was in a state of great flux and two-way authoritarian mistrust. The lack of English teams in Uefa competition post-Heysel had created a knowledge vacuum of how English football was played.\n\nNow, simple supply-and-demand economics. Football is a capitalist orgy and a 24-7 event. The domestic game has reached its peak of omnipotence and the Premier League is king of the fiefdom.\n\nEvery punter has all the excitement they want all of the time and, thus, if the England team doesn't excite, it will gain and keep few friends. Add to this: nobody just ignores anything anymore; you must moan about \"having to watch\".\n\nThe weirdest aspect of this anger is how even facts become debated. Gareth Southgate is the first England manager in the post-truth era. He's never beaten a decent team (he has). Beating Germany didn't count because they weren't good enough. He's only reached three semi-finals in four tournaments by technicality (England's most consistent run ever). He's only faced bad teams and England always beat those at major tournaments, didn't they? (No).\n\nAs England prepare to play only the third semi-final in their entire history on foreign soil, I wonder whether we might look back on this period and agree that people spent too much of it being angry.\n\nHindsight may give this all a golden tinge. We had a squad full of likeable, talented players who went deep into tournaments and we spent the whole time griping, booing and throwing beer cups at the manager. Odd little country, in many ways.\n\nThat is clearly what England's players think. During time spent with them over the last fortnight, each individual has displayed a mystification at the treatment and criticism of Southgate. They all say he has given them their belief and that he created an environment in which playing for England is an honour more than a chore; it wasn't always that way.\n\nThey're asking for a little more faith in them and him and with good reason. Much has been written about how World Cup 2018 brought the nation closer to the England team, but this was a miracle of symbiosis: the team looked more happy because they felt the love, the team played better because they looked more happy and the team got more love because they played better.\n\nSo we have to ask: what good does this negative focus do? If, on a basic level, we all want this team to go as far as it can in every tournament, is it not worth temporarily parking all reservations? I know you're desperate to tell everyone online that you fell asleep watching England pass the ball around, but maybe save the 38th rendition of the anecdote for another time.\n\nHistory rarely feels as if it is being made in the present. Only seldom do you feel the significance of an occasion in real time. The rest is constructed and shaped by hindsight. In 1968, when England travelled to Florence for their first Euros semi-final outside England, nobody thought that it would be their last for 56 years.\n\nWe are the lucky ones, with three semi-finals in six years: World Cup 2018, Euro 2020, and now this. Nights such as these should never be taken for granted for we can never know how many of them we shall get. These are the pillars of our football lives, holding up the roof during fallow decades and stopping the rain rendering the whole place condemned.\n\nSo try to come together - if it goes well, you will always remember who you were with and where. Try to park your doubts about tactical conservatism.\n\nTry to focus on the positives. Try not to scowl for too long when the ball is passed backwards. Try to remember that it wasn't like this for too long and try to remember the strength of your desperation and despair back then.\n\nTry to save the worst of your opprobrium for when England are actually eliminated. Try to have faith that they have faith in themselves. Try to...enjoy it? It is really 50-50 in my opinion.\n\nEngland have shifted formation as the tournament has worn on but Koeman insists Oranje will be ready to deal with a back-four or a back-three depending on what Gareth Southgate decides.\n\n\"It's always good to know in what kind of system they will start,\" he said. \"We are prepared for both ways to compete against them and we know they have a lot of individual qualities.\n\n\"Both teams are really strong and it will be a good fight. There are different ways to win. You can't always play the football that you like to play. Sometimes you need to work harder and be more aggressive.\n\n\"We are both experienced coaches, Gareth has much more years as a national coach, but we know each other well.\n\n\"We played several times against each other. We played against each other in the semi-final of the Nations League (which the Dutch won 3-1 in 2019) - let's hope we get the same result\n\n\"It's good to know we have a big support from our country. England was moments away from elimination in the Round of 16 against Slovakia, only to score two goals late. Then England needed to win a penalty kick shootout against Switzerland in the quarterfinals. The Netherlands was down 1-0 in the quarterfinals to Turkey before scoring twice in the second half.\n\nWhile England aims at a return to the Euro final, the Netherlands hasn't played in the Euro final since 1988 when it won the tournament.\n\nHere's everything you need to know for Wednesday's UEFA Euro 2024 semifinal match:\n\nKickoff is slated for 3 p.m. ET on Wednesday, July 10.\n\nThe television broadcast will be available on FOX, with pregame coverage starting at 2 p.m. ET. Ian Darke (play-by-play), Landon Donovan (analyst), Geoff Shreeves (sideline reporter) and Mark Clattenburg (rules analyst) will provide coverage for FOX Sports.\n\nA Spanish-language television broadcast is available on Univision/TUDN.\n\nFOX Sports will provide a live stream option. Vix will provide a streaming option for the Spanish-language broadcast. Streaming is also available on Fubo.\n\nAccording to BetMGM, these are the odds for the regular-time result of the match: Netherlands +210; Draw +180; England +165. The over/under for goals is 1.5.\n\nPer BetMGM, Spain is the current favorite to win UEFA Euro 2024 at -175, followed by England (+275) and the Netherlands (+500).\n\nDortmund (BVB Stadion Dortmund). Also known as the Westfalenstadion and Signal Iduna Park, the venue is the regular home stadium for German Bundesliga club Borussia Dortmund, which played in the 2024 UEFA Champions League final against Real Madrid. The stadium hosted four games during the 1974 World Cup and six games during the 2006 World Cup. Dortmund is hosting its sixth and final UEFA Euro 2024 game during the Netherlands-England semifinal.\n\nGoalkeepers (3): Justin Bijlow (Feyenoord), Mark Flekken (Brentford/England), Bart Verbruggen (Brighton & Hove Albion/England)\n\nDefenders (7): Nathan Ak\u00e9 (Manchester City/England), Daley Blind (Girona/Italy), Matthijs de Ligt (Bayern Munich/Germany), Stefan de Vrij (Inter Milan/Italy), (Liverpool/England), Ian Maatsen (Borussia Dortmund/Germany), Tijjani Reijnders (AC Milan/Italy), Jerdy Schouten (PSV Eindhoven), Joey Veerman (PSV Eindhoven), Georginio Wijnaldum (Al-Ettifaq/Saudi 2024 semi-final with England after UEFA decision", "body": "The Netherlands appear to have been handed an advantage for their Euro 2024 semi-final against England following a UEFA decision.\n\nOn Wednesday England will play in their third semi-final in four major tournaments, with the Netherlands standing between them and the final of Euro 2024.\n\nGareth Southgate's side have underwhelmed in Germany, but they will be confident of beating a side that haven't exactly set the world alight either.\n\nWednesday's clash will take place at the BVB Stadion in Dortmund, the second biggest venue at the tournament following the Olympiastadion in Berlin.\n\n66,000 fans will be in attendance to watch the clash, although 60 per cent of the sell-out crowd are expected to be supporting the Dutch.\n\nIn addition, the fact that Dutch supporters have been allocated the stadium's 'Yellow Wall' means the Netherlands will effectively have home advantage.\n\nAs reported by Mail Sport, UEFA have allocated half of the Westfalenstadion's south stand to Dutch fans, with the other half going on general sale.\n\nThe south stand - dubbed the 'Yellow Wall' due to it housing the most vocal fans of Borussia Dortmund - is set to become the 'Orange Wall'.\n\nThere will be some England fans seated in the Gelbe Wand area, but they will be massively outnumbered by thousands of Oranje supporters.\n\nEngland fans might also be concerned about UEFA's choice of referee for the match.\n\nDutch authorities are expecting between 75,000 and 80,000 fans to travel across the border to Germany, while 30,000 England supporters are set to travel to North Rhine-Westphalia for the huge match.\n\nThe winner of the clash will face either Spain or France in the final on Sunday.", "source": EUROS DAILY: Harry Kane has to come out of the England XI - it's holding them back and it's time for Ivan Toney or Ollie Watkins\n\nTrent Alexander-Arnold has said that 'pressure makes diamonds' after scoring the decisive spot-kick in Saturday's penalty shootout against Switzerland.\n\nAlexander-Arnold stepped up to take England's fifth penalty with the chance to put his side through to the last four and he took it by emphatically smashing his spot-kick into the corner of the net.\n\nIt sent the Three Lions into the semi-finals for Euro 2024 and the Liverpool man had a message for fans hours after the game finished.\n\nHe tweeted that 'pressure makes diamonds' with a series of photo of himself netting the spot-kick and a couple of the celebrations.\n\nJordan Pickford saved Manuel Akanji's effort in the 5-3 triumph to set up a semi-final against the Netherlands in Dortmund on Wednesday.\n\nTrent Alexander-Arnold posted this tweet shortly after England's win over Switzerland\n\nSpeaking after the game, manager Gareth Southgate credited his side for finding ways to win.\n\n'There's what we ideally want to be and then there's how we've needed to find ways to win with all the obstacles we've had,' Southgate said.\n\n'Going back to losing players a couple of months ago, losing players just before the tournament, different balance of the team, different challenges all the way through, really.\n\n'But as I said to the players, with England it was often start 25 minutes really well, ahead in games and then and then out in the early knockout rounds.\n\n'We weren't savvy, we weren't tournament wise. This group are different. They keep possession for longer periods.\n\nAlexander-Arnold scored the winning spot-kick to send his team to the semi-finals\n\n'We haven't always got it right. The games we've ultimately gone out in people can always look back and highlight things.\n\n'But, in general, we've shown the resilience that the teams that win tournaments have had for years and years.\n\n'Italy, France, Spain, you know, it's not all pure football. It's other attributes that they've had and we're showing a little bit more of that streetwise nature.\n\n'We want to always be competitive in tournaments. England should be competitive for the coming years. This is a young team - a lot of them are going to be around for a long time.\n\n'But, of course, now we want to deliver one. "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 98}], "image": null, "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9712618", "eventUri": "eng-9712618", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment":
